In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. May Allah, the Exalted, send blessings upon our master Muhammad and all his family.
May Allah increase your desire for literature and love for knowledge, guide you to the proof, lead you to the clear path, help you in your quest with rectitude, and grant you success in achieving your goal upon inquiry.
You asked me, may Allah strengthen you, to record for you verses of vivid similes from poets and their witty innovations therein. People, may Allah strengthen you, have preceded us in selecting poetry and distinguishing it, but they did not categorize it into chapters. This is because poetry is divided into three types:
From it is the proverb (Mathal) that circulates, like the saying of Al-Akhtal:
'Glory swore truly it would not ally with them ... Until the ten fingers ally with the palm of the hand.'
And like the saying of Al-Farazdaq:
'As for the enemy, we do not soften for him ... Until the stone softens for the chewer's molar.'
And from it is the strange metaphor (Isti'arah), like the saying of Al-Tirimmah:
'So I said to her, O mother of Bayda', indeed ... My youth has been spilled and my skin has withered.'
And like the saying of Al-Hutay'ah:
'They competed with you, so they revealed from their quivers ... Ancient glory and arrows that are not reversed.'
And from it is the vivid, rare simile (Tashbih), like the saying of Imru' al-Qays regarding the eagle:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry ... At her nest, are jujubes and withered dates.'
And like the saying of Adi ibn al-Riqa' in describing the wild bull:
'He drives a nasal-sounding (female), as if the tip of his horn ... Is a pen that took from the inkwell its ink.'
Whatever falls outside these three categories is mediocre or inferior speech with no benefit or utility.
I saw the most majestic of these types and the most difficult for its creator is the simile. That is because it only occurs to one whose contemplation is prolonged, whose sense is refined, and who distinguishes between things with his subtle thought. I will record for you in this book selected verses of simile, and I will intersperse the different meanings and common similes with rare and witty verses. I will limit myself to a collection in which you will find enjoyment, pleasure, education, and exercise, avoiding prolongation that is met with boredom. I will follow this with a book on proverbs and a book on metaphor. And through Allah is power and strength.
We begin in the name of Allah with the similes of the Creator of things, Mighty and Majestic, in His Book, for He is the most perfect witness and clearest proof. Among what He likened physical objects to is His saying, Mighty and Majestic: 'And the moon, We have measured for it mansions until it returned like the old date stalk.' And His saying, Mighty and Majestic: 'Its spathes are like the heads of devils.' And His saying: 'As if they were rubies and coral.' And 'As if they were hidden eggs.' And His saying regarding the simile of actions: 'But those who disbelieved – their deeds are like a mirage in a lowland which a thirsty one thinks is water until, when he comes to it, he finds it is nothing.' And His saying: 'The example of those who disbelieved in their Lord is that their deeds are like ashes which the wind blows forcefully on a stormy day.' Examples like this are numerous in the Qur'an. And in Allah we seek help for every pursuit.
The Arabs, may Allah support you, make similes using 'ka-anna' (as if), like the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'As if the eyes of the wild beasts around our tent ... And our saddles are onyx that has not been pierced.'
And using 'ka-man' (like who), like the saying of Aws ibn Hajar:
'For indeed you two, O sons of Janab, you found ... Like one who crept hiding while a bell was on his neck.'
And using the Kaf (like), like his saying:
'And a fire like the magic of the oud, its light is raised ... With the night by the gusts of cold winds.'
And using 'Mithl' (like/similar), like the saying of Al-Salami:
'Like the one whose family thinks she is ... A virgin maiden while she is in the ninth (month of pregnancy).'
And using 'Ka-ma' (just as), like the saying of Ka'b ibn Zuhair:
'She does not hold to the promise she made ... Except as water holds sieves.'
And using 'Ka-mithl' (like the likeness of), 'Ka-amthal' (like the likes of), 'Takhalu' (you imagine), 'Tazunnu' (you think), 'Takadu' (almost), and the like. Also by hiding one of these particles if the poet cannot maintain the meter by showing it, like his saying:
'I rose to her after her family slept ... The rising of water bubbles, state upon state.'
He meant 'Like the rising of water bubbles.'
Chapter (2) On the Pleiades (Al-Thurayya)
Among the beautiful similes is the saying of Imru' al-Qays regarding the Pleiades:
'When the Pleiades appeared in the sky ... Like the appearance of the folds of a detailed sash.'
A group of poets likened it, hitting the mark or coming close. Among that is the saying of Ibn al-Tathriyyah:
'When the Pleiades are in the sky as if they are ... Pearls that fell from their string and scattered.'
Another said in this meaning:
'When I reached, and the Pleiades were as if they were ... A necklace of pearls whose string was pulled.'
Another said:
'And the Pleiades appeared to its night traveler as if ... At the western side, they were a chained earring.'
Ali ibn al-Abbas al-Rumi said similar to it:
'I sipped his saliva after midnight ... While the Pleiades on the western side were an earring.'
Dhu al-Rumma said describing a land he crossed:
'I arrived at it traversing blindly while the Pleiades were as if ... On the top of the head, a bird circling over water.'
'Its Aldebaran crawls on its tracks ... So neither is it outstripped nor does it catch up.'

Abu Qays ibn al-Aslat said:
'And the Pleiades appeared in the morning to the one who sees ... Like a bunch of white grapes when it blossoms.'
Ibrahim ibn al-Mahdi followed him and described a land he crossed, saying:
'I traversed it while the Pleiades star was humble ... As if it were a bunch of grapes in the skin of the night.'
Al-Mubarrad recited:
'When the Pleiades appear in the sky ... The sharp-eyed sees them as seven stars.'
'On the liver of the sky (Al-Jarba'), and they are as if they are ... A splint of pearls mounted on a wrist.'
He likened it to a wide bracelet (Dastinj).
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the Pleiades in the late part of its night ... Are the opening of blossoms or a silver-inlaid bridle.'
He also said:
'So hand it to me, while the Pleiades are as if they are ... The harvest of narcissus which the cupbearer gifted to the boon companions.'
Ibn al-Rumi likened it to a white foot, mentioning a woman's hair:
(Munsarih Meter)
'The coverings of her locks cover a foot ... White, capable for the onlookers.'
'Like the Pleiades when they appear at dawn ... After clouds, and a remover removed it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz took it and added, saying:
'And I see the Pleiades in the sky as if they are ... A foot appearing from mourning clothes.'
The Arabs call the Pleiades 'Al-Najm' (The Star). They recite regarding its rising in winter:
'Drinking wine became pleasant when ... The Star rose in the evening.'
'And the shepherd sought for his winter ... A cloak against the cold.'
Another said regarding its rising in summer:
'The Star rose early in the morning ... So the shepherd sought his small waterskin.'
Ka'b al-Ghanawi said regarding Gemini (Al-Jawza'):
'And Gemini leaned until it was as if it were ... Tents of riders descending in the desert.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if Gemini in the highest horizon ... Are branches of blossoms or a sash of leaves.'
Al-Dulfi said regarding the stars in general:
'When the sky is a garden ... Its stars are like flowers.'
'And the atmosphere is pure ... Not muddied by the spreading of dust.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if our sky, when it revealed ... Through its stars at the morning.'
'Are gardens of violet whose dew is moist ... Between which the blossoms of chamomile open.'
Imru' al-Qays said:
'I looked at it and the stars were as if they were ... Lamps of monks lit for a return journey.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the stars of the night in the coal-black darkness ... Are heads of pins fixed in veils.'
Abd al-Aziz ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir said:
'And Sirius intercepted the middle of the sky ... As if it were a ruby in a comb.'
Abu Nuwas likened the dirham to it, saying:
'I describe a falcon that defeats falcons ... Victorious, white, round.'
'You imagine it in its size to be Sirius.'
Another said:
'It delights my eye to see in his place ... Canopus (Suhayl) like the glance of the squint-eyed looking arrogantly.'
Jarran al-Awd said:
'I watch a glimpse of Canopus as if it ... When it appears at the end of the night, blinks.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'As if Canopus is the figure of a thirsty person leaning ... From the night into a pool of the earth drinking.'
Another said:
'When Sirius the Crosser (Al-Abur) was as if it were ... A suspended lamp upon which are churches.'
'And Canopus appeared from afar as if it were ... A flame which a fire-starter turns away from the wind.'
Abdullah ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And Canopus appeared to the night traveler as if it were ... Upon every star in the sky a watcher.'
Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
'As if Canopus, while the stars are in front of him ... Are opposed by a shepherd behind a herd.'
'When he stood from his squatting, you said a monk ... Prolonged standing after a long bowing.'
Al-Alawi said regarding Vega (Al-Nasr al-Waqi'):
'And a rider of three like the tripod stones took turns ... On the darkness of the night until the light of dawn flashed.'
'If they gather, you name them with the name of one ... And if they separate, they will not be known till the end of time.'
Al-Ta'i recited:
'And the daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) appeared and loomed ... Like a bier (Na'sh) upon which is a new garment.'
'And as if Gemini, when it rose ... And hung down, was an extended canopy.'
Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
'And the stars of Gemini extend their arm ... To embrace the darkness while bidding farewell.'
'And as if they are in the air the bier of a brother of decay ... Weeping, stopping at times, and escorting.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding the inclining of the Pleiades:
'And the Pleiades inclined to the West ... Just as the fearful one inclined to the sound.'
'As if its stars, while dawn is appearing ... To our eyes, are sick women recovering.'
Ibn al-Zubayr al-Asadi said regarding that:

'And the Pleiades pierced the West as if ... They were therein a white banner lowered for stabbing.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said similar to it:
'And the Star fell and Gemini followed it ... Like one with an earring she turned and it fell.'
He also has regarding Al-Ayyuq (Capella):
'And the Pleiades desire ... In setting a desire.'
'Like the falling of the high-bred horse ... Almost dropping the bridle.'
And he has, 'And he gave me wine to drink while the night was wrapped in the morning':
'And the Pleiades were like the blossoms of a branch scattered on the West.'
Abu al-Najm said regarding the sun's inclining to set:
'Until when the evening revealed it clearly ... Between the sides of a frightening twilight.'
'It is on the horizon like the eye of the cross-eyed ... Inclined, it almost did but did not yet do.'
He also said:
'A hunter poured upon him when he was heedless ... And the sun was like a mirror in the hand of the paralyzed.'
Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
'And a drinking gathering I came to seeking joy ... At evening, while the eye of the sun in the horizon was dozing.'
Ibn al-Rumi said in this meaning:
'As if the inclination of the sun then its setting ... While it started to sicken in the wing of the night.'
'Is the squinting of an eye whose eyelids drowsiness ... Muddies sleep in them while it closes.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'The sun continues to glance at us with a look ... Sick, exhausted, from behind a curtain.'
'Trying to tear a cloud while it refuses ... Like an impotent man wanting to marry a virgin.'
Regarding the rising of the sun from between the clouds, Ibn al-Rumi says:
'And the day is cloudy so its sun ... In it is rising and veiled.'
'It continued to play hide and seek with us while sending ... A light that watches us without flame.'
Dhu al-Rumma said describing a woman:
'She shows you the whiteness of her lock and a face ... Like the horn of the sun that broke through then moved.'
'It hit a gap so it appeared dim ... No, but the rest of it was inserted deeply.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding the sunset:
'When the afternoon sun was patched and shook ... Upon the western horizon a trembling saffron.'
'And bid farewell to the world to fulfill its vow ... And the rest of its life diminished and became thin.'
'And it glanced at the blossoms while it was sick ... Having placed a cheek on the earth submitting.'
'Just as the eye of an exhausted person glances at his visitors ... Pained by his ailments what he is pained by.'
'And the eyes of the blossoms remained wet with dew ... As the eye of the sad person welled up to shed tears.'
'And between the fainting of separation upon them both ... As if they were two pure friends bidding farewell.'
Another said regarding the halo of the sun:
'And the sun appearing, moving as if it were ... A shield kissed by a brave lancer.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding the crescent moon:
'I did not taste the taste of sleep, if only you knew ... As if my insides were on embers.'
'From a moon showing half of itself ... As if it were a burner of perfume.'
He also said:
'Welcome to a Fitr whose crescent has shone ... So now go early to the wine and be early.'
'And look at it like a boat of silver ... Burdened by a load of ambergris.'
Another said:
'And the light of the full moon appeared at the end of a night ... On a peak as if it were half a bracelet.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a night:
'The waning ate its crescent ... Until it appeared like the curvature of ivory.'
Tha'lab recited to us:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
'As if the son of its cloud was a demon ... Appearing at the horizon from a little finger.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And he came to me in the shirt of the night hiding ... Hurrying the step out of fear and caution.'
'And the light of a crescent appeared, almost exposing him ... Like the clipping cut from a fingernail.'
He also said:
'When the crescent separated from its night ... It became to one who sees and describes it.'
'As if it were a dark man whose beard turned gray.'
Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
'What is with the crescent emaciated in the west ... Like the Nun (letter) written with gilded water.'
Al-Najim said:
'And a blamer dirtied my name when ... He blamed at dawn, what a dirtying.'
'I said to him: You woke me for wine ... So bring it and be fond of rebuking.'
'And the full moon has faced me rising ... As if it were a slice of melon.'
'And its saffron smeared the wall ... When it rose, what a smearing.'
Abu al-Askar recited to me:
'And a people, they were kings, I guided them ... In a desert where no star light appears.'
'Nor a moon except small as if it were ... The clipping of the fingernail of the dyed girl.'
Chapter (3) On the Clarity of Morning
From the beautiful similes regarding the clarity of morning is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:

'And there appeared to the night traveler who completed the journey ... At the ends of the night, a famous opening.'
'Like the horse with a white belly standing ... The saddle cloth tilted from him and the color is blond.'
He likened the mixing of light with darkness to the horse with a white belly, which is 'Al-Anbat'.
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a cupbearer who makes the napkin from him ... In the place of the sword's long suspenders.'
'He went early while the morning under the night was appearing ... Like a blond horse casting off the saddle cloths.'
Abu al-Farah recited:
'They spent the most pleasant night until appeared ... A morning that became clear like the blaze-faced blond horse.'
'So they clung together at separation out of passion ... The clinging of the creditor to the excess of the helmet's cloth.'
From Andalusian similes is the saying of Abu Yusuf al-Ramadi:
'And a night of intimacy whose darkness we illuminated ... With stars of wine shining so they are sipped.'
'Until the light of morning appeared as if ... Luqman departed and Joseph arrived.'
Humayd ibn Thawr said:
'And you see the morning as if in it is an unsheathed ... Sword carried by a blond horse.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And nothing startled us except the morning as if it were ... Coverings of Coptic linen on a swimming rose-colored horse.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'As if the pillar of morning is a neck and upper chest ... Behind the darkness from a free woman of color, unveiled.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And the morning follows Jupiter as if it were ... A naked man walking in the darkness with a lamp.'
Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
'And the dawn in the clarity of the air is rose-colored ... Like wine radiating in glass.'
He also has:
'As if the clearing of night from the face of its morning ... Is the fading of dye that was covering whiteness.'
Dhu al-Rumma said with beautiful metaphor:
'She stayed in it until the wood withered in the earth ... And the dawn dragged the Pleiades in its sheet.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'So I stood up and the night, the morning clears it as ... Smiling cleared the bright front teeth.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'When the horizon of light became bare ... Like the smiling of the dark-lipped mouth.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding a black woman:
(Munsarih Meter)
'As if she, while joking makes her laugh ... Is a night whose darkness was bared from a dawn.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'Your smiling while colors are eclipsed became ... The smiling of morning in dark gloom.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I may leave early on lean horses ... While morning has shone or has not shone.'
'Until it appeared in its saffron-dyed robe ... And its star like the bright lamp.'
'As if it were the blaze of a blond colt.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'I may leave early while morning in its darkness ... Is like the fringe of the cloak on its fold.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Until the light of a splitting morning appeared ... Like the appearance of gray hair in the parting of the head.'
Al-Shamardal ibn Sharik said:
'And the light of morning appeared so we distinguished ... Just as you saw the oiled parting.'
Another said:
'When the night, the morning in it was ... A split like the parting of the oiled head.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Until the morning appeared from a veil ... As the blade appeared from a scabbard.'
He also said:
'And the dawn lifted the darkness as if it were ... A male ostrich upon eggs whose side was uncovered.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'When the morning appeared from its veil ... Like the appearance of the gray-haired from his robe.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Until the morning appeared from the veil ... Like gray hair descending upon youth.'
He also said:
'When the light of morning cleared and opened ... The clearing of purity from under turbidity.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'I may leave early while the night in its sanctuary ... Camping in the flowers of its stars.'
'And the morning has begun in its skin ... Leaving it with the sides of its chest.'
'The leaving of the guardian the back of his orphan.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I may leave early while the night in its hide ... Is like the Abyssinian fleeing from his companions.'
'And the morning has uncovered its canine teeth ... As if it is laughing at his leaving.'
He also has:
'As for the darkness, when its shirt thinned ... It showed the whiteness of morning like the polished sword.'
He also said:
'And I followed the rain whose clouds drip ... While the morning is confused like the eye of the blue-eyed.'
He also said:
(Munsarih Meter)
'Do you not see the dawn under its night ... Like a kindler who spent the night blowing charcoal.'
Describing horses, he said:
'So they arrived before the early morning ... While the western horizon has redness.'
'As if it were the eyelids of the eye of the ophthalmic.'
He also has:
'Until I saw the night in the horizons with black locks.'

'And as if it were, when it appeared in the East, the line of a mustache.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding the blackness of the night:
'To you we tore the wing of a night as if ... The lands had applied kohl from it with antimony.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Explain to me how you came to my sanctuary ... While the eyelid of the night is kohled with pitch.'
Another said:
'And the night threw its chest upon him ... As if its blackness was the color of ink.'
Abd al-Samad ibn al-Mu'adhdhal said, and it is beautiful metaphor:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
'I say while the wing of darkness is felted ... And the night has a hand in every valley.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And a desert like the sky I crossed ... While the night had dyed the pebbles with black.'
He also said:
'She visited us while the night was dark as if it were ... Two wings of a crow from which he shook off the rain.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O many a night like the wing of the raven ... I waded through before the rising of the sun.'
He also said:
'O many a night black of cloak ... Wrapped in the wings of a crow.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And a night like the bride's gown I donned ... With four, while the figure in the eye is one.'
'A black Alafi (camel), a white sharp sword ... A reddish-white Mahri (camel), and a noble magnificent man.'
Al-Buhturi said similar to it:
'O my two friends in the midday heat from Ma'n ... ibn Awf and Buhtar ibn 'Atud.'
'Seek a third other than me for I am ... The fourth of the reddish-white camels, the darkness, and the deserts.'
Chapter (4) On the Chameleon
From the beautiful simile with the chameleon is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma describing a land:
'And a barren, waterless desert where crouched ... The dusts of summer from every side.'
'As if the hands of its chameleon, sunning itself ... Are the hands of a sinner asking Allah for forgiveness, repenting.'
The chameleon is a small animal resembling the lizard that comes to a tree known as the Tandub and similar branching trees, holds two branches of the tree with its hands, and faces the eye of the sun. Whenever the eye of the sun moves from a stem, the chameleon lets go of it and holds another stem until the sun sets, then it hides. Regarding that is the saying of Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi:
'How was a chameleon of a Tandub tree available to her ... Not releasing a leg (branch) except holding a leg.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding a songstress:
'What is the matter with her, she has become beautiful while her watcher ... Is always ugly, may watchers be ugly.'
'That is only because she is the sun of the forenoon ... Her watcher is always the chameleon.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'While the chameleon's color began to yellow ... And its dewlaps turn green from the heat of the midday.'
'And it stretches with the palms until it is as if it is ... A brother of wickedness whom his crucifier raised on the trunk.'
Abdullah ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a desert in which are eggs of sandgrouse, broken ... As if they are flasks in the nests.'
'As if its chameleon, while the sun melts it ... Is a heater who approached the flame of the fire, cold.'
From good metaphor in it is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'The chameleon prays in it to the sun, standing ... On the trunk, except that he does not say Takbir.'
'If the afternoon shifted the shadow, you saw him ... Inclining (Hanif), and at the horn of forenoon he triumphs.'
He informed that it turns facing the sun wherever it turned.
Al-Buhturi said regarding Babak when he was crucified:
'Overlooking the sun, erected for it ... At the ends of the trunk like the chameleon.'
Chapter (5) On the Crucified
The poets have likened the crucified person frequently. Among the best of what was said in that is what Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Ukhaytil al-Wasiti, known as Barquqa, recited to us describing the day of separation:
'As if he were a lover who extended his reach ... On the day of farewell to bid farewell to a departing one.'
'Or one standing from drowsiness, having laziness ... Persisting in his stretching from sloth.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Babak:
'He gifted to the back of the trunk his back, thus ... Does one who loathed the back of the tawny spear.'
'High, as if the trunk pulls his arm ... And his height is from humiliation and lowness.'
'No ankle is lower in position than his ankle ... Even though he is high above every ankle.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'There was for him in the atmosphere a rope he measures ... Whenever a rope ended, a rope was made available for him.'
'He embraces the breaths of winds at dawn ... The farewell of departure for which no saddle is prepared.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And it healed the vitals from their intensity ... That Babak became the neighbor of Maziyar.'
In Al-Miftah after his saying: 'And it healed':
'His second in the liver of the sky, and he was not ... Like the second of two when they were in the cave.'
'Black of clothes as if wove for them ... The hands of the hot wind armors of pitch.'

'They went early and traveled on the backs of standing horses (crucifixes) ... Which were led for them from the stable of the carpenter.'
'They do not leave, and whoever sees them thinks them ... Always on a journey of journeys.'
Following this in metaphor is the saying of Muslim:
'And the head of Mihran, you mounted its peak ... A supple (spear) that sufficed him instead of the neck and throat.'
'He continued to be harsh with grace and despise it ... Until a wood rose with him upon a wood.'
'You placed him where the wind doubts him ... And the hyenas of the desert envy the birds regarding him.'
'The beasts go early and throw him with their eyes ... Breathing in the air breaths upwards.'
Al-Khuzaimi said:
'And a group who became riders on wood ... Erected, whose anchor has anchored in the earth.'
'Stripped except what was of waist-wrappers ... No successor is hoped one day for their wearer.'
The other said regarding a standing one:
'Sitting with a strap in his mouth ... Grim-faced, showing molars.'
'Spreading his reach without embracing ... Tilting his head without drowsiness.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'How many in the land of Sham you left of them ... Remaining, overlooking the land of Najd.'
'Playing Dastband alone, even if ... He had a distraction from Dastband.'
Al-Mubarrad recited for him:
'He stood and did not seek help from his leg ... He became familiar with his dwelling despite his separation.'
'As if in the figure, from his bonds ... He saw a beloved he intended to embrace.'
'As if he is laughing from his cheeks.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'God showed you to me as a companion of a trunk ... Hugging you, not the hug of commitment.'
'Like a sodomite having a long penis ... Thighing the rented one from a standing position.'
Ibrahim ibn al-Mahdi said:
'As if he were the limb of a ram and the air for it ... Is the oven of a grilling woman and the trunk is a skewer.'
Di'bil said:
'My eyes have not seen like the row of the Zutt ... Fifty of them crucified in a line.'
'As if you dipped them in naphtha.'
He singled out one and said:
'... As if he, in his excessive trunk.'
'Is a brother of drowsiness serious in stretching ... Sleep has mixed with him and he did not cover.'
The best of what was said in that is the saying of some Bedouin:
'And as if he were a head at the head of a desert ... Whose stick his hands tied to the shoulders.'
Chapter (6) On the Horse
From the excellent similes in describing the horse is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'And I may leave early while the birds are in their nests ... With a short-haired one, shackle of the wild beasts, huge.'
'Attacking, fleeing, advancing, retreating together ... Like a boulder of rock the torrent brought down from above.'
So he described him with speed in running and success in pursuit.
Abdullah ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding the speed of the horse:
'Faster than water to a descent ... And than the return of the glance of the suspicious.'
Another said, who is Ali ibn al-Jahm:
'Upon a horse like the glance in the speed of the glance ... And like the heart, his heart in intelligence.'
'Eyes do not see him except as a phantom ... And he is like the phantom in folding.'
Ibn al-Qariyyah described a horse Al-Hajjaj gifted to Abd al-Malik, saying:
'I have sent a horse of good stature, smooth cheek, preceding the glance and exhausting description.'
A Bedouin was asked: How is the running of your horse? He said: He runs as long as he finds ground.
Poets have many poems describing the horse, among them Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi, Al-Nabigha, Al-Ja'di, Al-As'ar al-Ju'fi, Muzarrid, Salamah ibn Jandal, Tufayl al-Ghanawi, and others from the ancients and moderns and those in between. But the condition in what I explained in this book is selecting rare similes, not descriptions and metaphors. What came in mention of this chapter is much, and if we intended to categorize chapters, the condition in simile would be void, good selection would cease, and the lean would mix with the fat and the cold with the hot. In Allah we trust and seek help.
His saying: 'Shackle of the wild beasts, huge': The 'Awabid' are everything that became wild of wild cows, gazelles, etc., singular 'Abidah'. From it their saying: 'You have brought an Abidah of speech' i.e., its wild/strange one. He informed that he caught them so he became like a shackle for them. In success with hunting, he says in another poem:
'When we rode, the children of our family said ... Come, until the game comes to us, we gather wood.'
Umarah ibn Aqil said mentioning a horse:
'And I see the wild beasts in my right hand whenever ... His rein is in my left hand one day.'
Abu Nuwas said in similar confidence:
'I may leave early while the birds are in their dwellings ... With dogs frolicking in their leashes.'
'Counting the eye of the wild beast among their foods.'
Al-Shammakh said:
'Little of old wealth other than a bow and arrows ... As if what is shot of the wild beasts is frozen (Tariz).'

i.e., stiff and cold. The 'Haykal' is the building, and the horse is likened to it if it is huge. Regarding that is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'Like the built Haykal except that he ... In beauty came like an image in a Haykal (temple/altar).'
Imru' al-Qays said:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
'And I ride in the fright a Khayfanah (locust-like mare) ... Her face covered by spreading palm branches.'
'Al-Khayfanah' is the locust, and the long-legged, meatless female horse is called 'Khayfanah', and that is praised in her.
'She has a hoof like the cup of the boy ... A knotted shank was mounted in it.'
He meant her hoof is cup-shaped, which is firmer for her. Regarding that is the verse of Ibn al-Khara':
'She has a hoof like the cup of the boy ... The mouse takes a cave in it.'
'Al-Wazif': Between the pastern and the knee.
'She has a rump like the rock of the stream ... A harmful torrent exposed it.'
It is said 'Sayl Juhaf' and 'Juraf' if it swept away everything. Thus Al-Juhfah was named because a flood in Jahiliyyah swept it away.
'She has a tail like the train of the bride ... She blocks her vulva with it from behind.'
The train of the bride is dragged because she is most shy on that night.
'She has a forehead like the back of the shield ... The capable maker smoothed it.'
'Al-Mijann': The shield. He meant her forehead is wide.
'If she advances, you say a gourd ... Of the green ones dipped in the pools.'
He meant she is smooth like the 'Dubba'' which is the gourd. Slenderness of the front is praised in female horses, therefore they likened them to the thorn/needle for the slenderness of its front.
'And if she turns sideways, you say a locust (Sur'ufah) ... Having a tail behind it extended.'
'Al-Sur'ufah': The locust. He likened her for her lightness.
'And if she retreats, you say a tripod stone ... Rounded, having no trace.'
'And she runs like the running of the escape of the does ... The capable skillful one missed them.'
Combining good simile, good metaphor, and brilliance of meaning are the verses of Al-Ta'i describing a horse Al-Hasan bin Wahb gave him. They are beautiful in the connection of their arrangement and description. If we detached the verses of simile from the verses indicating them or pointing to them from it and others arranged in its order, the verse would come mutilated and cut off, and the benefit in it would be little and the enjoyment from it narrow. Our purpose in what we establish is rare similes. So if the verse of simile is connected to what follows it, we mention it if it indicates it, and if it stands alone and nothing else is mixed with it. Likewise, if something comes with no simile resembling the meaning of what has a particle of simile, we mention it with it and add it to it.
Al-Ta'i said:
(Munsarih Meter)
'Excellent enjoyment of the world he gifted you with ... A magnificent one, neither deviating nor cowardly.'
'Yellow of them (horses) as if he were the yolk of the ... Egg, pure as if he were the handle of a bow.'
'His neck is a trunk of Arak, and what is ... Behind the rump of him is a rock of Jals.'
'Saffron almost flows from the water of his ... Sides, and Wars is gathered from his back.'
'Refined in his genus and possessed the goal ... By himself, so he alone is a genus.'
'Smeared from his color so he came as if ... The sun was eclipsed in his skin.'
His saying: 'So he alone is a genus': He meant his offspring is attributed to him excluding others for his nobility, as it is said 'This horse is from the lineage of Dhu al-Iqal' and 'Ashqar Marwan' and the like. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions: "Follow me, you will become houses or households." He said: And the family of Abu Bakr are called Bakris, not Taymis, and the family of Umar are called Umaris, not Adawis.
His saying: 'Pure as if he were the handle of a bow': 'Al-'Ajs' is the handle of the bow. It became pure and beautiful due to the frequent touch of the hand on it.
Al-Buhturi said regarding a blond horse:
'A marking that deceives the eyes, you see that ... Upon him from it are filings of gold.'
'The dye of the horizon between the end of a night ... Passing its affair and the beginning of a dawn.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a bay horse:
'And an aged horse, four are his lights ... As if his supper is from his skin.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'Did your hands return me with an A'waj (noble horse) ... Like the arrow of the Nab' tree in harmonized feathers?'
'With a dark one like darkness, blaze-faced clearing ... With his blaze the darknesses of the night.'
'You see his white anklets ascending in him ... The ascent of lightning in the waterless cloud.'
His saying: 'Like the arrow of the Nab' tree': He meant an arrow and likened him to it for his smoothness and slenderness, as Jarir said:
'And the chase with the leading folded their backs ... The folding of the merchants in Hadramout of the cloaks.'
Al-As'ar said describing gathered horses:
'They come out from the gaps of dust frowning ... Like the fingers of the cold person, squatting then warming himself.'
The cold person, when warming himself, gathers his fingers and does not spread them.
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And horses the leading folded until they were as if ... Brown tubes from the spears of Al-Khatt, withered.'
'We poured our whips upon them unjustly ... So hands fast and feet flew with them.'

Similar to it is his saying regarding a horse:
'The most wasted thing is his whip when he rides him.'
Likening them to tubes is an old, circulated simile. Similar to it is the saying of Abu Du'ad:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
'And I may leave early in the whiteness of morning ... And the ends of a night turning its tail.'
'With a horse disputing with me a nose-rein ... Leading, pure of lineage.'
'If shackled, he rushes blindly whoever led him ... And his neck sinews turn and he extends.'
'Like the shaking of the Rudayni spear between palms ... Running in the tubes then trembling.'
Al-Ta'i said mentioning a horse:
'If he visited a field, he captivated its people ... Or a club, the sitting ones stood for him.'
'You see the composed of the people, their eyes ... Have become ugly from his beauty while they look askance.'
'As if a lightning flash appeared to them ... In the drought, or a bride was led to them.'
'High, if you view him from the side, adorned him ... A moist top and a dry bottom.'
'As if madness mixed with him ... Or wine flirted with his head.'
'The envier sought refuge for him out of stinginess with him ... And souls fluttered over him in fear.'
Al-Buhturi said, and he was a describer of horses:
'As for the excellent horse, we have tested his day ... And a day suffices as news for his year.'
'He raced the excellent horses and flew from their imaginations ... In precedence, and almost flew from his own imaginations.'
'Joyful, the sides of a blaze slap him ... Coming the coming of the full moon at its completion.'
'He blackened, then cleared to the eyes of an onlooker ... His sides, so he shone in his darkness.'
'The sides of his mane inclined so they were as if ... The branches of a tamarisk inclined under its doves.'
'And the front of the ears, you think that ... With them he sees the person who is in front of him.'
'And as if his rider behind his occiput ... Is a pillion rider, for you do not see him from his front.'
'His sides softened so it was imagined that he ... Is related to the rattan in his bones.'
'In a flame like gray hair passing by my parting ... Flirting with it from his gray hair with his passion.'
'And as if his neighing when he rose with it ... Is thunder rattling in the crowding of its clouds.'
'Like the crow walking competing with his companions ... With the blackness of his dye and the beauty of his stature.'
'And the horse is the most attracting visitor for provision ... As long as you do not visit him with his saddle and bridle.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I may leave early while the morning is like gray hair ... With an aged, marked, swift horse.'
'Having an ear like the palm leaf of the branch ... Or a myrtle leaf overlooking a rod.'
Al-Umani the Rajiz recited to Al-Rashid in the description of the horse:
'As if his two ears when they perked up ... A feather or a pen sharpened.'
Those present knew he made a grammatical error and did not know how to correct it. Al-Rashid said: Say: 'You imagine his two ears when they perked up.'
Adi bin Zaid said regarding a horse:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
'He has a neck like the trunk of the tall palm ... And the ear is listening like the pen.'
Al-Mubarrad mentioned that Jarir said: I entered upon Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan while Ibn al-Riqa' was reciting his Daliyyah (poem ending in Dal) to him. When he reached his saying 'He drives a nasal-sounding (female), as if the tip of his horn', I said to myself: By Allah, the Sheikh has fallen, where will he get 'As if'? When he said 'A pen that took from the inkwell its ink', I envied him, so I went out and did not recite anything.
Al-Buhturi said:
'And a blaze-faced in the dark time, ankleted ... I went from him on a blaze-faced, ankleted.'
'Like the built Haykal except that he ... In beauty came like an image in a Haykal.'
'A tail as the cloak is dragged, defending ... A mane, and a mane like the lowered veil.'
'Joyful, shaking a forelock in a blaze ... Pure white, whose anklets flow in rocks.'
'Like the returning intoxicated one, most of his walk ... Width-wise on the far, longest array.'
'You imagine Gemini in his pasterns ... And the full moon is the blaze of his rejoicing face.'
'Pure of skin, as if concerned with it ... For the purity of his color, the polishers of a polisher.'
'And as if shook upon him its dye ... A red wine of Baradan or Qutrabbul.'
'And you imagine him clothed in cheeks, soft ... Whenever the glance connects with them, they blush.'
'And you see his flame rising in the dust ... In color and intensity like the ignited fire.'
'Trilling of neighing, as if in his tones ... Are the tones of Ma'bad in the beginning.'
'He possessed the eyes, so if he appeared, they gave him ... The look of the lover to the approaching beloved.'
Ibn al-Zayyat said regarding the workhorse (Birdhawn) he took from Al-Wathiq:
'And as if your saddle when it topped you was a cloud ... And as if under the cloud was a star.'
'And you became ringing of bridle, as if ... In every limb of you a cymbal is struck.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:

'And a town that is not possessing a peak ... I shortened it with an aged, truthful (horse).'
'Excellent companion of travel among my companions ... He throws the pebbles of the road with the leg.'
'As if he is a shooter without verification.'
He also said:
'I may leave early with an aged ... Marked, swift horse.'
'Repelling the pebbles with a hoof ... Like the overturned cup.'
'His blaze became clear ... In the place of frowning.'
Al-Buhturi said asking Ibn Humayd for a horse:
'So help in raiding the enemy with one folded ... His insides the folding of the rolled book.'
'Either with a blond, bright, covering the war ... From him with the like of the blazing star.'
'Clad in a marking that painted his sides ... With blood, so nothing meets you but blood-stained.'
'Or a black, pure of skin, as if he is ... Under the brave one, a cover of Birandaj (black silk).'
'Burning, the whip stirs from his downpour ... The stirring of the side winds of the fire of Arfaj.'
'The places of his tread are light, so if he ... Ran in the sands of Alij, he would not raise dust.'
'Or a pure white, illuminating behind him ... A back like the back of the trembling deep water.'
'The anklets are hidden even if they reached his chest ... In a white glittering one like the bracelet.'
'Complete with a black mane, unique ... In what follows it, and a turquoise hoof.'
'Or a piebald coming to the eyes when he appears ... From every amazing color with a sample.'
'I throw the thorns of spears with him and return him ... Like the wolf (Sim') in whom the thorns of Lycium made an impression.'
Al-Abbas bin Jarir gifted a workhorse to Al-Mutawakkil on Palm Sunday and wrote to him with a poem containing (Hazaj Meter):
'And I have for you a workhorse ... Like the light of the star in brightness.'
'He has the two neck sides of a gazelle ... Terrified of the hunter.'
'If his rider overlooks ... With a back of him, bunched.'
'And his soul boiled, you thought ... In him is the sting of a wasp.'
'Upon him are black dots ... Like musk upon camphor.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a donkey and she-donkeys (Hazaj Meter):
'He grazed two months at the two monasteries ... Lean-bellied like the folded scrolls.'
'They turn to terror ... Eyes like flasks.'
'And ears, listening ... Like halves of hive covers.'
'As if they meet the earth ... With the tails of wasps.'
Another said regarding a horse:
'He came like the flash of lightning, his rain boiled ... His first swims and his last overflows.'
'So his hoof does not touch the ground.'
Khalaf al-Ahmar said regarding a bull:
'And as if his buttocks strove ... That his four (legs) do not touch the ground.'
Another said regarding dogs:
'As if they raise what is not put down.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And I leave early at the edge of the night ... With a spirited, bay, flying one.'
'Galloping wet his sides as ... The cup of wine overflowed in the hand of the boon companion.'
Another said regarding a sweating horse:
'As if he, while his eye is high ... Wrapped, came from the bath.'
Al-Buhturi gifted a horse to Ubaydullah bin Yahya bin Khaqan and wrote to him:
'What do you see in a compact, thick-legged one ... From the lineage of A'waj like the looming meteor?'
'The humbleness of the young does not hold him back ... The weakness of fatigue, and he is not the tiredness of the aged.'
'He struts in a marking whose light ripples ... The rippling of chainmail on the spearing brave.'
'If the thirsty were to sip in it, he would not incline ... A glance to the sweet flowing fresh water.'
'I gifted him so you may go white, clear ... From him upon a joyful, white, clear one.'
'So it would be the first tradition transmitted ... Or the praised one accepts the gift of the praiser.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And I have trodden the rain, carried by ... A horse like the color of the morning when it arrived.'
'He walks and turns sideways in the rein as ... The adored one possessing coquetry turned away and repelled.'
'The gathering of the herd's limbs, so the ... Running is not upon him when he runs with intensity.'
'He wet the oryx with their blood and ... A body of him did not get wet with sweat.'
'And as if he is a wave that melts if ... You released him, and if you held back, he froze.'
He also has:
'And I race the rein of the morning, early ... While the night is exposed of sides, departing.'
'And the star, a Levantine wind polishes it ... And the morning is like the mane under the night, uncovered.'
'With a swimming, huge, high-chested one, his spurring places ... Extending the step a span while he overlooks.'
'A blaze was completed for him like the morning, shining ... Its flowing almost drips from his face.'
'If he is earrings one day with the bridle, he appears ... As if he is a tender girl with an earring in her ear.'
Chapter (7) On Hunting and Victory

Among the similes in hunting and victory is the saying of Abu Nuwas regarding the dog:
'As if his jaws when he smiles ... Are the heads of nails on his edge.'
'As if behind the meeting of his eyelids ... Is the ember of Ghada wood sprinkled from its fire.'
'So he turned like the star in its descent ... The turn of the pointer at midnight with his fire.'
Dhu al-Rumma said regarding the speed of running:
'As if he is a star in the trace of a demon ... Marked in the blackness of the night, swooping down.'
Ibn al-Rumi took that and said at the end of a poem mocking a man:
'Take it, pursuing the one who turned away, marked ... As if it were a star in the trace of a demon (Ifrit).'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a female dog:
'And a bright female dog like the meteor ... You think her in the speed of gliding.'
'A luminous star appeared in pouring down ... Light of tread on the dust.'
Khalaf al-Ahmar said regarding a bull:
'Like the shining star, exerting ... A run whose fastest escapes the glance.'
'And as if his buttocks strove ... That his four (legs) do not touch the ground.'
Abu Nuwas said describing the dog:
'He sent him like the arrow when he shot high with it ... Outstripping the glance of the eye in his dust-raising.'
'He almost slips out of his skin ... Like the flash of lightning in his cloud.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a female dog, her time of running was not seen ... Ever when she was released from her strap.'
'I waded with her a night seen like her skin ... As if it borrowed the color of her coat.'
'So she saw ten coming after her ... And was released, so she launched from her knot.'
'Like the arrow, knowing nothing but her seriousness ... The Merciful caused me to lose the day of her loss.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding the dog:
'As if his back muscles when he slips away ... Are the back muscles of a snake persisting in its gliding.'
'As if the claw in his sheath ... Is the razor of a craftsman returned to its handle.'
'You see him in the run when urged ... Almost exiting from his skin.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a female dog that boasted over the dogs ... With a yellow skin like gold (Ziryab).'
'Gliding like the gliding snake.'
The meaning of Abu Nuwas's saying: 'Almost exiting from his skin': belongs to Dhu al-Rumma describing two bulls that fled:
'They do not save any remaining (effort) from the deep running ... Until the skins are almost peeled off them.'
Kuthayyir said regarding a horse:
'If he runs relying on his mother ... He almost splits his skin from his flesh.'
Ibn al-Riqa' said regarding two running bulls:
'They take turns in a sheet of dust ... White, woven, which they both wove.'
'Folded if they arrive at a hard place ... And if the hooves find soft ground, she spreads it.'
Al-Tirimmah said regarding a bull:
'The lands show and hide him as if he were ... A sword on a height, drawn and sheathed.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding dogs:
'You imagine them in the circle of collars ... Laughing teeth from the width of the jaws.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding it:
'You see if you opposed him fleeing ... Daggers that grew in lines.'
'He gives you his utmost abundant run ... A running, you see from his spurring the fingernail.'
'Stripping from his ear thongs.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a female dog with whom youths went early ... Time released them from its hand.'
'As if she, when she stretched, is a snake (Jan) ... Or a spear and her snout is the spearhead.'
'And gazelles appeared for her glance ... So she caught up with what the rein caught up with.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'You see him with two jaws, line by line ... And a smooth lip and a lank jaw.'
'That and two back muscles, if he stretches ... You say two straps that excelled cutting.'
'You see if the running was envy ... Claws, black tripod stones, smooth.'
'He pulls his ears with them a pull ... You imagine two arrows from him stripped.'
'They do not fall on the ground except ahead ... As if they hasten something picked up.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a horse:
'And four as if she snatches it ... You imagine her hastening something she calculates.'
Al-Jahiz recited:
'He almost, at the intoxication of liveliness ... Flies in the air without a wing.'
Another said, who is Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'You think him flying while he is running.'
Another said:
'Her steps outstrip the glance in precedence as if they were ... Arrows of speech or meteors of stars.'
'As if the daughters of jumping (legs) when they separated ... Came upon her with branching deaths.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'So she saw a herd of gazelles ... And left them without fatigue.'
'You likened my glance from a distance ... To a dip of a black pen.'
'Satisfied with blood instead of meat.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding the falcon:

'As if his eyes when they shone ... Are two segments of eggshell of red cornelian.'
'In a high head guiding a beak ... Like the curve of the Jim in a left-handed palm.'
'One who thought about it with a mind says ... If he added an Ayn to a Fa and a Ra.'
'And connected with the Jim, it would be Ja'far.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And we terrify the game with a white falcon ... As if he is in a buttoned coat of mail.'
'And a breast embellished, adorned ... As if it is a parchment of hidden lines.'
He also said:
'I went early in a worn garment of night ... With a caster of glance in every horizon.'
'And an eye that confirms him when he glances ... As if it is a narcissus without leaves.'
'Blessed, if he sees, he has been provided.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Repetition clothed him from its weaving ... A brocade on the breast, woven.'
'He has spears above his gloves ... They combine elevation and sharpening.'
'Every spearhead clamored from his back ... You imagine the curve of his side a Nun.'
'And a beak, blackish, having a hook ... As if it is the knot of eighty.'
'And an eye whose ducts were made to drink ... Gold that pleases the moneychangers.'
'Al-Mawdun': Arranged one next to another. 'Wadantu al-khusa': I arranged the palm leaves. 'Tanyifan': Elevation. 'Nayyafa 'ala al-mi'ah': Exceeded it. 'Ash-Shagha': The upper beak overhanging the lower. From it the eagle is called 'Shaghwa''.
He also said:
'He polishes an eye duct, intense in expelling (Tahr) ... As if kohled with gold dust.'
'In a head gathered like the gathering of the stone (Fihr) ... And a breast like the hard stone.'
It is said 'Ayn Tahra'': If it expelled the speck. 'Al-Malmum': The evenly round. 'Al-Qahqarr': The hard of stones.
Another said describing a magpie (Mutaqarib Meter):
'If Allah blesses a bird ... Then may Allah not bless the magpie.'
'He turns two eyes in his face ... As if they are two drops of mercury.'
'Long of tail feathers, short of wing ... Whenever he finds negligence, he steals.'
Another said describing a she-camel:
'As if her eye, from the length of what she endured ... Of the heat of midday, is oil in flasks.'
Al-Shamardal al-Yarbu'i said regarding a hawk:
'As if his eyes when he revealed them ... Are two rubies whose buyer profited.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a falcon:
'I may leave early at the breath of morning ... With a lord of hunting, possessing liveliness.'
'Hanging the glances on the figures ... Running in the air with the wing.'
'Collected feathers, beautiful in whiteness ... Upon him from it is like the bubbles of wine.'
'Possessing a bell like the loud cockroach.'
He also has:
'And youths went early while the night was dark ... And the light of morning accused of rising.'
'As if their falcons are commanders of an army ... On their shoulders is the rust of shields.'
He said regarding the blue-eyed ones:
'And a blue-eyed one, succulent from his youth ... As if the slough of the snake is from his clothes.'
Al-Shamardal said regarding the hawk:
'I may leave early while the night is in its robe ... With a Tuji (hawk) who hunted in his youth.'
'So he swooped like the boulder when he rose with it ... As if with the hollow of his dye.'
'Is the safflower of the dyer or his butcher ... Or the extraction of musk with which he is painted.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a strong falcon understanding the speech of the speaker ... Rounded of head, grand of shoulder.'
'Hooked of claws, seeking, passing through ... As if they are Nuns of the hand of the fast writer.'
'Possessing a breast wearing a beautiful brocade ... Like the beginning of Lams in the parchments.'
'Or like the extension of kohl in the eye ducts ... And ten geese appeared to the glance of the watching eye.'
'In a green sea (Ghalafiq) ... So he passed like the wind with a true resolve.'
'Until he approached it the approach of the thief ... Then rose over it with a flapping wing.'
'So they began [to fall] dead or perishing.'
He also has:
'And a strong falcon not devoid of discipline ... Seeing the distant thing like the near.'
'Falling the fall of the bucket into the well ... With a foreign, inverted eye.'
'Like the eye of the cross-eyed possessor of frowning ... He saw geese in moist soil.'
'So he was like the terrified, frightened one ... Penetrating into the North and the South.'
Abd al-Samad ibn al-Mu'adhdhal said regarding the cheetah:
'As if she, with the squint in her eyes ... And the black lines on her jaws.'
'Are Turks whose antimony ran from their eye ducts.'
Another said regarding it:
'And there is nothing for the chase but a cheetah ... As if the Kurds threw upon it.'
'From their nature or the lions gave birth to it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding the cheetah (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And no hunting except with a jumping one ... Walking on four like the fringe.'
'Hugging the prey to her throat ... Like the hug of affection of one who does not love.'

'If he sees her running behind him ... His consciences whisper of destruction.'
'She has a seat in the place of the pillion rider ... Like a Turkish woman captured by the Arabs.'
'And her eye is running with its kohl ... And she is adorned with jet from gold.'
Chapter (8) On the Snake
From the similes regarding the snake is the saying of Al-Ahmar:
'And a snake as if it were a rope ... Black, there is no cure for its touch.'
'So its touch and death are equal.'
Another said:
'From every moving one, sharp of jaws ... Until if he followed between two sloughings.'
'And returned like the branding iron heated by the blacksmith.'
Khalaf said:
'And as if she wore on the top of her color ... A garment of clothes worn out by decay.'
'In her eye is a cast and in her nose ... Flatness and in her fangs like knives.'
He also has:
'He has a green neck, his back extended ... Tattoos like the beautification of the striped Yemeni.'
'To a head like the millstone, round ... Having black dots and two eyes like blood.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I describe a speckled one whose bitten victim does not live ... If the sword cut her, no moisture would stick to it.'
'She throws, when she sloughs her skin on the ground ... As if it were the sleeve of a coat of mail cut by a hero.'
Another said:
'If cut with knives, no moisture touched her ... And if the charmers surrounded her, they would not be able.'
Khalaf said:
'And a snake whose dwelling is the sands ... As if he, when he twisted, is an anklet.'
Ashja' al-Sulami said regarding a farting man mentioned to Malik bin Tawq al-Taghlibi:
'Indeed a man seeking my hunting with a lean ... Bow-legged, wet, tight-trousered one.'
'Is like one dangling a withered hand in a hole ... To a snake like the stripe of the garment, let down.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said regarding it (Mujtath Meter):
'A body like the Arak stick ... Not approved for a Siwak.'
'There is no benefit in it for a seeker ... Except the assumption of your destruction.'
Another said:
'So if you saw, you saw a stick of Arak ... And if you knocked, you knocked the horns of a mountain goat.'
'Created as death for souls and a sign ... For the askers and a lesson for the onlooker.'
Abu Safwan al-Asadi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And from a snake that does not answer the charmers ... Speckled, having a head of hair like the rope.'
'Deaf, silent, long of hibernation ... Wide of jaw, bare of back.'
Another said:
'Speckled, between a snake and a serpent ... As if in his jaw are two spearheads.'
'And in the sockets of his head are two lamps.'
Khalaf said:
'And folded on the sand dune like the plate ... As if he is dark from the night, dusk.'
Another said:
'His jaw muscles were created separate and his head ... Like the disk flattened from barley flour.'
'And as if his two jaws when you viewed him ... Are the jaws of an old woman rinsing for purification.'
'And he turns an eye for the sting as if it were ... The two eyes of a brave snake from behind dust.'
Another said:
'O Lord, if my brother Zayd ate ... My flesh unjustly, second drinking after first.'
'Then send him a serpent from the root ... Flat-headed like the disk or the camel's hoof.'
Another said:
'And a viper whose touch is like the file ... In the size of two spans like the leg of the cripple.'
'As if his eyes are a lit lamp ... You imagine the sound of his repeated blowing.'
'The creaking of a camel's two fangs in a rough ground ... Or the boiling of a cauldron that has not cooled.'
A man from Banu Shayban said:
'And a snake like the ring of the bracelet ... Its limit is a span of the spans.'
'As if it is a rod of flowing water ... Smiling from the like of the blazing of fire.'
Another said:
'And a snake summering in the sands ... As if it is a piece of worn rope.'
'You imagine the sound of its incurable blowing ... The sizzling of meat on the frying pan.'
'Turning two eye ducts like wicks.'
Khalaf said:
'As if the sound of its skin when it spun ... Is the sizzling of meat at a capable cook.'
Another said:
'Short-tailed, not exceeding the cubit ... Turning two eye ducts like the brave snake.'
Khalaf said:
'Then he brought a snake that does not save ... Short-tailed like the pawn of chess.'
Khalaf al-Ahmar said, and it is the best said in that even if it had no simile:
'A serpent of rocks that does not fold from shortness ... Long of ends without failure.'
'A calamity that became small from old age ... Wide of the two jaws, cross-eyed of look.'
'Smiling from crooked sharp [fangs] like needles.'
Abd al-Samad said:
'As if saffron mixed with indigo ... On his back was sprinkled with dragon's blood.'
'A big-headed one fell like the twisted rope ... Possessing a sharp point like the sharp spearhead.'
'Extracting the soul before the blood.'

Another said describing the sound of milking:
'As if the sound of its flowing stream ... Is the hissing of vipers gathered some.'
'She rubs some of her against some.'
Another said regarding that:
'As if the sound of her stream in the morning ... Is the rustling of wind or the hissing of a snake.'
Al-Hudhali said regarding the tracks of snakes on the road:
'As if the tracks of snakes in it ... Before the morning are traces of whips.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if their tracks are leather straps ... Dragged singly and some of them doubled.'
Ibn Abi Rabi'ah said:
'The anklet does not cease upon the mattresses ... Like the folds of a killed snake.'
Another said:
'Oh would that a viper, there is no one for whom ... It walked his path, escape.'
'Slipping like the swift sword ... With a head like the rock.'
'Or would that a black sloughing one ... Baffled all the charmers.'
'They charm him, so it is as if ... Other than him is meant by his charm.'
'Became the bedfellow of our companion ... So he relieved from him and his harm.'
Khalaf said:
'As if he is wearing a mat ... As if saffron was woven with tar.'
'His back is lined with silk.'
Another said:
'On him are black and yellow dots as if ... He is sprinkled a sprinkling with tar and saffron.'
Khalaf said:
'As if you drew it a drawing ... You see in the fold of his skin lines.'
'And his back is as you saw the striped cloths.'
Another said:
'As if his skin is a book ... Years and epochs did not wear it out.'
Ashja' said regarding a snake:
'And as if the gradation in its bellies ... Is the waves of the Tigris in the blowing of the North wind.'
Khalaf said regarding the spider (Rutayla'):
'Send to him, O Lord, one with legs ... In her mouth is a hook like the sickle.'
'Black like the transformed spider ... Taking him from below him and from above.'
Abd al-Samad said regarding the scorpion:
'O Lord of a lie whose deceptions are many ... He emerges like the two horns when you extract him.'
'In the like of the chest of the leather when you cut it ... Black like the jet, in him is his lancet.'
'Raising it at times and at times returning it ... Neckless, dangerous, his ugliness appears.'
'The speckled snake does not do what he does not do.'
Chapter (9) On the Flash of Lightning
From the beautiful simile in the flash of lightning is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'O companion, do you see a lightning I show you its flash ... Like the waving of two hands in a crowned cloud.'
Another said:
'I was sleepless for a lightning at the end of the night flashing ... Moving diligently therein, blowing and sleeping.'
'Moving like the sipping of birds while the night is striking ... With its curtains and the morning almost shines.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'I was sleepless for a lightning moving at midnight ... Hidden like your wink with the eyebrow.'
'As if its shining in the sky ... Is the hands of a writer or the hands of a calculator.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a cloud:
'I saw in it its lightning since it appeared ... Like the glance of the eye or a heart beating.'
'Then the east wind drove it until appeared ... In it, besides the lightning, like meteors.'
'You think it in it when cracked ... Its insides from it, a snake writhing.'
'And at times you think it as if it is ... A piebald horse whose covering tilted when he leaped.'
'Until when the day raised the forenoon ... You thought it chains of gold.'
'Ash-Shuja'' here is the snake, and it is taken from the saying of Di'bil in his saying:
'I was sleepless for a lightning at the end of the night pouring ... Hidden like the belly of the turning snake.'
Labid bin Rabi'ah said:
'You see the thunder in the imagination from it ... Like the growling of stallions among the she-camels.'
'And you see the lightning, a spreading cloud ... The frolic of piebald horses roaming in horse-cloths.'
Another said:
'As if it, when appearing shining ... Is an Indian sword shaking when unsheathed.'
'And the lightning at its edge does what ... The passion of the sad one does to the vitals.'
Al-Ta'i said describing a cloud:
'Driven by a lightning of burning flint ... As if it is the consciences of scabbards.'
Al-Alawi said regarding a cloud:
'And as if the flash of its lightnings ... In the air are swords of fencers.'
Di'bil said:
'I ceased not watching a lightning in its sides ... Like the blink of an eye, fading then snatched away.'
'A lightning whose flash dared from Khaffan ... Fulfills the need of my heart and departs.'
Antara said regarding its lingering and light:
'Lo, O one for this Yemeni lightning ... Shining as if it is the lamp of a builder.'
He likened it to the lamp of the builder for his family because it does not extinguish that night due to its long stay.
Another said:
'And until I thought the lightning was two fires kindled ... At the sandy ground of Saq, their kindler did not build.'
Al-Ta'i said:

'O Sahm, for the lightning that flew ... It returned, despite the darkness, day.'
'It became water for us and was fire ... It pleased the soil and angered the dust.'
The people of meanings recite regarding it:
'A fire renewing for the sticks their burning ... And the fire scorches sticks so they burn.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'So it watered them, even if its distance prolonged ... The succession of time, its night and its day.'
'Every generosity, when the lightning met in it ... Its fire was kindled for the eyes with water.'
Another said:
'The lightning appeared from towards Hijaz so it excited me ... And for every Hijazi the lightning is exciting.'
'It moved like the pulse of the vein while the night was before it ... And the mountains of Najd all of them and the deserts.'
Al-Ta'i said similar:
'To you a people traveled with praise as if they are ... On the saddles, snakes of the mountain paths, moving.'
'Watching lightnings of catching up as if they are ... When their first appeared, pulsing veins.'
'Al-Lisab': Roads in mountains, singular 'Lisb'. 'An-Nadanid': Snakes, singular 'Nadnad', which has movement that does not settle. 'Al-Mays': Wood of the saddle. He informed that they were tired from travel until they became in slenderness like snakes. Similar is his saying also:
'And riders like spearheads camped ... On the like of it while the night, its darknesses assault.'
'For a matter upon them is that its beginnings complete ... And not upon them is that its consequences complete.'
And he has regarding travelers who exhausted their mounts:
'They have eaten the humps from them by night travel ... And their figures became to them like humps.'
Chapter (10) On the Emaciation of Travelers
Connected to this regarding the emaciation of travelers, leanness of camels, and intensity of fatigue is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'And disheveled like the sword, his body has become lean ... And the carcasses of the Mahri camels and the distant worries.'
'Slumber gave him the cup of drowsiness to drink, so his head ... To the religion of slumber from the beginning of the night is prostrating.'
Another said:
'And a desert as if the night wrapped ... Its riders with the sons of Ham.'
'I waded in it to the Caliph at Al-Sharafah ... Two seas of noon and darkness.'
Al-Ta'i said describing travelers:
'Toil blackened their faces so as if they ... And their father is Shem, their father is Ham.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Then a preceding guide consulted them ... Rising to his goal with the eyes of a falcon.'
'His face wore pallor with the noons ... So he is like a mirror not polished.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'She visited disheveled ones like swords and she-camels ... Lean from the offspring of Al-Jadil and Da'ir.'
'They pulled the nose-rings until they leaned and turned ... The noses of the Mahri camels to a strength in the nostrils.'
In describing the she-camel he also says:
'A returner of travels, as if her rein ... Is a snake on the left of the forearms, head down.'
Another said:
'She disputes a doubled Hadrami (rope) as if it is ... A snake of a sand dune followed by a thrower moving away.'
He likened her rein to the snake. Al-Farazdaq said:
'When they were made to kneel, they faced from their backs ... Lean ones like crescents, emaciated.'
Thabit Qutna said regarding a she-camel:
'And as if the path of the straps on her side ... Are roads cutting deserts and hills.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a she-camel:
'She gazes with a look as if its orbit ... You said overlooked a high place not descended.'
'And as if the traces of straps on her side ... Are the night path of snakes in pouring sand.'
'And as if her place of falling when she camped ... Are traces of the place of falling of a prostrating devotee.'
'And her tail is blocked by a complete rope ... Like the branch of a palm tree whose leaves were not stripped.'
He also said:
'As if the mounts when they left early in the morning ... Left nests of sandgrouse in the kneeling places.'
Malik bin akhi Rafi' said:
'As if their eyes are rock pools ... Water descends from their tear ducts.'
Al-Attabi said:
'When the mounts, their eyes are sunken ... Just as flasks contained oil.'
Similar is the saying of another regarding a weary she-camel, who is Dhu al-Rumma:
'As if her eye is of her when she became lean ... And the travel joined it a joining in the Adamim.'
'Al-Ada': Ponds. 'Al-Mida'ah': What is used for ablution for prayer.
Another said:
'Oh, how lovely is the life of ease and lying ... Beside a shaker of the girth, wide-stepping.'
'Al-Wadin' for the camel is like the girth for the beast. 'As-Sa'um': Wide-stepping.
'Terrors threw her until as if ... She was carved from her sides with an adze.'
Ibn al-Khatim said similar to that:
'And she became lean until as if her girth ... Is the sash of a bride roaming from her on a waist.'
Dhu al-Rumma said regarding the weariness of a she-camel:

'Complaining of the nose ring and the place of the two straps as ... The sick person (complains) to his visitors of pain.'
'Al-Khashash' is like the nose ring. Similar is the saying of Al-Muthaqqib al-Abdi:
'When I stood to saddle her at night ... She moaned the moan of the sad man.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding her speed:
'And she bore with me the terror of every desert ... Crazy, in her is the boldness of a daring one.'
'She leaves the mounts behind her and as if she is ... A row she precedes and she is an Imam.'
All of them describe a she-camel with huge size and height, like the saying of Tarafa:
'Like the bridge of the Roman whose owner swore ... It would be raised until plastered with bricks.'
And like the saying of Antara:
'So I stopped my she-camel in it and as if she is ... A palace, to fulfill the need of the lingerer.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'We have camels filling the space as if they ... Carried the black hills above the withers.'
Ibn Abi Hafsa said:
'Following one ignorant of the rein as if she is ... One of the bridges while she is a lean camel.'
Al-Ra'i said describing her ribs:
'And as if there butted on her middle ... Mountain goats on a peak that completed and became old.'
Al-Farazdaq said regarding her speed:
'She strives with them through the middles of every desert ... As if the mounts protect themselves with her from embers.'
Al-Farazdaq said regarding a she-camel:
'Her hands expel the pebbles in every midday heat ... The expelling of dirhams by the critics of moneychangers.'
Similar is the saying of the other (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Their pads fly the pebbles ... Just as the moneychanger picked the dirham.'
Ru'ba said:
'As if their hands in the smooth plain ... Are hands of maids passing leaves.'
Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'To the Imam she guided us with our saddles ... A creation from the wind in the likeness of ostriches.'
'As if her escape while dawn takes her ... Is the escape of one returning from the bow of a crossbow.'
The Arabs liken her speed to the fleeing of ostriches. Layla al-Akhyaliyyah said:
'They aimed at her with light bodies so you do not see ... For her a likeness except the frightened ostrich.'
Tha'lab said: Bodies here mean bodies. He said: And in the saying of the Mighty and Majestic "And your clothing purify", he said: Your heart.
Another said:
'When she kneeled, she fell on her calluses ... Keeping a backbone away like the arch of the bridge.'
'As if her hands when her plaits run ... Are two chased ones and the legs are two seekers of revenge.'
Another said:
'Red from the offspring of Mahri camels, her offspring ... When her hand and leg throw each other.'
'As if she is a jealous woman whose mind was provoked ... She came to the one whom her husband feared.'
Al-Ghatammish al-Dabbi said:
'As if her hands when her salvation became serious ... Began swimming in a flood, reaching out.'
Similar is the saying of Bishamah bin al-Ghadir (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if her hands when she trotted ... And had been confused then found the way.'
'Are hands of a swimmer who choked in a flood ... So death overtook him except a little.'
Included in this chapter, even if it has no simile, is the saying of the poet:
'I say to a lean camel whose fat the journey removed ... So nothing remained of her except bone covered with skin.'
'Take me, may Allah afflict you with longing and passion ... And the cooing of the singing pigeon excite you.'
'So she walked joyfully fearing the call of a lover ... The darkness trots with me in every desert.'
'When she slowed in walking, I repeated my call ... So it was a whip for her until the morning of tomorrow.'
Al-Quda'i said:
'Sunken-eyed, swift ones, when the drivers urged them ... You thought their legs were in front of their hands.'
Muslim said:
'To you, O Trustee of Allah, the sandgrouse startled us ... Daughters of the wilderness in every soft ground and desert.'
'They took to night travel the taking of the violent one and hastened ... Her steps with her while the star is bewildered, guided.'
'They wore the darkness until the heads of the stars of the night ... Were stripped and descended like the throwing with the hand.'
Chapter (11) On the Mirage
Connected to this chapter in beautiful simile regarding the mirage is the saying of Muslim in this poem:
'And a hollow causing the foot of the traveler to slip, fearful ... As if on its sides is the edge of a file.'
'Girded with the mirage in it as if it is ... Men sitting in washed sheets.'
Another said:
'I scare with Al-Hajjaj until as if ... A broken bone in the heart is moved.'
'And short of the hand of Al-Hajjaj from reaching me ... Is a carpet for the hands of swift camels, wide.'
'Deserts resembling each other as if their mirage ... Is sheets in the hands of washers, washed.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And the mirage, the hills danced in it as ... Pregnant women fondled children with bouncing.'
'As if it is suits spread between the stones ... So they are between clothed and exposed.'

Ibn al-Rumi said describing she-camels traversing a land with him:
'They fold the deserts and as if the mirage is cloaks ... Wrapping, and as if the night is teak (sijan).'
Then he likened the night and the mirage to the sea, saying:
'As if they are ships in the shallows of the forenoon ... And whales in the depths of darkness.'
'Al-Saj': The black shawl. There is disagreement about likening the night to it; it was said for its blackness, and it was said it was likened to it because it has no sides.
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'The mirage, its waves leap with the stones ... The leaping of the Kudri sandgrouse in the traps.'
'And the shadow is coupled with every mount ... The walking of dark Mahri camels between mares.'
Similar is the saying of the other:
'And the sun shod her with a shadow as if it is ... A young ostrich her feathers made sway.'
Mas'ud, brother of Dhu al-Rumma, said:
'And a desert in which the mirage glimmers ... Its guide in a depression is thrown.'
'The people toil in it until they are exhausted ... Then they remain as if they did not leave.'
'As if they spent the evening where they spent the morning.'
Al-Ma'mun said (Munsarih Meter):
'She opens with the promise the door of her gift ... Until you see the connection then it closes.'
'A promise like the glimmer of the mirage you think ... Near you while beneath it is twilight.'
Another followed him and said:
'What is my trick for a beloved ... Whose promise is the glimmer of the mirage?'
'He promises connection but ... Beneath it is the touch of clouds.'
'I praise Allah for what ... Is with me, even if I am for what is with me.'
Abu Uthman al-Najim wrote to Ibn al-Rumi blaming him for asking for fish from Ibn Bishr al-Marthadi (Mutaqarib Meter):
'O Abu Hasan, you are one whose no ... descent we praise in examination its preponderance.'
'So why did you not think well of Al-Marthadi ... While Allah has decreased his kindness?'
'And the sea of mirage escapes the seeker ... So say regarding your seeking: its whales.'
Similes of moderns like Abu Nuwas, Bashar, Muslim, Al-Ta'i, Al-Buhturi, Ibn al-Rumi, Ibn al-Mu'tazz and their likes have recurred in our book because we relied on establishing the best selected similes and strange distant meanings, not the common worn-out ones. Although the ancients opened the speech and opened the door for the moderns and paved the way for them, so they had the virtue of precedence and initiating meanings and the difficulty of beginning, these (moderns) have improved contemplation, hit the mark in simile, generated meanings, added to what they transmitted, and were strange in what they innovated. If we established their ancient similes like likening the she-camel in bulkiness to the castle and bridge, in hardness to the anvil and rock, in speed to the boulder and tripod stone, and the speed of the horse to the escape of the gazelle, and likening the generous to the sea, the master to the horn (stallion of camels), the beautiful face to the moon and sun, women's litters to palm trees and ships, stars to lamps, and women to ostrich eggs, the book would have been long with that, and most of it would return to one meaning, and the narrated part of it would be known not strange, so the beauty of selection, refining words, and strangeness of meanings would disappear. Our quest is for the good wherever found, and we intended the fresh and rare for whomever it was. And through Allah is power and strength.
Chapter (12) On the Night Visit of Horses (Phantom)
From the beautiful simile in the night visit of horses is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'Are you serious? A phantom never ceases to travel to Zaynab ... If the darkness returns, he returns.'
'He traveled from the heights of Sham, brought by slumber ... The blowing of the garden breeze brought by the east wind.'
He also said:
'She visited us after the calm, so she permitted ... A connection which, when you seek it in seriousness, she prevents.'
'And she turned away as if separation pulls her figure ... At the time she turned away from my vitals and ribs.'
The origin of this meaning is for Qays bin al-Khatim, and from him Al-Buhturi and others took it, which is his saying:
'Indeed I traveled and I was not a traveler ... And dreams bring near the non-near.'
'And what she prevents awake, she may give ... In sleep, not restricted nor calculated.'
Based on that is the saying of Al-Mu'ammil:
'Slumber came to me at night with a person I love ... The horizons shone for him while the night was dark.'
'And he spoke to me in sleep not angry ... And my covenant with him awake is he does not speak.'
Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf mentioned the cause in the night visit of the phantom, saying:
'Your phantom when I sleep is before my eyes ... Until the time of my waking, it does not leave.'
'And it does not visit me as a connection, but ... The soul's talk about you is the means to it.'
Al-Ta'i followed him and said:
'Her phantom visited, nay, rather visited you ... A thought, if the thought of creation slept, did not sleep.'
'A gazelle I hunted when I set up for him ... At the end of the night traps of meat.'
He also said:
'The visitor visited you a night from Ram...lah between Al-Hima and Al-Matali.'

'Sleep, for the phantom did not visit you, but ... You, with thought, visited the specter of the phantom.'
Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said:
'I did not attain him, so I attained him by wishes ... In my sleep, secretly from abandonment.'
'The dream connected between us after abandonment ... And we met while we were separated.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'I see myself never ceasing every night ... Al-Malikiyyah returns to my bed in it.'
'I rejoice at the nearness of a visiting conversationalist ... And I grieve at the separation of a departing beloved.'
