'So how much for us after distance of separation ... Dreams of slumber drive and gather.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'My thought asked him to visit in sleep ... So he came to it in secrecy and concealment.'
'Nights are more generous to my heart when ... Distance wounded it than days.'
'O what a night in which souls visited each other ... Secretly from bodies.'
'A gathering in which we had no fault ... Except that we were in the invitation of dreams.'
From the beautiful simile in this meaning is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'A beloved came in secrecy and in fear ... Traversing the darkness until we met by decree.'
'I doubted him out of joy and thought him ... An imagination coming in sleep from his specter traveling.'
He also said:
'A thought of her occurred in sleep ... The thought of lightning started then vanished.'
'What a visitor for you if he traveled intentionally ... And a guest with you if he did it truly.'
'He appears while slumber is in my eye ... So when sleep leaves it, he becomes invalid.'
Ali bin Yahya said similar to that (Madid Meter):
'By my father, by Allah, is the one who knocked ... Like the smiling of lightning when it flashed.'
'The specter of the beloved visited me, so it ... Did not increase except inciting sleeplessness in me.'
Similar is the saying of Ahmad bin Yusuf:
'In the path of Allah is a beautiful love ... That lasted from my heart for a beautiful face.'
'And a passion I wasted on a resident ... My share from him is nothing but sadness.'
'He sleeps at night and finds it sweet ... While if I found the goodness of slumber sweet.'
'A phantom from him visited me having no ... Need except to wake me up.'
Al-Buhturi said, and he is one of the excellent ones in mentioning the night visit of the phantom:
'And I see your phantom does not cease with slumber ... Appearing, I meet him or he meets me.'
'He brings close to me of connection the like of what ... He shows me always of abandonment.'
He also has:
'And a night we nodded off on the white camels, she sent ... A specter of imagination whose false resembles the truth.'
'Were it not for the whiteness of morning, my clinging would have been long ... To the sides of a gazelle I spent the night flirting with.'
Al-Tammar said:
'If your specter visited me, O my master ... I would say: No, by Allah, we will not separate.'
He inverted this meaning and said:
'Your specter comforted me until when ... He intended to leave, I clung to him.'
Al-Buhturi said (Munsarih Meter):
'And a visitor who visited one whom he effaced ... Mixing weight with his intimacy his fear.'
'As if he came fulfilling a promise ... And I spent the night among the watchers looking at him.'
'I did not forget him being quick in haste ... Merging in speech, shortening it.'
'As if the haters had attended ... His place or his news came to them.'
Chapter (13) On Weeping
From the good simile in weeping is the saying of the poet:
'I looked as if I was from behind a glass ... To the house, from the water of longing I look.'
'So my eyes at times drown from weeping ... So I become blind, and at times they recede so I see.'
'Neither does my eye clear from the overwhelming water ... Nor does my tear drop from the intensity of passion.'
'And it is not water that flows from the eye ... But rather my soul melts and drips.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'We stood and eyes were heavy ... A weary look fights their tears.'
'The watching of slanderers forbade it until ... It hung, neither sinking nor flowing.'
Another said:
'Tears overcame my eye, so my pupil ... Is a drowned one appearing repeatedly and hiding.'
'So as if I see you from behind a curtain ... The wind shook its surface so it folded.'
Another said:
'Perhaps eyelids that time separated between them ... Will reunite or be sweetened with the taste of sleep.'
'And a tear is revealed, never ceasing as if it is ... On the cheek, a pouring water pushing a valley.'
'As if the night clouds and morning clouds took upon themselves ... For him with night tears and morning tears.'
Ibn Harmah said:
'As if my eyes when their loads turned away ... From me were wings of a pigeon that encountered rain.'
'Or loose pearls in the necklace of a maid ... Clumsy, the children struggled with her so they scattered.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'What is the matter with your eye, water pours from it ... As if it is from worn-out water skins, a leak?'
Similar is his saying:

'And the two waterskins of Kharqa, weak of kidneys ... A water-carrier poured into them and they did not get wet.'
'Are more wasting of water than your eyes whenever ... You discerned a lightning or imagined a dwelling.'
Imru' al-Qays said:
'Your eyes, their tears are pouring ... As if their ducts are dripping water.'
'Or a stream ... In the shadows of palm trees ... The water has a course beneath it.'
Jarran al-Awd said:
'It became as if the eye is branches of a lote tree ... Upon which is frost from the night's dew dripping.'
Another said:
'An evening of farewell, how ugly of an evening ... But she was not ugly as a bidder of farewell.'
'As if the descent of tears from her, counting it ... To us is a female counter, counting little and hurrying.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'Stop the white camels at the ruins of Mayya and ask ... Traces like the rags of the patterned cloak.'
'I think what her asking grants you is ... Tears like the scattering of the detailed pearls.'
Such simile is very common and worn out, and the condition in selection is more controlling.
Al-Ta'i said:
'I scattered unique tears not strung ... And the tear carries some of the weight of the debt.'
'She connected a conversation with tears, so her cheek ... Is in the likeness of the border of the marked cloak.'
Similar is the saying of the other:
'So oh for the sorrows if the forenoon shines ... And in my liver from their heat is a fire.'
'We mixed blood with tears until as if ... Pearls and carnelian are melted in my eye.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'She went seeking refuge for the tear fearing separation of tomorrow ... And every sleeping place returned as thorns to her.'
'So pity shed for her a rose-colored tear ... From the eyelid running over a rose-colored cheek.'
Ibn Yusuf excelled in his saying:
'Separation was sweet to us shortly before our farewell ... Then we gulped it like a soaking poison.'
'And as if the trace of tears on her cheek ... Is dew of frost on a ripe rose.'
Another said regarding the same:
'As if the falling of tears on the heat of her face ... Is the falling of dew overlooking the leaf of the rose.'
Ibn al-Rumi added to this and said (Munsarih Meter):
'The day of separation of the beloved is not with distance ... Nor is my heart capable of endurance over it.'
'If you were a witness to us on the day of farewell ... While they were extinguishing the thirst of passion.'
'You would not see but tears of a weeping woman ... Shedding from an eye onto a cheek.'
'As if those tears are drops of dew ... Dripping from a narcissus onto a rose.'
Al-Nashi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'She wept for separation and I was terrified by ... The weeping of the beloved for the distance of the abodes.'
'As if the tears on her cheek ... Are the remains of dew on pomegranate blossoms.'
Al-Buhturi said in the reverse of that:
'Anemones carrying dew so it is as if ... It is tears of youthfulness on the cheeks of virgins.'
Abu Nuwas said, which enters this chapter even if it has no simile:
'One of their women says on the morning of separation ... My liver is hot, so go and patience is yours.'
'And a tear overcame her, so her tears ... On her cheek are red and on her chest are yellow.'
He says the color of her cheek is red so the tear took its form when it fell on it and became red, and the color of her chest is ivory yellow so the color of the tear reaching it became yellow.
It was said to Al-Abbas bin Muhammad: What is the color of water? He said: The color of its vessel.
The Arabs describe the pearly color, like the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'Black-eyed in whiteness, yellow in brightness ... As if she is silver touched by gold.'
'Al-Burj': Wideness of the eye. 'Al-Na'j': Intensity of whiteness.
Al-Muraqqish said:
'The scent is musk and the faces are Dinars ... And the fingertips are Anam (red tree).'
It was said to a Bedouin woman: How is the color of your daughter? She said: Better than the kindled fire.
Bashar said:
'And you imagine what her clothes gathered upon gold and gold dust.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'A gazelle, as if Allah clothed him ... With shells of pearls as skin.'
'And you see on his cheeks ... At whatever time you wish, a rose.'
This is very abundant. From good metaphor in tears is the saying of Al-Ta'i:
'Rain of tears watered the land of his cheek ... Until the morning, and his eyes were its sky.'
'His loved ones did to the core of his heart ... What his enemies do not do to him.'
Similar is the saying of Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir:
'And when I saw separation had become serious ... And stagnation was due from obtaining separation.'
'We sat and rained tears, their sky ... Eyelids of eyes and the lands were cheeks.'
The narrators consider good the saying of Ibn al-Ahnaf (Mutaqarib Meter):
'She wept, not accustomed to weeping ... You see the tear in her eyes as a stranger.'
Bashar said: The boy of Banu Hanifa, meaning Abbas bin al-Ahnaf, kept entering himself among us and we expelled him until he said:
'Weeping exhausted the tears of your eye, so borrow ... An eye belonging to another whose tear is flowing.'

'Who will lend you his eye to weep with? ... Have you seen an eye lent for weeping?'
Di'bil bin Ali said:
'O quarter, where did Salma head? ... Did she pass? For the soul of his self is more passing.'
'I do not seek the watering of clouds for it ... In my eye is a substitute for watering.'
Al-Abbas said, and likened with the best simile, also narrated for Abu Nuwas:
'May Allah not reward the tear of my eye with good ... And may Allah reward my tongue with all good.'
'My tear tattled, so it conceals nothing ... And I found the tongue possessing concealment.'
'I was like the book whose folding hid it ... So they inferred it by the title.'
Chapter 14 On the Sickness of the Eye and Its Coquetry
From the beautiful simile regarding the sickness of the eye and its coquetry is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'Weak of returning the glance, you think she is ... Recently recovered from illness.'
He said:
'O gazelle who made the body ... Like his eyes, sick.'
'There settled in my body what was ... In your eyes, residing.'
It was said the most flirtatious verse the Arabs said is the saying of Jarir:
'Indeed the eyes which in their glance is sickness ... Killed us then did not revive our dead.'
'They throw down the person of intellect until there is no movement in him ... And they are the weakest of Allah's creation in pillars (limbs).'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Weak are his eyelids ... And the heart of him is stone.'
'As if his glances ... Are apologizing for his heart.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'And as if in my body is that which ... Is in your eyes of sickness.'
He also said:
'I find the fire borrowed from the fire ... And from the sickness of an eye, my sickness originates.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And she wounds my vitals with a sick eye ... Just as the flat of the sword is soft while the edge is cutting.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'White women turning their eyes to youth ... As if they are turning cups with them.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'And the cup did not intoxicate me until its circulator ... Aided it against me with his eyes in the morning.'
Mani said:
'And as if the powers of his eyelids were worn out ... By wine or mixed with drowsiness.'
Al-Buhturi said (Hazaj Meter):
'And in the coffee are shapes ... From the cupbearer and colors.'
'Bubbles like what he laughs ... About while he is joyful.'
'And intoxication like what an eyelid ... Of his, drowsy, intoxicated.'
'And the taste of saliva when he was generous ... With it while the lover is madly in love.'
'We have from his hand wine ... And from his scent basil.'
Another said similar to this:
'She is wine in beauty, and her saliva is like wine ... And the delicacy of that color is in the delicacy of wine.'
'For three wines have gathered in it ... And in one is intoxication exceeding intoxication.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'The morning she turned for farewell and greeted ... With the two eyes of a joined one whose eyelids are magic.'
'I imagined her eyelids twisted by slumber ... Slumber of sleep, or wine swayed her sides.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And two eyes, Allah said "Be" so they were ... Doers to minds what wine does.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'You think him intoxicated if he gazes ... Due to the languor of his eyelids while he is sober.'
They likened the eye to the narcissus. Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And the best of what is in faces are eyes ... And the most similar thing to them is the narcissus.'
He also said (Munsarih Meter):
'As if those tears are drops of dew ... Falling from a narcissus onto a rose.'
One of the wits said:
'A fawn, his cheek and eyes ... Are my rose and my narcissus.'
'If he is generous to me with wine of his mouth ... Then a session is complete.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Drowsy, slumber deceived his eyelids ... So he imitated with his eye the wilting of the narcissus.'
They liken the eye in its coloring to the gazelle's eye. This is an old simile, like the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'The gazelle reminds me of Mayya by its eye ... Repeatedly, and her mouth the blossoming chamomile.'
Ibn al-Riqa' al-Amili said:
'And as if she, amidst the women, lent her ... His eyes, a gazelle of Jasim with intense white and black eyes.'
'Drowsy, slumber aimed at him so hovered ... In his eye a sleepiness while he is not sleeping.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'If a white-black gazelle turned away ... To us, I said this is Mayya's eye and her neck.'
They only liken the neck to the gazelle's neck in its length and beautiful erection, as Abu Tammam al-Ta'i said (Munsarih Meter):
'Like the bough in stature, and the gazelle (sun) in joy ... And the fawn of the gazelle in his neck.'
'And he did not imitate him, and he has no softness ... In his neck, rather he imitated him in his neck.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'One-eyed of the pupil without intense blackness ... Were it not for being one-eyed, he would be ugly.'
'You think the dot in his eye ... Is a white pearl in a setting of jet.'

Ibn al-Mu'adhdhal said (Madid Meter):
'I desire in the eye the kiss ... Not much that resembles squint.'
'And the redness of the cheek from shame ... Indeed I find shame beautiful.'
Chapter 15 On the Face and Its Light
From the old similes regarding the face and its light is the saying of Tarafa:
'And a face, as if the sun removed its cloak ... Upon it, pure of color, not wrinkled.'
'Hallat': Spread. 'Ahallahu': From 'Al-Hall' opposite of knotting. Ibn al-Rumi said:
'As if she sang to the sun of the forenoon ... So it clothed her its beauty as a robe.'
Zuhair said regarding Harim:
'If you were of anything other than humans ... You would be the illuminator on the night of the full moon.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'The wish was to meet her, so I met her ... So I played the play of a lied-to man.'
'So I saw like the sun at its rising ... In beauty, or like its nearing setting.'
i.e., in two times when looking at the sun is possible. Al-Nimr bin Tawlab said:
'So she turned away as if the sun under her mask ... An eyebrow of it appeared and she was stingy with an eyebrow.'
He meant she turned her face away in anger. Abu Nuwas said similar:
'O moon at the half of its month ... Showed a light for eight remaining.'
Bashar said regarding a woman who turned away:
'She was stingy with a cheek and revealed a cheek ... Then turned away like the apostate soul.'
Among the best said in praising turning away is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'His turning away did not harm me ... From me, but pleased me.'
'His sideburns are a substitute ... For every beautiful thing.'
'I did not say that he was undutiful to me ... By turning away, but he was dutiful to me.'
'He exchanged me for beauty ... A beauty, so what harmed me?'
Abu Nuwas said:
'The sun and the illuminating moon boast ... If we say they are like the Emir.'
'So if they resembled him a little ... A great resemblance missed them.'
'Because the sun sets when it becomes evening ... And that the full moon is decreased by the journey.'
'And the light of Muhammad is always complete ... On the clarity of the path, it does not recede.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said:
'O full moon, what have you done to the full moon ... Did you expose him from where time does not know?'
'You are capturing his moon ... And for that is his night of the month.'
Another said:
'If I blame her, I liken her to the full moon rising ... And suffice you as a fault for her the resemblance of the full moon.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said mentioning women:
'And they said to us: We are crescents, we only ... Light for the one who travels by night and we do not host.'
'There is no giving except what a looker takes as provision ... Nor connection except with the phantom that travels by night.'
Abu Uthman al-Najim said similar to that:
'I demanded of the one who chased my sleep and terrified ... And kohled the eye with the applicator of sleeplessness.'
'For a kiss that improves the trace in the heart ... So he said to me rushing: And what are you waiting for?'
'The eye has no share in the moon except the eye.'
Ibn al-Musayyib al-Katib said:
'And one with cheeks starting to grow hair I saw him ... Shaking like the moist branch.'
'He resembled with the growth of hair what ... Is in the full moon of those scars.'
'By Allah, what the eyes of ... His onlookers gifted to hearts.'
'From a possessed of coquetry, soft ... Whatever you wish of beauty and goodness.'
'The eyes of men plundered him ... So there was not a scant share.'
'But I was pushed to enjoyment ... When he hastened to set.'
'And he is like the moon of darkness ... When it inclined to setting.'
'I likened him to the full moon in the two ... States, the simile of the correct one.'
'Wonder at that if the winking ... Obeyed with the suspicious glance.'
'So I won the illuminating moon ... On a branch in a sand dune.'
'And I ascended a pulpit with shaking ... Like the quivering of the preacher.'
'And I added that to a snorting ... Like the tearing of pockets.'
'That was possible ... But I was pushed to distresses.'
Included in this category of women's descriptions is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'Her face lights up the bed for her bedfellow ... Like the lamp of oil in the wicks of lamps.'
'As if on her upper chest is the ember of a warmer ... Who found Ghadha wood thick and covered it with stumps.'
The light of oil is brighter than others and less smoky. Regarding that is the saying of Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di regarding a woman (Mutaqarib Meter):
'The fire illuminated for us a face bright ... Mixing with the heart a mixing.'
'It lights up like the lamp of oil (Salit) ... Allah made no copper (smoke) in it.'
The slave of Banu al-Has-has said:
'As if the Pleiades were hung above her chest ... And ember of Ghadha whose wind blew glowing.'
'If she pushed forth in a single sheet and a black garment ... And wrapped the top of the head with a Yemeni cloak.'
'She showed you on the morning of separation a palm and a wrist ... And a face like the Dinar of Al-Agharra, pure.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'And a neck like the neck of the gazelle, pure, adorned by ... The glowing of ruby and the separation of chrysolite.'
'As if the Pleiades above the pit of her throat ... Glow in the darkness what a glowing.'
Similar to that is much in their speech, and this sample suffices.
Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said regarding women:
'And they tore the fold of night from ... White necks and cheeks.'
'So as if the curtains of night laughed ... From the eggs of ostriches.'
Imru' al-Qays said:
'When she bathed, the excess of her water was ... On her back muscles like pearls with the gatherer.'
Another said similar (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if the water on her back ... When she scooped it with her cups.'
'Is pearls rolling on silver ... Which the irons of her treaders polished.'
Another said:
'The bath stripped him of silver ... Revealed from him soft folds.'
'As if the water on his body ... Is ants on a fresh lily.'
Al-Nabigha said:
'The headcover fell and she did not intend to drop it ... So she picked it up and shielded us with the hand.'
'With a dyed, soft one, as if its fingertips ... Are 'Anam' (red plant) on its branches not knotted.'
'She looked at you with a need she did not fulfill ... The look of the sick to the faces of the visitors.'
'Al-Humam claimed that her mouth is cold ... Sweet, if you kissed it you said: Increase.'
'And if you stabbed, you stabbed in a raised target ... Swollen of touch, plastered with ambergris.'
'And if you pulled, you pulled from a tight one ... The pulling of the strong man with the firm rope.'
In this meaning is what was mentioned in the poem which was not woven on its pattern, famous as being an orphan (unique), and it was said it is by Zawba'ah al-Malha, the beginning of which is:
'Is there for a questioner a reply regarding the length ... Or does she have a covenant with speaking?'
Until he said:
'And she has a raised organ, its touch ... Narrow are its paths, in it is heat.'
'And if you stabbed, you stabbed in felt ... And if you pulled, it almost clogs.'
Ibn al-Rumi took this meaning and said describing Al-Hashimi's slave girl with good saliva and tight private part (Munsarih Meter):
'I described her mouth which I loved despite ... Not testing nor tasting.'
'Except by your news which fell ... From you to us about the gazelle of Al-Barq.'
'That blackness smiles revealing whiteness ... Of her mouth like restless pearls.'
'As if she, while joking makes her laugh ... Is a night whose darkness was torn by dawn.'
'She has a private part borrowing its heat ... From the heart of a lover and the chest of an angry one.'
'As if its heat to its tester ... Is what ignited in his insides of burning.'
'It increases in tightness upon practice as ... The knot of the lasso increases in tightness.'
He also said:
'O likeness of the full moon in beauty ... And in distance of example, become generous.'
'For the rock might burst ... With fresh water.'
In this meaning due to what Al-Rumi has from the beginning of a poem:
'He hunted hearts with an eye and light ... And captivated minds with panic and light.'
'And he came with his blue garment sash-wrapped ... As if he is a full moon appeared in a sky.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a boy wearing Jarmi brocade and violet:
'The garment is the killing of his lover from his disease ... Now you became the full moon since ... You wore the color of his sky.'
Abu Uthman al-Najim said in this meaning:
'Qatul did not transgress if she got used to an ... Attire similar to her face possessing splendor.'
'She wore blue so she came with a face ... Resembling the full moon in the skin of the sky.'
Jarir said:
'People did not seek description of a thing that pleases them ... But they saw Umm Nuh above what they described.'
And he said:
'As if she is a bright white cloud appearing ... Or a pearl whose color the shell does not hide.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding women:
'The full moon humbled itself when they wore luxury ... So they were pearls and the pearl was shells.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding women:
'If they took off the sheer sheets at times ... They peeled shells off the pearls of Bahrain.'
Chapter 16 On the Walk of Women
From the beautiful simile in the walk of women is the saying of the poet:
'I likened her walk to the walk of a victor ... Strutting between spearheads and swords.'
'Arrogant, his soul reached its limit in itself ... When he turned back with his bloody spearhead.'
Al-Asha said:
'As if her walk from her neighbor's house ... Is the passing of the cloud, neither slow nor hasty.'
'Bright, wide-mouthed, polished of side-teeth ... Walking slowly as the barefoot fearful one walks.'
Ibn Muqbil said:

It showed you on the morning of parting a hand and a wrist... and a face like a dinar of the elite, pure. And Qays bin al-Khatim said: And a neck like the neck of a gazelle, pure, adorned by... the glowing of ruby and intervals of chrysolite. As if the Pleiades were above the pit of her throat... glowing in the darkness, oh what a glow! And there is much like that in their speech, and this sample of it suffices. Abdul-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said regarding women: They tore the fold of the night away from... white necks and cheeks; As if the curtains of night laughed revealing... the white eggs [of ostriches]. Imru' al-Qays said: When she bathed, the excess warm water... on her back was like pearls on the harvester. Another said in the Mutaqarib meter: As if the warm water upon her back... when she scoops it with her vessel, is pearls; Rolling upon silver... polished by the irons of its trampler. Another said: The bath stripped her of silver... revealing plump creases of skin; As if the water upon her body... were ants upon a fresh lily. Al-Nabigha said: The veil fell, and she did not intend to drop it... so she picked it up and shielded herself from us with her hand; With a tender, dyed [hand], as if its fingertips were... 'anam' [red fruit] on its branches, not yet knotted. She looked at you with a need she did not fulfill... the look of the sick toward the faces of visitors. The King claimed that her mouth is cold... sweet, if you kissed it, you would say 'give me more'. And if you thrust, you thrust into a target... with a raised touch, plastered with perfume. And if you pull out, you pull out from something tight... the pulling of the strong boatman on a firm rope. In this meaning is what was mentioned in the famous poem—which has no equal woven on its loom—called the 'Orphan', said to be by Zawba'ah al-Mulha, which begins: 'Is there a reply for the asker at the ruins... or is there any covenant for her to speak?' Until he said: 'And she has a raised mound, its touch is... tight in its passages, containing heat; And if you thrust, you thrust into felt... and if you pull out, it almost closes up.' Ibn al-Rumi took this meaning and said, describing the slave girl of Al-Hashimi, regarding the sweetness of saliva and the tightness of the private part (Al-Munsarih meter): I described the mouth that I desired despite... opposition, though it was not tested or tasted; Except by your news that fell... from you to us regarding the gazelle of lightning. That blackness smiles revealing whiteness... from her teeth like shimmering pearls. As if she, when joking makes her laugh... is a night whose darkness is torn by dawn. She has a 'heat' [private part] that borrows its intensity... from the heart of a lover and the chest of one filled with rage; As if its heat, to the one who experiences it... is what burning passion has kindled in his entrails. It increases in tightness during the struggle just as... the knot of a lasso increases in tightness. He also said: O you who resembles the full moon in beauty... and in the distance of the likeness, be generous; For indeed, the rock may burst forth... with fresh water. And in this meaning, due to what Ibn al-Rumi has in the beginning of a poem: 'He hunted hearts with an eye and a light... and captivated minds with fear and brilliance; And he came wearing a blue garment... as if he were a full moon appearing in the sky.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a boy wearing Crimons silk and a violet garment: The killing of his lover is part of his illness; Now you have become the full moon since... you dressed in the color of its sky. Abu Uthman al-Najim said in this meaning: The killing glances did not transgress when they found a costume... resembling her face possessing splendor; She wore blue, so she came with a face... resembling the full moon in the skin of the sky. Jarir said: The people never sought the description of something that pleased them... except that they saw the mother of Nuh as greater than what they described. He said: As if she is a bright, shining rain cloud... or a pearl whose color the shell does not hide. Ibn al-Rumi said regarding women: The full moon humbled itself when they donned fine garments... for they were pearls, and the pearls were shells. Al-Buhturi said regarding women: When they took off the sheer robes at times... they peeled off the shells from the pearls of Bahrain [their bodies]. Chapter 16: On the Walking of Women. Among the beautiful similes regarding the walking of women is the saying of the poet: I compared her walk to the walk of a victor... strutting between spearheads and swords; Arrogant, his soul consumed with itself... when he turned with his blood-stained spear. Al-A'sha said: As if her walk from the house of her neighbor... is the passing of a cloud, neither slow nor hasty; A distinct, white woman, her side-teeth polished... she walks slowly/gently just as the barefoot, fearful one walks. Ibn Muqbil said...

'They shake soft limbs for walking ... As the South wind shakes the branches of castor-oil plants (Yabrina) together.'
'Or like the shaking of a Rudayni spear handled ... By the hands of merchants so they increased its blade in softness.'
'They walk the pouring of the sand dune whose sides inclined ... It pours at times and the moist earth forbids it at times.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I decreed that from my saying to a moon ... Playing with kohl at times and dye.'
'She came pushing in a brocade she has, beautiful ... The pushing of water in a brocade of bubbles.'
Similar is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'I rose to her after her family slept ... The rising of water bubbles, state upon state.'
Al-Tirimmah said praising:
'He rose to the heights from both its sides ... The rising of water bubbles whose crests boiled.'
Ibn Abi Rabi'ah said:
'And the voice was lowered from me, I approached the walk ... Of the bubbles, and my corner fearing the people was slanted.'
Another said:
'What is the matter with you, you do not mention or visit ... A white woman between whose eyebrows is light.'
'She walks as the stream flows.'
Ashja' said:
'And she waved like the wave of water between her clothes ... A half inclines with it and a half straightens it.'
'If her thin clothes described what is above the path of her sash ... The waist-wrappers rejected her testimony.'
Another said (Munsarih Meter):
'She walks slowly when she walks, excellently ... The walk of the drained drunkard on an ascent.'
'She remains from visiting her neighbor's house ... Placing her palm on the liver.'
Al-Munakhkhal al-Yashkuri said:
'And I entered upon the young woman ... The curtain on the rainy day.'
'I pushed her so she pushed ... The walk of the sandgrouse to the stream.'
'And I kissed her so she breathed ... Like the breathing of the inexperienced gazelle.'
Al-Harith bin Hillizah said:
'She went out daring among three like statues ... The walk of ewes in blooming chamomile.'
'Like the palm branch shaken by strong winds ... And its clusters shook after its fruit.'
Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah said (Munsarih Meter):
'I saw her one night and her women ... Walking between the Maqam and the Stone.'
'Strutting in sheets and cloaks as ... The young cows walk slowly.'
Ibn al-Ahnaf said:
'A sun determined in the creation of a maid ... As if her flank is the folding of scrolls.'
'As if she, when she walks among her maids ... Steps on eggs or green flasks.'
Chapter 17 On Hair
From the beautiful simile in hair is the saying of Bakr bin al-Nattah:
'White, dragging her hair from a standing position ... And disappearing in it while it is thick black.'
'So as if she is a bright day in it ... And as if it is a dark night upon her.'
He said (Munsarih Meter):
'And coal-black flowing, accepting its path ... When he strutted letting down his braids.'
'He approached like the night from his partings ... Descending, his descent is not blamed.'
'Until he reached his places ... Kissing from every footstep its dust.'
'As if he is a lover approached out of passion ... Until he fulfilled his desire from his beloved.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And she lowers on the two loins abundant hair as if it were ... Bunches dropped by Shanu'ah or Qasr.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'If she put down the Jilbabs and wore ... Of the hair, Mayya, she can hardly shape it.'
Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'Are you serious? You do not know that many a night ... As if its darkness spreads from your locks.'
'I set up for it until it cleared with a blaze ... Like the blaze of Yahya when Ja'far is mentioned.'
Another said, who is Ibn al-Mu'tazz (Mujtath Meter):
'A full moon, a night, and a branch ... A face, hair, and a figure.'
'Wine, pearls, and a rose ... Saliva, a mouth, and a cheek.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'She gave me drink in a night resembling her hair ... Resembling her cheeks without a watcher.'
'So I became in two nights of hair and darkness ... And two suns of wine and a beloved's face.'
Chapter 18 On Saliva and the Mouth
From the beautiful simile in saliva and the mouth is the saying of Imru' al-Qays (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if wine and the pouring of clouds ... And the scent of lavender and the spread of rain.'
'Are given as a second drink by the coldness of her canine teeth ... When the early bird sings.'
He only meant the time of early morning because mouths change at night due to their closing and shutting. Regarding that is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'And no human bane afflicts her ... From sleep except that she becomes cold.'
'Likewise the breaths of gardens in the morning ... Are pleasant, and the breaths of people change.'
Similar is the saying of Ubayd, and narrated for Aws bin Hajar:
'As if her saliva after slumber was given as a morning drink ... From water of a dark wine in the shop, oozing.'

'Or from a diluted one like musk, its scent ... Or from tubes of pomegranate and apple.'
Similar is the saying of Zuhair:
'As if her saliva after slumber was given as a morning drink ... From the goodness of wine not yet aged.'
Such is very abundant.
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Lo, perhaps I equaled the jealous one and he harmed me ... And we both spent the night with grudge against his brother.'
'And I kissed sweet mouths as if they were ... Springs of wine whose pebbles are pearls of the sea.'
He also said:
'She chews a saliva whose cold drives away sleep ... And heals the hovering thirsty hearts.'
'And is there a pool whose pebbles are like her mouth ... Found except good of taste, pure?'
He also said:
'O many a saliva the full moon of darkness spent the night ... Ejecting between your teeth, quenching.'
'And he does not forbid you from drinking it ... While water quenches you and forbids you.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'By my father is a beloved I used to know ... Connecting with me, but his side turned away.'
'Fragrant of speech with a musk scent that wafted ... From his mouth, pleasing the one who blames him.'
Simile of the Mouth (Thaghr)
Al-Buhturi gathered all that the mouth is likened to in one verse, saying:
'As if she laughs revealing pearls ... Or silver or hail or chamomile.'
Al-Samhari said regarding the beauty of the mouth:
'And a white, lazy, playful virgin ... Delicious at the full night is her smelling.'
'As if the flash of lightning is between me and her ... When her smiling appeared from some of the houses.'
Al-Nabigha said:
'She reveals with the two primaries of a thicket pigeon ... Coldness (teeth) whose gums were sprinkled with antimony.'
'Like the chamomile on the morning after its sky (rain) ... Its tops dried and its bottom is moist.'
It is desirable for the color of the gum to incline to blackness.
Jarir said:
'She runs the Siwak on a bright [mouth] as if it is ... Hail descending from the backs of clouds.'
Jarir said:
'And possessing Shanab (lustrous teeth), pure, the soul knows that it ... Even if not tasted, thin of gums, is sweet.'
'Al-Shanab': Thinness/Luster of teeth. 'Al-Hamash': Lean. Thus the gum is described with leanness.
Another said similar:
'As if upon her canine teeth is wine mixed ... With dew water at the end of the night, a morning drink.'
'And I did not taste it except with my eye discerning ... Just as lightning was watched in the highest cloud.'
Similar is the saying of Umarah:
'As if on her canine teeth is the arousal of slumber ... A pool of icy water shining in a hollow.'
'An eye contemplates, not resting if it sees ... And a heart, and what informs you is more poetic (aware) than a heart.'
Shaqiq bin Sulayk said:
'And she smiles revealing dark-gummed, spaced teeth ... Created of the incisors with sweetness and coldness.'
Bashar said:
'O best of people in saliva, untested ... Except the testimony of the tips of Siwaks.'
Its completion is what follows:
'You visited us once in time, a single time ... A second, and do not make it the egg of the rooster.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And I did not taste it except by watching her smiling ... And how many a sight informs you of a good report.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding such thought:
'She gives you her logic so you know that it ... With the harvest of its sweetness passes by her mouth.'
Al-Atawi said:
'Possessor of two soft cheeks stingy with what is in them of apples ... And incisors and saliva and a stream.'
'Of wine and a garden of chamomile.'
Another said:
'And she smiles revealing two strings of pearls, their spacers are ... Mixtures of ruby approached by wine.'
Chapter 19 On the Speech of Women
From the beautiful simile in the speech of women is the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'A speech like the taste of honey, sweet are its beginnings ... And its ends are the colocynth short of the prohibitions.'
Al-Akhtal said:
'And I may converse with Layla while she is playful ... The falling of ornaments, my needs and my secrets.'
Abu Dahbal al-Jumahi said:
'And you see a coquetry in her, if she spoke ... She left the daughters of his heart inclined.'
'Like the falling of the fresh dates from the ... Branches, neither scattering nor plucking.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn Ahmad:
'She places the speech in its places ... And her speech afterwards possesses strength.'
Al-Shammakh said:
'A white woman, the neighbors do not dislike her appearance ... Nor is the sword of the Qayl (king) unsheathed by her mouth.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And we obtained scraps of a speech as if it is ... The harvest of bees mixed with the water of pools.'
Tha'lab recited to us for Abu al-Amaythal:
'I met the daughter of Al-Sahmi, Zaynab, at 'Afir ... While we were in Ihram on the evening of the tenth of the ten.'
'So she spoke two words to me, like snow was one of them ... And another on a tablet hotter than embers.'
One was the meeting and the other the farewell.
Another said, who is Al-Shammakh:
'And the nearness of separation hurried us, and between us ... Was a speech like the breathing of two sick people, disturbing.'

'A speech, if meat were roasted by its heat ... Raw, it would come to his companions cooked.'
Similar is the saying of the other:
'She says to me while lightening the howdah ... A beautiful, good, smooth saying.'
'If meat were cooked by it, it would be cooked.'
Ibn Abi Rabi'ah said:
'And indeed there runs between us when we meet ... A speech having embroidery like the embroidery of cloaks.'
'A speech like the falling of rain on the drought, heals ... With it from passion inside the heart, kind.'
Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
'And her speech is like the rain heard by ... A shepherd of years that followed in drought.'
'So he listened hoping it to be a rain ... And says out of joy: O Lord.'
Al-Qatami said:
'So they cast a saying with which they hit ... The locations of water from the thirsty possessor of thirst.'
Bashar said:
'And as if the return of her speech ... Is pieces of gardens clothed in flowers.'
'And as if under her tongue ... Is Harut blowing magic into it.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'Her words almost, from recognizing distance ... Out of the delicacy of complaint, became tears.'
Chapter 20 On the Heaviness of the Buttocks

Similar is the saying of the other:

'She enters today, then enter ... Her buttocks tomorrow.'
From the beautiful simile in that is the saying of Abu Nukhayla:
'As if of her when she bends the girdle ... Two dunes of sand leaned on two dunes of sand.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And sand like the hips of virgins I crossed ... While the dark nights covered it.'
This is from the inverted simile because they say: As if her hips are dunes of sand, as some of them said:

Al-Tammar said (Munsarih Meter):
'Her last tires her first ... So some of her is unjust to some.'
Abd al-Wahhab al-Sandubi took this meaning and said:
'He stood and the softness of his sides almost ... Was broken by the buttocks from his rising.'
'And how can he hope for justice from others ... While some of him wronged some?'
Al-Harith bin Khalid said:
'She rises with difficulty, her buttocks weighing her down ... The action of the weak rising with the load.'
From the free speech in this chapter is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'They returned what the waists lightened of it to ... What is in the waist-wrappers, so they found the buttocks heavy.'
Another said:
'Her buttocks became huge so they hurt her waist ... And her sash is anxious like the heart of the lover.'
The leanness of the flank and the looseness of the sash are considered beautiful by them. Al-Ta'i said regarding that:
'Of slenderness, if the anklets were made ... A clarity for her, the anklets would roam on her.'
Al-Najim said in the reverse of this mocking a songstress:
'Her anklets are forever in clamor ... Her sash is suppressed, silent.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mentioning women:
'And if they wear anklets ... They lie to the names of anklets (Khalkhal - implies looseness).'
'Their anklets refuse legs weighed down, languid.'
Khalid bin Yazid bin Muawiyah said:
'The anklets of women roam, and I do not see ... For Ramlah an anklet roaming nor a heart.'
Ubaydullah bin Ubaydullah said:

'Her sash envies her anklet ... As a hungry one envies a satiated one.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The desire of your eyes from him is between a sun of forenoon ... And a soft one of the branches of the Ban tree, succulent.'
'His upper parts lightened and his lower parts wrapped ... As if the Ban tree crafted his two halves for us.'
He has:
'She gave him my eye the slumber ... So she rewarded it from him with tears.'
'A gazelle, as if in his waist ... From his leanness is thirst and hunger.'
Chapter 21 On the Breast
From the beautiful simile in the breast is the saying of Amr bin Kulthum:
'And two breasts like the box of ivory, soft ... Protected from the palms of touches.'
Al-Hasan bin al-Takhtakh said regarding two breasts:
'Or like halves of two boxes of ivory ... You resembled two breasts truly.'
Bashar said:
'And the breast, you think it drowsy or lazy ... And it swayed a swaying not broken.'
Al-Qallakh said:
'As if the color of eggs in the nest ... Is your color except the yellowness of saffron.'
'The dome of the kidneys is the knot of the breast.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Chests above them are boxes of ivory ... And pearls adorned by good arrangement.'
'The sayers say when they see it ... Is this pearl from these boxes?'

This is taken from the saying of Abdullah bin Abi al-Samt bin Marwan in a poem of his (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if the breasts when they appear ... And necklaces adorn the chests with them.'
'Are boxes of ivory hidden ... Holding much of pearls.'
He has on the tongue of a man called Hamdan bin Salim:
'And breasts, swelling ... Like the corners of bookcases.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said, although there is no simile in it:
'I was longing and nothing blocks me ... From you except a barrier preventing me.'
'Rising in the chest, angry at ... The domes of the belly and the folding of the creases.'
'It fills the palm and does not separate it ... So if you bent it, it does not bend.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding songstresses:
'Feeding their children breasts ... Swelling like the best pomegranate.'
'Full as if they are flowing ... While they are empty of the flow of milk.'
Chapter 22 On Songstresses
From the beautiful simile regarding a songstress is the saying of some of them:
'And Ukasha made easy from the hand of a girl, as if her fingertips ... Are of silver that tipped jujubes.'
'And as if her right hand when she spoke with it ... Meets a calculation on her left hand.'
Like the first verse is for Abu Nuwas:
'O moon whom a funeral surrounded ... Wailing with sorrow among peers.'
'He weeps, so he sheds pearls from his eye ... And slaps the rose with jujube.'
Combining good simile and close metaphor is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi describing female singers:
'And songstresses as if they are mothers ... Affectionate to their sons, compassionate.'
'Having children while they did not carry a fetus ... Breastfeeding while they are not possessing milk.'
'Feeding their children breasts ... Swelling like the best pomegranate.'
'Full as if they are flowing ... While they are empty of the flow of milk.'
'Every child is called by various names ... Between Oud, Mizhar, and Kiran.'
'His mother interprets for him forever ... While he is apparently rich from the interpreter.'
'He was given wisdom and clarity as a boy ... Like Jesus son of Mary, possessor of Paradise.'
Al-Ta'i recited:
'So as if he is in her lap a child of hers ... She hugged him between ribs and chest.'
'At times she tickles his belly, so if he slips ... She rubs an ear of the ears for him.'
Al-Najim said regarding a songstress (Mutaqarib Meter):
'When she embraced her Oud, she blamed ... And cooed to him the best of expression.'
'She tickles his belly slowly ... So he brings us amazing laughter.'
'And she rubs his ear if he slips ... And in truth is the discipline of one who sinned.'
'And people have disciplined his likes ... But he is the head of who was disciplined.'
Al-Hamduni said in likening the Oud:
'And a speaker with a tongue having no conscience ... As if he is a thigh attached to a foot.'
'He reveals the conscience of another in speech just as ... The writing with the pen reveals the conscience of another.'
Another said:
'As if his statue is a leg on a foot ... Attached to a thigh separated from the buttock.'
'His ears, from him, have gathered four ... Answering four in the hand of a worker.'
'So this is nasal, and this has humming ... And that is clear, and this has like hoarseness.'
Abu Malik al-A'raj said in describing the Oud:
'And working speakers from Kiran ... With a slit of thin eggs.'
'He has two eyes under his throat ... One of them resembled the moon of waning.'
'If she sang old or new ... Then the pocket has no protector from your palms.'
Ahmad bin Yusuf said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Leave the Oud from us, how hard it is ... And move to revelry and the wind's soughing.'
'With a bright-faced like the full moon in his cheek ... If he is in a gathering, he shakes it.'
Ibn Abi Awn al-Katib opposed him saying (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Lo, how ugly is the Duff, how foolish it is ... And oh for the Oud, how noble it is.'
'Its resting places are from the throats of songstresses ... To the limit of their luxurious thighs.'
'And playing in the knot of its strings are ... Fingertips polished, slender.'
'Like the touch of the physician the pulse of veins ... For the knowledge of the healthy and the sick.'
'Its strings whisper to you with the voice ... So their tongues fulfill its letters for you.'
Like that is the saying of Al-Najim regarding a songstress (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Her playing was good from Atib ... And increased as her singing came.'
'If she intended the tune before singing ... Her Oud recited her poetry to us.'
He said regarding a flute player:
'Qatul did not attend us except ... She kindled our burning with her enchanting.'
'She sings loudly with the voice, it is said it comes ... As if in her flute is a tongue.'
From good metaphor is his saying regarding a songstress:
'The songs of Atib come ... Always with the joys of souls.'

'She sings, so we dance with heads ... For her, and pipe with cups.'
Similar is his saying (Mujtath Meter):
'Salamah bin Sa'id ... Masters urging the wine.'
'If he sings, we pipe ... Upon him with cups.'
From the beautiful simile in this chapter is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'Bid'ah (Innovation) is to me like her name, an innovation ... There is no doubt in that nor deception.'
'As if the delicacy of her heard (voice) ... Is the delicacy of a complaint that preceded a tear.'
'She sang and did not need a piper ... Does the morning need a candle?'
'And the flute escorted her wonders ... Like a doe overlooking a hill.'
'As if a crown increased in joy ... Not a turban covered nor a baldness.'
Al-Najim said regarding his saying "delicacy of a complaint that preceded a tear":
'Hazwa created among us with her charm ... Royal singing thinner than complaint.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'She extended to you a fingertip like a worm ... Complaining of separation and an eye like a spring.'
'Her words almost, from recognizing distance ... Out of the delicacy of complaint, became tears.'
Abu Uthman said regarding a songstress (Munsarih Meter):
'Atib and her Mizhar did not sing loudly ... But we trusted in amusement and joy.'
'She has singing like healing in a body ... Exhausted by the length of sickness and grief.'
'The wine worships it, so as long as she sings ... Our pitcher is prostrating on the cup.'
Another said:
'When her Mizhar yearned for her ... And the noble drinkers yearned for its voice.'
'And they inclined ears towards her until ... As if they, while not sleeping, were asleep.'
In good listening to singing, Al-Najim says:
'We are silent if she intends her singing ... Our silence if the preacher spoke.'
A Bedouin said:
'The air has stagnated until ... As if it is an ear listening.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And my boon companions in youth and old age ... Generous souls destroyed their wealth.'
'Between their cups is a short conversation ... It is magic and what is other than it is speech.'
'And singing that hastens wine with wine ... As the pigeon cooed in the branches.'
'And as if the cupbearers among the boon companions ... Are Alifs standing between the lines.'
Likening singing to the cooing of the pigeon is an old circulated meaning, and the condition is presenting the rare. Al-Najim said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'If you distinguish the people of singing ... You distinguish her as the most skilled, the best.'
'She shakes the poetry with her melodies ... As the East wind shook the branch.'
He also has:
'The tones of Hubba did not resemble ... Except the embracing of loved ones.'
'How lovely is Hubba, indeed she ... Is to our joy always beloved.'
He also said:
'She did not sing but a worry was uncovered ... From a heart and sorrows cleared.'
'She excels the singers in goodness and skill ... Like hearing excels seeing.'
He also said regarding a songstress:
'God revived Abu Yahya, for he ... Revives us with our hearing from Atib.'
'She started singing to us, so we thought she ... Out of her joy at her singing, sings to us.'
From good metaphor in this meaning is his saying (Munsarih Meter):
'Atib and her Mizhar did not speak ... Except we remained working for the wine.'
'Her strings seek worries with strings ... So they do not recover, she kills them.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mourning the slave girl of Umm Ali bint al-Rasibi called Bustan (Munsarih Meter):
'Oh for that annihilation from a calamity ... Capable over all hearts.'
'She became, from dwelling in their graves ... The dwelling of expensive perfumes in the oil containers of beds.'
'O drinking place that was for me without turbidity ... O night talk that was for me without sleeplessness.'
'You became in the soil not outweighing ... By it, while you outweigh the full moon.'
Al-Najim said mourning Aja'ib, the slave girl of Ibn Marwan:
'The soil became by her neighborhood ... The most fragrant of paths and drinking places.'
'She occupied her grave the occupation ... Of the king the thrones of processions.'
'O pearl that was illuminating ... For an onlooker from every side.'
Like that is the saying of Ibrahim bin al-Abbas:
'A pearl, wherever it was turned, it shone ... And a smelling place, wherever it was smelled, it diffused.'
Al-Najim said regarding a songstress:
'Singing more delicious than the beginning ... Of the eye in its slumber.'
'Sweeter and more desirable than the wish ... Of a soul in the truth of its hope.'
He also said:
'She has amazing, entertaining singing ... It does what wine does.'
'It makes the ear yearn for her singing ... As the eye yearns for greenery.'
'As if the joy of one who visited her ... Is the joy of one to whom the Qumrah (bird) flew.'
'If Ishaq sang after her ... You would think the listener is in mockery.'

'Rare in all her melodies ... Not like the one who is rare in rarity.'
He has mocking a songstress in the reverse of this meaning:
'I wondered at her, woe to her, how she does not ... Get charity in rarity.'
This is taken from the saying of Ibn Munadhir mocking a judge:
'Oh wonder at Khalid, how ... He errs among us once by being right.'
Abu Uthman said regarding a songstress (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Atib excelled in singing ... And increased and exceeded the excellent.'
'Her listener glorifies (God) if she sings ... So her voices are the rosary of the listener.'
Included in this chapter, even if it has no simile, is what Yahya bin Ali wrote to Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'My master, indeed we have Ziryab ... She filled us with narration and correctness.'
'She wore out her evil and her benevolence in hearing ... Increases in newness and youth.'
Ibn al-Jahm said regarding Nabatah, the slave girl of Ibn Hammad:
'His dwelling is desolate except of plants (Nabat) ... And his signs and ruins are erased.'
'Every thing she does has become clear from her ... Except singing, its Nasb and its Raml.'
'So she is as he sent truly his likeness ... You have nothing of your Sheikh except his deed.'
Chapter 23 On Satire of Songstresses
From the beautiful simile in satire of songstresses is the saying of Ibn Uthman regarding a flute player:
'The flute of Qatul is killing ... With the stench from it, raising dust.'
'It resembles in my view a sewer pipe ... Mounted in an exit.'

'And possessor of a flute, bright her face ... Beloved of glances and coquetry.'
'As if she kisses a child of hers ... She committed adultery with from the children of Zanj.'

'Your time met you with a flute player ... Striking fire in the face of every joy.'
'Win the edge of her jaws when she blew ... That is more fitting for her than the flute.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking a songstress:
'Green like the scorpion in yellowness ... Freckled like the snake in its spots.'

'If she sees a huge penis ... She falls to it saying: Put it down.'

'And she swallows provisions and puffs ... So she is, of the two meanings, a whale.'

'I lost you, O Kunayzah, every loss ... And tasted death, the first who dies.'
'For you were given a wide mouth and vulva ... As if you are from both your ends a whale.'
Al-Basir said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Your singing to me kills joy ... And your playing the Oud revives grief.'
'I have not seen before you a songstress ... Singing so I think she is wailing.'
Were it not that our purpose is rare similes, we would have mentioned a collection of satire for female singers: And we will mention it in the other book.
From the rare similes in connected verses is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'Her smell while she is alive is the smell of a dead ... Who spent the night in the grave then exhumation revealed him.'
'And you see her seeking concealment with perfume and litharge ... Secretly her stench while she breaks wind.'
'Her dusty pockmarked face resembles ... Yesterday's plaster whose top a drizzle hit.'
'Smallpox, what is the matter with her, and it is a flaw ... Every trace in that face is an engraving.'
'Every thing erased her ornaments so it is decoration ... Every thing the dust hid so it is furnishing.'

'As if he sang to the sun of the forenoon ... So it dotted him out of joy with stars.'

'And a listener whose separation I did not lack ... For it is a blessing of blessings.'

Al-Massisi said:

'And if you walk, a rolling thing (Dahrujah) ... And if you veil, a gap (Farujah).'
'O forehead bald, open ... And anus wide, ginned (Mahlujah).'
'To you, O one whose mouth is a waterskin ... And whose exhausted anus is a Falujah (plowed land?).'
Chapter 24 On Satire of Women
Connected to the satire of songstresses is what women were satirized with. Among the good of that is the saying of Di'bil (Mutaqarib Meter):
'I saw a gazelle and she looked out ... So she revealed to my eyes a belt.'
'Short of build, squat ... She rolls in walking like the hazelnut.'
'As if a cubit on her palm ... When she uncovered, is the tail of the spoon.'
'She draws her eyebrow with ink ... And ties a pad on her buttocks.'
'And a nose stuck on her face ... Short of nostrils like the pistachio.'
'And two breasts, a breast like an acorn ... And another like the filled waterskin.'
'And a mouth, if she grimaced, you thought it ... The joints of a closed table leg.'
A Bedouin said regarding his wife:
'And she cannot use kohl due to the narrowness of her eye ... If she tried, it became above the sockets.'
'And in her eyebrows is a fleece for a sack ... If shaved, they would be three sacks.'
'And two breasts, as for one, it is a banana ... And another in it is a waterskin for the traveler.'
Another said:
'The buttocks are lean, her shoulders are hobbled ... As if the manger of a sheep is in her collarbones.'
'And the breast of her is draped on the thighs ... As if it is a waterskin whose content has flowed.'
Di'bil said (Munsarih Meter):
'As if her palm when she dyed it ... Is the claws of the hawk stained with blood.'
Abu al-Najm recited to Hisham regarding his daughter:
'As if Zhullamah, sister of Shayban ... Is an orphan while her parents are alive.'
'The head is all lice and nits ... And there is nothing in the legs but threads.'
'So she is the one from whom Satan is terrified.'
So he gifted him one hundred and fifty dinars and said to him: Put this in place of the two threads.
Di'bil bin Ali said:
'Cut me off, O creation of the nail ... And connect me with the length of distance of the visit.'
'A deficient chin and a long nose ... And a forehead like the teak of the moneychanger.'
Another said regarding his wife:
'I seek refuge in Allah from a scrawny, obscene one ... As if her two clothes were hung on a stick.'
'Her waist does not hold the rope when she girds ... And in the tailbone and the tendon is sharpness.'
'I seek refuge in Allah from a leg that has malice ... As if it is from the iron of the blacksmith, a skewer.'
Another said:
'When she laughed, wrinkles roamed as if they were ... Dewlaps of a chameleon in Hawran, sunning.'
'As if her jugular veins are two ropes of a pulley ... Twisted from skin of raw hide, dry.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'On the outside of her face are creases ... And two-thirds of her face is chin.'
'And teeth like the feathers of the ... Duck, between their roots is rot.'
Di'bil said regarding a woman:
'Wide-mouthed, ugly, her laughing reveals the liver ... Aquiline in width and big-eyed in length.'
'She has a mouth, the meeting of its jaws ... Her nape, as if her lip was cut from an elephant.'
Al-Najim said mocking the husband of an old woman (Mutaqarib Meter):
'You will envy from her when she comes to you ... With furs of a monkey and backs of a ghoul.'
'And you embraced from her the awn of a spike ... Meeting the bedfellow with the like of arrowheads.'
Di'bil said:
'May Allah not bless a night that brings me near ... Except a lying together like rubbing with rope.'
'I touched her nakedness but my hand did not fall ... From what I touched except on a peg.'
'In every limb of hers is a crack she hits with ... The side of the bedfellow so he becomes weak of body.'
A Bedouin said to his wife:
'An index finger for the husband and the mother-in-law ... As if her legs are the trotters of a sheep.'
'In a foot as if it is a shovel.'
Di'bil said:
'Your temples have turned gray and your chest is dry ... And the chest of you is like the breast of the Tanbur.'
'O you whose hugger spends the night as if he is ... In a lice-infested prison and in a pillory.'
'I kissed her and found the sting of her saliva ... On the tongue like the sting of the wasp.'
Abu Ubayda recited for a Bedouin regarding his wife (Mutaqarib Meter):
'I was afflicted with a virago like the stick ... More thieving and malicious than a Kundash (magpie?).'
'She has the hair of a monkey when adorned ... And a face like the speckled egg of the sandgrouse.'
'And a leg an anklet rattles on ... Like the leg of the chicken or thinner.'
'She has a knee like the hoof of the gazelle ... More intensely yellow than the apricot.'
'As if the warts on her face ... When she unveiled are the seeds of currants.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Munsarih Meter):
'Sprinkled with her moles so her skin ... Is patterned like the skin of the leopard.'

Another said:
'And he is infatuated with a speckled, freckled one ... Like the grain of nigella in Shiraz (cheese/milk).'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking a servant:
'Freckles upon yellowness so you see him ... Like the specks of flies in pollen.'
Al-Mu'adhdhal bin Ghaylan said:
'And a knee like the egg of the ostrich ... As if the growth of hair painted.'
'Upon it is nigella on a round loaf (Furni).'
Di'bil said:
'Black, wide-mouthed, having hair ... As if it is ants on a sackcloth.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And she has a thicklip (Ka'thab) like the hoof of a gazelle ... In it is a crack as if it is a scratch.'
Chapter 25 On the Nut Bow (Qaws al-Bunduq)
From the beautiful simile in the nut bow is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'As if its back and the horns that are in it ... Even if the eye does not find them except by tracking.'
'Is a sprinkler of crushed saffron upon a stone ... Upon which the creeping ants crawled, advancing.'
'It has a beginning obedient to the hands and an end ... If you task it with drowning (full draw) in it, it resists.'
He took this meaning from the saying of Al-Shamikh regarding the bow:
'So he tasted, and it gave him of softness a side ... Sufficient, and it has a barrier preventing the arrow from drowning.'
Ibn al-Rumi also said:
'In it is available for its thrower the targets as if ... The caller of death called them for him so they heard.'
'The birds turn towards it a seeing eye ... Like your eyes, nay sharper in intelligence and faster.'
'Squared, divided from its ingots ... Like the statue of the idol's house, sufficient for you as a square.'
'It has a wailing, more fitting for the one it hits ... And more worthy of wailing is the one who was pained.'
This resembles his saying regarding a woman:
'The lover complains and she meets while she is complaining ... Like the bow wounding the targets while it is ringing.'
Al-Shammakh said describing a bow:
'When the archers twang from it, it hums ... The humming of a bereaved mother pained by funerals.'
Tha'lab recited describing the bow:
'And it, if you twang from it, coos ... The humming of the bereaved mother, she refused, she does not sleep.'
He also recited to us:
'You hear after the pulling and stringing ... In its two curved ends the ringing of the Tanbur.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'The sorrowful one was destined to bridle his bow ... With the smallest of the curved back, not unarmed.'
'So he deposited in it an arrow like the comb of combers ... Which they sent into a parting so it penetrated.'
'Slow if you hastened the release of its notch ... But if you slowed in the pull, it hastened.'
Another said regarding the bow and arrows:
'I prepared a mute one for stabbing and a coat of mail ... Loose, and a spear from the wood of Kharsan.'
'And joints of Shawhat wood, as if its yearning ... In the palm is the wailing of a bereaved ringing one.'
'And long arrowheads, blue, as if their blades ... Were sharpened by the flames of fire.'
'Their notches are the filling of the quiver as if they are ... Mouths of chicks of small birds (Nughran).'
Chapter 26 On the Sword
From the good simile in the sword is the saying of Ishaq bin Khalaf:
'He threw by the side of his waist ... Sharper than the decreed term.'
'And as if the sprinkling of dust ... Upon it is the breaths of winds.'
Imru' al-Qays said:
'Pillowing a sharp sword whose edges ... In its blade are like the track of ants.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And he stripped from its scabbards every thin sword ... If the palm unsheathed it, it almost flowed.'
'You see upon its blade the firind (water pattern) as if ... The blacksmith breathed into it while it is polished.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And how can the one whom a sword settled his worry sleep the night ... Like the color of salt, white, sharp.'
'You lied, by the House of Allah, you will not take it ... By force as long as the sword has a hilt.'
Mansur al-Namari said:
'A male (sword), by its luster the blood as if ... It covers the men with soaking purple.'
'And you see the edges of its two blades as if they are ... Salt scattered from behind the armored one.'
Another said:
'And a sharp sword cutting the necks of the neck ... As if its two sides, salt is sprinkled on them.'
'And the crawl of ants crept in the tracks of ants.'
Abu al-Hawl said:
'A sword on the morning of fright, passing as if it is ... From Allah in seizing souls a messenger.'
'The pupil of the eye floats in its shimmering ... And swims in its clothes and roams.'
'As if armies of ants broke upon it ... Horns of locusts, between them are vengeances.'
'As if upon its firind is the wave of a deep sea ... Shortening in its shallow water and lengthening.'
'If death stretches in its wakefulness ... Then there must be a soul there flowing.'
'And if it glances at the heroes or shakes hands with the necks ... A slain one will sprawl one day among them.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Amidst the army in his palm is a male ... Sharp sword as if in its blade are freckles.'

'Pure of iron, as if its polisher ... Wrote the firind on it or engraved.'
Abu al-Hawl said:
'Musa al-Amin possessed the Samsamah (sword) of Al-Zubaydi from among all mankind.'
'And as if the firind and the luster flow...ing on its two pages are flowing water.'
'It flies the sights like the lit torch ... Eyes do not settle in it.'
'It does not care when the struck object comes ... Whether a left hand attacked with it or a right.'
'Excellent handkerchief (Mikhraq) of the possessor of rage in the war ... He strikes with it, and excellent companion.'
'Al-Mikhraq': The napkin children play with. Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'I fight them on the Day of the Garden bare-headed ... As if my hand with the sword is the handkerchief of a player.'
From the best said regarding the sword is the saying of Al-Buhturi, even if it has no simile:
'He attains the hope distant in its attainment ... Easily, and opens in the locked decree.'
'Passing (sharp) even if the hand of a knight did not pass it ... Hero, and polished even if not polished.'
'He covers the battle, so the shield is not a protection ... From his edge, and the coat of mail is not a fortress.'
'Listening to the judgment of death, so if he passed ... He did not turn, and if he decreed he did not deviate.'
'Glowing, he cuts with the first blow ... What it caught, even if it were in Yadhbul (mountain).'
'And if he hits, then everything is a killing spot ... And if he is hit, he has no killing spot.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And I have a sharp sword in which deaths are hidden ... So it is not unsheathed except to shed blood.'
'You see upon its two blades the firind as if it is ... A remnant of a cloud thinned without sky.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The best of what the palm held fast to is a sharp ... Male sword whose edge is soft of shaking.'
'You did not contemplate it with your eyes except ... Its two pages trembled without shaking.'
'Its like frightened the brave to the armor ... So he rose with it over every spoil.'
'He does not care if his two blades were determined ... In a notch or passed beyond a notch.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'In his palm is a sharp sword, if he shook it ... You thought it trembling from his fear.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The sayers say when they see it ... For a matter, the armors were overcome.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And I shook a Hindi sword ... Sharp of edges, thinned.'
'And when it entered the head of the ... Tyrant, it traveled and hurried.'
'Sharp of edges like the stream ... Expelled the speck until it cleared.'
A man from Tayy said:
'And possessor of ridges as if it is the belly of a snake ... When the palm tested it with the bone, it persisted.'
Chapter 27 On Spears
From the beautiful simile in spears is the saying of Antara:
'They call Antara while the spears are as if they are ... Ropes of a well in the chest of the dark horse.'
Duraid bin al-Simmah said:
'So I came to him while the spears were picking at him ... Like the falling of the shuttles on the stretched weave.'
Al-Ta'i excelled in their description even if there is no simile in it, which is his saying:
'Straightened ones, they robbed the Romans of their blueness ... And the Arabs of their brownness and the lovers of slenderness.'
The Arabs say: As if so-and-so is a spear. A Bedouin came to a club, so those in it moved to make room for him. He said: Only the planting place of a spear suffices me.
Muzarrid said regarding the spear:
'And a steady one, soft of joints, as if ... A flow of oil covered it.'
'Solid, if shaken its back quivered ... As the snake of the seeking sands quivered.'
'It has a shaking head, sharp of edge, as if it is ... A crescent appeared in the darkness of the night, emaciated.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'As if the Lahdhami spearheads in the forenoon ... Are wicks lit at the ends of the Rudayni spear.'
Layla al-Akhyaliyyah said:
'Indeed Al-Khali' and his group from Amir ... Are like the heart clothed in a chest and a windpipe.'
'And a people, the tying of horses is in the middle of their houses ... And blue spearheads imagined to be stars.'
Ibn Ju'ayl al-Taghlibi said:
'I shook a Rudayni as if its spearhead ... Is the light of a flame not ignited with smoke.'
Di'bil said:
'And a brown spear, in its head is a blue point ... Like the tongue of the thirsty snake.'
Another said:
'My carrying the spear has prolonged until as if it is ... Upon my shoulder a branch growing from the tree.'
'My tongue lengthens in the clan reconciling ... While on the day of hateful war it is silent.'
Sa'idah bin Ju'ayyah said:
'So prepare a blue point on the spear as if it is ... In the darkness of gloom the light of a meteor.'
Chapter 28 On the Description of the Coat of Mail
Abu Du'ad said in describing a coat of mail (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And I prepared for war a spacious one ... Shrinking in folding like the file.'
'Its sleeves overflow on the man ... Like the overflow of the stream on the hard ground.'
Tha'lab recited:

'So I restrained him until I wore a wide coat ... Smooth like the color of the pool when wind blew and rained.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'How many a hero I duelled in the battle ... Upon him is a coat of mail you thought flowing.'
'As if it is water running upon him ... Until when it disappeared in him, it froze.'
He has:
'And coats of mail as if they are the mixed gray hair of the curly ... Oiled, in which combs get lost.'
Another said:
'And a huge gathered army, its horses ... Are blood-stained in their manes and throats.'
'Upon them are the degraded of the blacksmiths (armors) as if they are ... The eyes of vipers, their weave and rivets.'
Another said:
'Its battalions weighed the mountains and clad ... Rings of iron so they showed its equipment.'
'So you imagine the wave of the sea, some of it tilting ... To some, the flash of its rivets and its weave.'
Salim al-Khasir said:
'As if the bubbles of pools flowed upon them ... And it is nothing but the wide flowing coats of mail.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Where there is no aid except a sharp sword ... And a shield like the bubbles of water covering me.'
Tha'lab recited to us:
'And a coat of mail mocking the blades ... As if it is from the slough of the snake (Hilal).'
He claimed 'Al-Hilal' is the snake. Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Halabi took it and said:
'I restrained its first with a true strike ... Cutting as the marked cloak is torn.'
'And upon me is a wide-tailed one as if it is ... A slough with which the brave speckled snake clothed me.'
Muzarrid bin Dirar said:
'And a poured wide one, Tubba'i ... Its rivets shine, the broad arrows dislike it.'
'Smooth like the back of the fish, no spearhead can pierce it ... Nor those entering wooden arrows.'
Mu'aqqir al-Bariqi said regarding helmets:
'As if the ostriches of the desert laid eggs upon them ... And their eyes under the iron are staring.'
Salamah bin Jandal said:
'As if ostriches laid eggs over their heads ... To death is a lightning from Tihama shining.'
Chapter 29 On the Equality of Peers in War
From the beautiful similes in the equality of peers in war is the saying of Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah:
'As if we, in the morning, and the sons of our father ... By the side of Unayzah are two millstones of a turner.'
He also said similar to this:
'They twanged the handles of bows and threatened ... Us as stallions threaten stallions.'
Zuhair took this meaning and said:
'We stab them as long as they shoot, until if they stab ... He strikes, until if they strike, he embraces.'
Another said:
'I approached him with a white Mashrafi sword ... As the shaker of hands approaches for greeting.'
From the beautiful simile in advancing is the saying of Abu al-Atahiya:
'As if you on the day of stabbing in war are only ... Fleeing from the peace that is behind you.'
'As if deaths do not run in the battle ... When heroes meet except in your innocence.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'Whenever we fled, our worst fleeing was ... The turning of cheeks and the deviation of shoulders.'
'The turning of cheeks while spears are engaged ... And feet do not leave during the striking.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Abu Sa'id:
'Indeed that heart was the heart of a peaceful man ... Even though that attire was the attire of a warrior.'
'You hasten until one who witnessed the battle said ... Is it a meeting of enemies or a meeting of loved ones?'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'How many a depth of death whose wading is feared ... I ran in it the running of a thread in a hole.'
'Until when it was said a term came to him ... I emerged from it with a dyed sword.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'And we were, when the destined luck deceived him ... The light of a morning lightning or the noise of a thunderer.'
'Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid dropped upon him ... With sharp swords whose long baldric made him proud.'
'In front of a purple army as if it is ... A shirt woven of spears and horses.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding the density of the army:
'To Allah is your deed on the day of Babak, brave ... Hero, knocking on the doors of deaths.'
'When he came to you leading a huge army ... Walking to him in density and crowds.'
'You distributed them between spearheads and blades ... Until you showed their crowds a distribution.'
'In a tight battlefield where you imagine the spears ... Between the ribs, if they bent, are ribs.'
Ibn al-Rumi said describing a battalion:
'If a cloud pelted them in the open space ... Its pebbles would remain rolling upon them.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said similar to that, and it is its origin:
'If you were to throw colocynth upon our helmets ... It would roll from a possessor of mark, convergent.'
'Al-Sam' here is the lines of gold in the helmets. 'Al-Sam' in other than this place is death. Muslim bin al-Walid said regarding an army:
'The open earth shines with it ... Like the night, its stars are the bars and spears.'

Similar to it is what Tha'lab recited for Bashar in likening two things in one verse. They claimed that Bashar said: When I heard the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry ... At her nest, are jujubes and withered dates.'
I strained my thought until I said:
'As if the raising of dust above our heads ... And our swords are a night whose stars are falling.'
Mansur al-Namari said similar to this:
'A night of dust, no sun nor moon ... Except your forehead and the sharpened spears.'
For some of them:
'And he left their head with continuous striking ... And stabbing not weak nor boring.'
'As if his spearhead in his shoulders ... Is a meteor behind a cursed devil.'
Another said regarding horses:
'Their hooves wove a sky above them ... They made their spearheads the stars of their sky.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And the dust covered the sky until it was as if it were ... Smoke and the tips of spears were sparks.'
Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'The Caliph unsheathed a sword from Banu Matar ... Passing, piercing bodies and heads.'
'Like Time, not turning away from what he intends ... He has encompassed people with compulsion and favor.'
'He executes deaths as his spearheads execute ... As if in his saddle is a full moon and a lion.'
A Bedouin said:
'We throw raids at Abs and Tayy ... And Tamim and Madhhij have fled from us.'
'With invasion like the lapping of the wolf, coming early and returning ... And marching like the chest of the sword, not bending.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Abu Sa'id:
'Their vanguard if the army headed out raiding ... And their rearguard if the army headed back returning.'
'Kings who count spears as staffs ... When they shake them, and coats of mail as inner shirts.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'A people, if they get angry at their enemies ... Drag iron as spearheads and coats of mail.'
'And as if our hands scare away from them ... Birds that were landing on the bodies.'
Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'Overlooking souls on a day of dust ... As if he is a term running to a hope.'
'He attains with gentleness what men are incapable of ... Like death, rushing, coming slowly.'
Ibn al-Rumi said praising Sa'id and mentioning the affair of the Alawi:
'You besieged the leader of the Zanj until his powers ... Failed and his provision carrier perished.'
'His sides were dense, but you ceased not ... Diminishing them with eradication as if you were a file.'
'His soldiers disperse from him by stratagems ... And you increase them as soldiers while your army is firm.'
'And the wearer of the peer's sword after stripping him ... Is more harmful to him than his breakers and more plotting.'
'You settled a settling that was hostage to an assault ... Dark, thus the lion crouches to leap.'
This meaning is taken from the saying of Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani:
'Indeed I forbade Banu Dhubyan from Aqr ... And from their grazing in every Safar.'
'And I said: O people, indeed the lion is contracted ... Upon his claws for the assault of the harmer.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Sa'id and the affair of a city:
'She refused but to be besieged, so there became for her ... From fear of the calamity of siege, a siege.'
'They humbled to your assault which is to them ... Like death coming having no shame.'
Similar to that is the saying of the poet:
'For indeed the Commander of the Faithful and his deed ... Are like Time, there is no shame in what Time did.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding the victory of Al-Afshin:
'If he did not march to them, they would have marched to him ... Due to what is in their chests of fears.'
'So as if his soul tricked against him ... If the trick of the trickster did not reach him.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Sa'id:
'You see him isolated from the fierce war ... While his traces in it, even if he is absent, are witnessed.'
'Just as the decree and the judgment is His judgment ... Veiled from people entirely, there is no escape from Him.'
Abu al-Hawl said regarding Yazid bin Mazyad taking Al-Walid bin Tarif:
'Say to the caravans and the armies and others ... Travel, for Yazid has killed Al-Walid.'
'Neither this one ceases seeking nor that one falls short ... Fleeing, so this is fatigue and that is exhausted.'
'Like the night, the day seeks it with its light ... So the darkness of that is chased by the light of this.'
Similar to that is the saying of Al-Nabigha to Al-Nu'man:
'For indeed you are like the night that overtakes me ... Even if I thought the distance from you is wide.'
One of the enamored with power said:
