'The evening we had the choice over them ... Whether to decrease from their lives or increase.'
Chapter 30 On the Description of the Stab
Connected to this is the saying of Imru' al-Qays describing the stab (Hazaj Meter):
'And I may snatch the stab ... My blade does not bleed for it.'
'Like the pocket of the foolish, clumsy woman ... Startled while she is searching for lice.'

He mentioned that the sword is most cutting when blood precedes. As he said: My blade does not bleed for it.
Another said (Hazaj Meter):
'And stabbing like the mouth of the wineskin ... While it and the wineskin are full.'
Another said:
'And stabbing like the mouths of water skins, you see for it ... Streams (Anajir), the watering of which is not touched by a returning one.'
Abu al-Najm said (Rajaz Meter):
'We shall surely throw down a lion whose funeral wails ... With a wide stab in which is his pain.'
'His blood boils from between his collarbones ... Like the dyer's cauldron boiled with its scum.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding Al-Muwaffaq when an arrow hit him:
'He split the crowds with his sword ... And healed the pains of grudges.'
'Bloody of wounds as if he is ... A rose opening on a branch.'
Antara said:
'And a husband of a beauty I left prostrate ... His shoulder muscle whistling like the corner of the harelip's mouth.'
'My hands preceded for him with a hasty stab ... And the spray of a penetrating one like the color of dragon's blood.'
Hassan said:
'Leave the gaps of Sham.' He said:
'Intervening before it ... Is striking like the mouths of the grazing pregnant camels.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Opening in the skulls of the people mouths ... Of camels grazing Arak and eating Asy.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'I stabbed Ibn Abd al-Qays the stab of a revenger ... It had a penetration, were it not for the rays, it would have illuminated it.'
'I possessed my hand with it so I widened its rip ... A standing one sees from this side what is behind it.'
'Al-Shu'a'': The scattering of blood and its redness. 'Malaktu al-ajina': i.e., I kneaded it strongly. Uthman, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Knead the dough strongly for it is one of the two increases. 'Anhartu': meaning I made flow, it is said 'Naharu al-anhar'.
Another said:
'And the hybrid of Banu Sulaym escaped us ... The colt is ransomed out of love for return.'
'Were it not for Allah and the ransomed colt ... You would have returned while you are a sieve of skin.'
Another said:
'I struck him in the meeting a blow ... So the withers separated from his shoulder.'
'So what was between them became a gap ... In which the lancer and archer walk.'
Another said:
'I left Ibn Aws while the spearhead was as if ... A peg aimed with it between his eyes.'
Chapter 31 On the Description of Rain Clouds and Meadows
From the excellent similes is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'And a rain cloud, rain was generous from its eyelids ... While the garden is organized and the drops are scattered.'
'You see its locations on the earth shining ... Like dirhams appearing then hiding.'
The meaning is from Antara describing a cloud:
'Every flowing spring was generous upon it ... So they left every puddle like the dirham.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz also said:
'And the tears of the pools did not become muddy ... As if they were dirhams in a spreading place.'
Al-Buhturi said describing a cloud:
'Possessing trembling with the moan of thunder ... Dragging the tail, truthful of promise.'
'Shedding tears without passion ... It has a breeze like the breeze of the rose.'
'And a ring like the roar of the lion ... And a flash of lightning like the swords of India.'
'The East wind brought it from Najd ... So it scattered like the scattering of a necklace.'
'So the earth became in a comfortable life ... From the embroidery of the flowers of hills in a cloak.'
'As if its pools in the depression ... Play with its bubbles with dice.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said in a poem of his:
'What do you see of the grace of the sky on the earth ... And the gratitude of gardens for rains?'
'And as if spring unveils a bride ... And as if we are from its drops in a scattering (of coins/sweets).'
Al-Ta'i said regarding a black cloud:
'I saw nothing but the blackness of diligence ... Connecting early departure with night travel.'
'She-camels, yet they are not she-camels ... Like the night, or like the Luba, or like the Nubians.'
'Led by a pitch-black cloud ... Like the Shia gathered around a leader.'
'Taking to the obedience of the South wind ... Undoing the ropes of calamities.'
'Erasing the sticking drought ... The erasing of kissing the Corner for sins.'
'When it appeared to the earth from near ... It longed for its pouring rain.'
'The longing of the sick for the doctor ... And the joy of the lover with the beloved.'
'And the happiness of the writer with the writer ... And the thunder stood in it like the preacher.'
'And the wind moaned the moan of old camels ... So the earth in its new robe.'
'Is like the middle-aged man after graying and bending ... Exchanged youth for gray hair.'
'Delicious of saliva with the pouring ... As if it pours upon hearts.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a cloud:
'And burdened with the weight of water, it came ... Swaying over the necks of winds.'
'So it poured its night heavily and abundantly ... And drizzling like the mouths of wounds.'
Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir said:

'Do you not see the day, its edges have softened ... And its caller has called you to pleasures?'
'And it was generous with rain until I thought that it has ... A lover far away, so it does not cease weeping for him.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Weeping, laughing from lightnings ... Traveled with a pocket torn in the darkness.'
'It inclined to the dry-saliva drought ... Like the inclination of a longing one to a beloved.'
'And it encompassed the soil like the collar ... Until it became a beautiful sight.'
'As if it imitates the weeping of the yearning one.'
Al-Ta'i said similar:
'As if the bright clouds hid beneath them ... A beloved, so tears do not stop for them.'
Abu Awn al-Katib said:
'The earth has come early to a morning drink ... It drinks it from the dew of the sky.'
'A rain like the tear of the yearning one, pouring ... Heavily upon the acacia and the Sorrel.'
'From a black cloud whose laughing is bright ... Like the mouth smiling from dark lips.'
Al-Mubarrad recited to us (Mutaqarib Meter):
'If Allah does not water except the noble ... Then may He water the dwellings of Banu Hanbal.'
'A rain, stationary, having a fringe ... Truthful of thunders and noise.'
'As if the clouds just below the sky ... Are ostriches hanging by the legs.'
Ubayd bin al-Abras said:
'Low, approaching just above the earth, its fringe ... He who stands with the palm almost pushes it.'
'So he who is in its high ground is like he who is in its courtyard ... And the sheltered is like he who walks in an open plain.'
Kuthayyir said similar:
'And the sheltered and he who walks in its desert ... Are equal in it, and he who is in the plain and the mountain.'
Regarding the covering of clouds, Imru' al-Qays says:
'A continuous rain, pouring, having low clouds ... Covering the earth, seeking and flowing.'
Ibn Abi Awn al-Katib said regarding the covering of clouds and its nearness:
'In a cloud that covered so it almost ... Shook hands with the soil with clouds.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said:
'And you see the sky when its white clouds approach ... And as if it was clothed in the wing of a crow.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the dark white clouds while the dawn is shining ... Are smoke of a fire whose embers do not light.'
Another said:
'The South wind wove it, and she is skilled ... So it ascended as if it were an Abyssinian.'
'And it collected (Qara) every gathering (Qariyah) it was collecting ... A collection, the gathered water (Qariyy) does not dry from it.'
'Al-Qariyan': Water courses, which are 'Al-Madhanib', singular 'Midhnab'.
Another said regarding a cloud:
'It came swaying, its peaks overlooking ... Dragging its first on its last.'
'The walk of the bride shortening her steps ... As if there falls from its insides.'
'Jumping locusts or their larvae.'
Tha'lab recited regarding a cloud:
'The onlooker thinks it from behind the tent ... Scattering rising locusts or larvae.'
'And the light donned a fitted shirt.'
Another said describing clouds when they empty their water:
'As if when their skin became weak ... And water poured from every cloud.'
'Is charcoal when its frying heated it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a cloud:
'It came with the eyelid of kohl and left ... Sore-eyed from the shedding of pouring tears.'
Another said describing the abundance of a torrent:
'It overturns a great tree in it to the chins ... Your crushing with the razor the hair of monks.'
Similar is the saying of Abu Qardudah (Mutaqarib Meter):
'It covers the thorny trees to their chins ... Like the covering of the stallion the slender young camels.'
Ibn Muqbil said describing the foam of a torrent:
'You see every valley baffled in it as if ... A salty rider stayed upon it.'
Chapter 32 On the Tripod Stones (Athafi)
From the beautiful similes in tripod stones is the saying of Abu Awn al-Katib:
'There remained in it nothing but blacks, experienced ... Like the coal of fire, in it is ash, neglected.'
Abu Nuwas said mocking Al-Qurashi:
'I saw people's pots black from the roasting ... And the pot of the Raqashis is white like the full moon.'
'He shows it to the seeker in their courtyard ... Three like the line of the Tha' (letter) from the dots of ink.'
Adi bin Zaid said (Ramal Meter):
'And three like pigeons in it ... Between their kneeling places is the tattooing of charcoal.'
He likened them to the pigeon because it has whiteness and blackness. Likewise is the saying of Jarir:
'As if the traces of the house are feathers of a pigeon ... Decay erased them and they became silent to speak.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding tripod stones:
'Whose is a trace, bare of place, buried ... Its era effaced except eternal blacks.'
'As pigeons were coupled at the roost ... Far of evening, they have no nests.'
Al-Murrar al-Faq'asi said:
'In every place are broad stones of a prostration place ... And standing ones in a fireplace, black.'
'The trace of fuel on their sides ... With their cheeks, as if it is a slap.'
Al-Ta'i said:

'Tripod stones like cheeks slapped in grief ... And a trench like the split of the bracelet.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Effaced except black ones standing as if they are ... Cheeks of virgins touched by pallor.'
Al-Ta'i said, and Ibn Tahir claimed it is the best thing said regarding the trench (Nu'y):
'And the trench, its half was erased so as if it is ... Under the accidents, an eyebrow joined (to the other).'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said similar:
'Effaced and emptied except moles of dung ... And a trench of hidden line like the single eyebrow.'
Jamil bin Ma'mar said:
'And traces of children and a trench as if it is ... A lip of a crescent, for the oldness standing.'
Chapter 33 On the Ruins (Talal)
Connected to that is the saying of Labid, and it is of the best simile:
'And the torrents revealed the ruins as if they are ... Books whose texts their pens renew.'
He informs that when the wind effaced the ruins and blew dust on them, and the rain came, it revealed the dust from them, so the traces appeared as faded scripts appear in books. 'Zubur': Books. Al-Muraqqish said, and he was named Al-Muraqqish by it:
'The house is desolate and the traces are as ... A pen dotted (Raqqasha) on the back of the leather.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'Is it for the four dark ones which are as if they are ... Remnants of revelation in the backs of scrolls.'
Tarafa said:
'For Khawlah there are ruins at the stony ground of Thahmad ... Shining like the remains of tattoo on the back of the hand.'
Zuhair said:
'And a house of hers at the two Raqmas as if it is ... Renewed tattoos on the veins of a wrist.'
'Al-Nawashir': Veins of the inner arm. 'Al-Washm': Decoration they used to use, and 'Al-Wasm' is its name, and they have names. 'Al-Rasm': Trace of a thing. Another said:
'I knew the dwellings of the tribe empty, waste ... As if in them, when I imagined them, was a line.'
'Renewed tattoos between a palm and a wrist ... Nights effaced it except that it has a trace.'
Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'Do you know a trace like the gilded embroidery ... For Amrah, desolate except for the standing of a rider?'
'Al-Madhahib': Leathers with gilded lines, steady, following each other, singular 'Madhhab'. 'Wahshan': i.e., desolate. From it, it is said to the one taking medicine 'Tawahhash': i.e., let nothing enter your stomach. 'Ghayra mawqifi rakibin': i.e., except that a rider passes and stops. Poetry in this chapter is very abundant. Abu Nuwas used to oppose the ways of the ancients and follow a path other than theirs in describing the decay of the trace and weeping over the ruins and asking for rain, as Al-Nimr bin Tawlab said:
'So by Allah, I do not ask rain for the dwellings for their love ... But I give you water, O Harith bin Tawlab.'
Al-Buhturi said mourning a boy:
'May Allah water Al-Jazirah not for anything ... Except that that well be quenched.'
Another said:
'May he water a grave containing Umm Amr ... At Nakhlah, what poured from the clouds.'
'And I do not ask rain for the earth, but ... For bodies that stayed in it and heads.'
Al-Ta'i said similar:
'Their house hosted shedding tears from me ... Even if my morning returned after them dark.'
'May He water their quarter, nay, may He water their distance ... From time, the udders of clouds full of milk.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding what we mentioned (Munsarih Meter):
'Watering for other than the height and the slope ... And other than the ruins of Mayya at Al-Jarad.'
'O pouring of the clouds, if you have ... Watered the bend once, do not return.'
'Do not water a town, if ... Towns are counted, it was an increase in grief.'
'If I protect myself from the crow in it ... My escape from it would be to the shrike.'
'Better to me than your falling with the ... Stone salting with it on a peg.'
'Is the standing of a basil on an ear ... And the movement of a cup to a mouth by a hand.'
He also said:
'Whose is a ruin increasing in beauty of traces ... With the length of its desolation and goodness of breeze?'
'Decay turned away from them until as if ... They wore from desolation a garment of bliss.'
Al-Buhturi said on the method of the ancients:
'I see among the wrapped Arak trees dwellings ... Standing, if only their oryxes were standing.'
'We met the dwellings at the bend, so as if we ... Met the beautiful women wearing no jewelry.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'If you wish not to see patience for a patient ... Then look at what state the ruin has become.'
'As if its singing place was generous so changed it ... Our tears the day they separated while they were pouring.'
Ibn al-Raqqi said similar:
'Longing turned him while man sobers and gets drunk ... Traces like the rags of scrolls, obliterated.'
'I held my companions at them, so its courtyards remained ... By my tears and breaths, joyful and rained upon.'
Mu'alla al-Ta'i said:
'They wore decay until as if their traces ... Tasted passion or tasted the abandonment of lovers.'
Muhammad bin Wuhayb said:

'They wore decay so as if they found ... After the loved ones the like of what I find.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'O East Wind of the afternoons, indeed the sandy ground of Thahmad ... Complains of your variation in eternal blowing.'
'Dung-heaps standing like stars, so if they are effaced ... Then by which star in passion do we guide ourselves?'
Al-Ta'i said:
'O ruins of Mayya, inform us at Manbij ... Is your singing forbidden to the exhausted sick one?'
'And among the deeds of ignorance is stopping a possessor of mind ... At courtyards like the confused book.'
He also said:
'Did you not see the dwellings of the daughter of Malik ... Her traces drew for him how sighing is?'
'And as if decay threw its staff in them ... Out of an intention of throwing, so it does not leave them.'
Al-Kumayt said:
'And a cracked (peg) the maids left its head ... Like the Siwak, and a piece of rope like the parchment.'
Regarding it Ibn Na'imah al-Madani says:
'And a castaway of humiliation cracked by the stone ... Upon its head is fine dust.'
Al-Mutalammis said regarding it:
'And none stays on humiliation he is subjected to ... Except the two humilitated ones: the donkey of the family and the peg.'
'This one is tied with his rope on humiliation ... And that one is cracked and no one pities him.'
Abu Nuwas mentioned it and said (Hazaj Meter):
'And a beaten one without sin ... And there is no sin in beating him.'
'And his beater does not blame him ... As long as the aged camels yearn.'
'And he does not say why ... Nor why am I beaten.'
'And a verse (house) too narrow for a shoelace ... And in it are the Khazars and Nubians.'
Meaning the verse of poetry. Another said regarding the erasure of dwellings:
'At the branch of the bend, and the quarter, its people have lightened ... And exchanged winds, South and North.'
'Co-wives settled in the courtyards as if ... They circled a sieve over what the tribe left.'
Similar is the saying of Urwa bin Udhaynah:
'And they sifted it the sifting of flour, staying ... Every wind lends it its sieve.'
Chapter 34 On Wine
From the beautiful similes in wine is the saying of Al-Ukkuk, who is Ali bin Jabalah:
'And a pure one, having softness in the cup ... And not having obstinacy in souls.'
'As if the hand of the boon companion circulates of it ... A ray which a cup does not surround.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Aged, the mixture forged for its head ... Crowns of pearls whose strung ones have no thread.'
'It was hidden until as if its light ... Is the certainty of a conscience which doubt almost enters.'
Abu Awn al-Katib said:
'And give it to me, may you be given drink, O Ibn Amr ... Of a bay (wine), shining like the ray.'
'Daughter of ten (years) like the thought of imagination or ... The snatching of lightning or like the sense of hearing.'
Ibn Abi Karima said:
'As if it is an accident in the palm of its drinker ... You think it empty while the cup is full.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'So drink upon the flowers of gardens mixed with ... The flowers of cheeks and the flower of wine.'
'From a coffee that makes one forget worries and sends ... Longing that has strayed in the vitals.'
'Its color hides the glass so as if it is ... Standing in the cup without a vessel.'
Ibn al-Rumi said in this meaning:
'And an orphan of her vine and her dew ... The sun left nothing of her but her core.'
'She became subtle so she almost became diffused ... In the air like its ray and its breeze.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And Karkhi in lineage or Babylonian ... She stayed eras in the darkness of the cave not traveling.'
'She poured the purity of water over her purity ... So I solved them as a basket from the sun and the moon.'
Another said:
'Water of vines and water of the Nile in a cup ... And water is two waters in what resembles water.'
'A cup that cleared, and its glass cleared from it ... As if it, for the resemblance of color, is hollow.'
Ibn Abi Umayyah said:
'Give me drink in Surra Man Ra'a to the monastery ... Then the top of the valley to its bends.'
'From a drink as if it is not in the cup ... When you poured it, due to its purity.'
Another said regarding its thinness and purity:
'And a cup the merchants captured from the land of Babylon ... Like the thinness of the water of longing in the wide eyes.'
'If the cupbearer mixed it, you thought its bubbles ... Eyes of locusts from under the wings of ants.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'And there is nothing for amusement but every pure one ... As if she is a tear in the eye of an abandoned one.'
Another said (Munsarih Meter):
'And coffee like tears, pure ... From the eye of a lover whom sadness melted.'
Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said:
'And he disputed with me a cup as if its saliva ... Is my tears when sleep was blocked from my eye.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'So give us from your clear sweet drink ... And do not prohibit us, may the sky water you.'

'From eyes as if it is the tear of the abandoned ... Weeping while his eye is sore.'
Al-Asha said regarding its purity:
'It shows you the speck from behind it while it is behind it ... If he tasted it, he who tasted it smacks his lips.'
Al-Nazzam was asked about glass, he said: It does not hide the speck, nor covers the face of the boon companion, and its fault is that breaking comes quickly to it and it does not accept mending.
From the beautiful simile it was likened to is the saying of Abu Nuwas (Munsarih Meter):
'Then I poked its head with the blade of the awl ... So it came as if it were a flame.'
'I say when they resembled each other in likeness ... Which of them is gold for the resemblance?'
'They are equal and the difference between them ... Is that they are solid and poured.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O my two boon companions, give me drink for there appeared ... A morning and the Christian bell called.'
'From a bay (wine) as if it is a land of gold dust ... In its sides are planted pearls.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Aged in the jar until ... It is in the thinness of my religion.'
'Then mixed so turned ... Around it like eyes.'
'Pupils gazing at us ... Not stony with eyelids.'
'Gold bearing fruit of pearls ... Every time and moment.'
He also has (Munsarih Meter):
'And old wine I went early to its tavern ... So they cut its jugular vein with a strainer.'
'So sweat flowed on its upper chest ... As if its course is the twist of an anklet.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said (Munsarih Meter):
'Coming out of its jar while humped ... Like a crescent appearing with curvature.'
'Whoever blames me regarding wine is like one who ... Writes with water on papers.'
Aws bin Hajar said:
'I will write in the pure water to you ... Upon your distance if there is a writer for water.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'So when you unveiled it, it is dust ... Denying the palm what it permits the eyes.'
'Then mixed so laughed revealing pearls ... If gathered in a hand we would have acquired them.'
'In cups as if they are stars ... Running, their constellations are our hands.'
'Rising with the cupbearers upon us ... So when they set, they set in us.'
'If you saw the drinkers around it from afar ... You would say a people warming themselves from cold.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'A gazelle free of sorrows deposited in me ... What Allah knows of sorrow and anxiety.'
'As if he and as if the cup in his hand ... Is the crescent of the first of the month gulping in twilight.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And a slender one whose beauties were complete ... Until he exceeded the wish of the soul.'
'The cups yearn for his sipping places ... And smile in his hand from imprisonment.'
'And as if he and the cup in his hand ... Is a moon kissing the side of the sun.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'If the drinker of the people gulped in it, you thought him ... Kissing in a dark night a star.'
He also has:
'And as if its drinker, due to excess of its ray ... At night, is sipping in the light of a torch.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O beauty of Ahmad going early yesterday ... With a yellow wine like Wars.'
'And as if his palms divide in ... Our cups pieces of the sun.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Munsarih Meter):
'And we are given drink the drink of a possessor of manners ... His praise is from the fruits of kindness.'
'It meets you in the thinness of drink and in ... The scent of lavender and yellowness of twilight.'
'It has a pure part as if it is gold ... And foam like restless pearls.'
Likening bubbles to halves of pearls is better than likening it to whole pearls. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Give drink the veiled one of the jars ... The first juice of wine, strong.'
'A wine as if its bubbles ... Are pearls rolling, hollow.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'As if the small and large of its bubbles ... Is gravel of pearls on a land of gold.'
He has:
'Then mixed so turned ... Above it a collar so it circled.'
'Like the coupling of pearls with pearls ... Small and large.'
'So if the eye intercepts it ... From where it circled.'
'You thought it in the sides of the ... Cup small Waws.'
Another said:
'So he came with it like the sun, its bubbles mimic ... The stars of Pleiades in the glass for us in beauty.'
Abu Nuwas said (Munsarih Meter):
'It plays the play of the mirage in the cup of the ... People when its bubbles connect.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a cup eyes are veiled from ... So there is no way for a looker into it.'
'As if a white cloud between me ... And the wind, lightnings pierce it.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Pure, if you extracted its power ... It led to your intellect joy.'
'And as if in it from its grasshoppers ... Is a horse, if you calmed him he bolted.'
And he took from the saying of Hassan in his poem:

'With a glass that danced with what was inside it ... The dance of the young she-camel with a hurried rider.'
Another said:
'A light descended from the mouth of the pitcher ... In the scent of camphor and color of perfume.'
'So as if it, while its sparks are flying ... And water extinguishes it, is the flame of a fire.'
Ibn Abi Awn al-Katib said:
'And for the sun in the guarantee of ages is a deposit ... Taking the place of the sun if the sun sets.'
'The depositors verify it so it appeared ... So nothing remained of it but the sense or the insertion.'
'And it has no limit that languages encompass its description ... Nor a body that touch touches.'
'The hand of the mixture plays with it out of love ... For it and so that intimacy runs between them.'
'So it foams out of pride at it as if it is ... A precious one of a boudoir whom touch confused.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Then when they mixed it ... It leaped the leap of locusts.'
'Then when they drank it ... It took the taking of sleep.'
Similar is his saying:
'And it has a creeping in the bones as if it is ... The grip of drowsiness and its taking of the joint.'
'Their palms were fragrant with it so as if ... They snatch with it a necklace of clove.'
Similar to it for him:
'So it sent from the mouth of the pitcher a pure one ... Like the tongue, it ran and the body held back.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And a cup like the honeyed wishes I drank ... But it glorified and drank my mind.'
'If blamed with water, its excuse was ... A flame like the falling of fire in thick wood.'
'If the hand attained it with a wrong, it became dignified ... Upon its grudge then took revenge on the man.'
Dik al-Jinn said:
'And rise you, so urge our cup not humiliated ... And do not give cooked drink, and give its wine.'
'So he rose, the cup almost dyes his palm ... And you think he borrowed it from his cheeks.'
'Rose-colored in the hand of a gazelle as if he ... Took it from his cheek and circulated it.'
'So we remained shaking its spirit with our hands ... And the wine takes its revenge from our feet.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz took his saying: 'As if he ... Took it from his cheek and circulated it', and added to it, saying:
'The cup circulates upon us from the hand of a fawn ... Who has a glance of an eye complaining of sickness, exhausted.'
'As if the first juice of wine is from the water of his cheek ... And its bunch is picked from his curly hair.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And a coffee whose star shines ... Musk and ambergris diffuse from it.'
'Rosy, a fawn urges it ... As if it is squeezed from his cheek.'
'Slender, he has not smiled laughing ... Since he was, except the jewel scattered.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a fire we ignited quickly at dawn ... Whenever water is spilled on it, it ignites.'
'The bubbles of water roam in its sides ... As a tear roamed on a rosy cheek.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'So when the water topped it, it clothed it ... With freckles resembling the bells of the partridge.'
'Until when its sides settled ... It wrote with the like of the legs of ants.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if in its cup while the water knocks it ... Are legs of ants or the engraving of rings.'
He said (Munsarih Meter):
'Water has in it a wondrous writing ... Like an engraving in the stone of a ruby.'
Muslim said:
'If the cupbearer touched it, it lent his fingertips ... Robes like saffron, yellow of its color.'
'A dust-colored hollow one kneeled upon it ... So she became a heart for him and he became a chest for her.'
'She refused that the jar attain the touch of her skin ... So the foaming wove for her a curtain without her.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'Lo, perhaps a cup whose first juice was given to me by ... A slender-bending, clear-mouthed, lustrous-toothed one.'
'If his fingertips took from its languor ... You saw the silver going with the wine.'
'As if in his eyes, the one who came carrying ... With his palms from its vessel when he frowns.'
He has:
'She shook hands in our farewell so she showed us ... Gold from her dye in silver.'
Abu al-Shis said:
'A gazelle gave me drink of it while the night had grayed its head ... Dyed with the henna of the glass.'
He also has (Mutaqarib Meter):
'A fawn circulates upon us with it ... His hands are dyed from the cup.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'A north wind (wine), if mixed you say a cornelian ... Bargaining competed in it among merchants.'
'As if the remains of what was effaced of its bubbles ... Are scattered gray hairs in the blackness of a sideburn.'
'A hand gives it to you as if its fingertips ... When the eye intercepts them are a row of orbital stars.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said (Munsarih Meter):
'So drink a wine as if it is a firebrand ... Time has cast its gold dust so it cleared.'

'The veil of the pitcher is moist from its blood ... As if it is bleeding from the nose while it did not bleed.'
Abu al-Shis said:
'From every trembling-locked, red one ... Kisra is his father and his mother is Bilqis.'
'He strives with a pitcher as if its strainer ... From its light is dipped in safflower.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And beloved of manners, military ... He has killing but he has no weapon.'
'As if the cup in his hand is a bride ... She has a sash of wet pearls.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'You see its cup at mixing as if you ... Scattered upon it the jewelry of a bride's head.'
'So it tears the curtains of conscience from the vitals ... And reveals from secrets every imprisonment.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'Abu al-Ghawth gave me drink and did not limit ... At the two camps a drink of stealth.'
'Of a wine you imagine it while it is a star ... In the darkness of night or the saliva of a sun.'
'It was emptied into the vessel from every heart ... So it is beloved to every soul.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Alert your boon companion, he has breathed ... He gives you a cup in the darkness.'
'Pure, as if its ray ... From the hand of its drinker is a firebrand.'
'It leaves the youth as if ... In his tongue from it is dumbness.'
'He is called so he raises his head ... So when he rises with it, he lowers it.'
Similar is the saying of Abu al-Hindi:
'I gave Abu al-Mutarrah drink when he came to me ... While the possessor of earrings was erect, shouting.'
'A drink flies flee from ... And the eloquent one lisps when he drinks it.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'It came to you from the house of a vintner with its clay ... Yellow like the ray of the sun, glowing.'
'So he snatched it from the mouth of the pitcher so it gushed ... Like the tongue, it ran and the body held back.'
Al-Akhtal said:
'I disputed with them the goodness of the North wind wine while ... The rooster had crowed and the time of the night traveler's fall came.'
'When they brought it with a lamp and their strainer ... It rose to them the rising of the trained vein (Abjal).' 
From good metaphor is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz (Munsarih Meter):
'Stand, give it to me, the first juice of what is pressed ... Polished in the covers of jewel.'
'She inhabited the jar in a safflower-dyed one ... And was brought out in a yellow straw-covered one.'
Al-Najim said:
'She was squeezed so she cast a jet-black suit ... Off her and dragged tails for the cornelian.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Munsarih Meter):
'And pearl of color in the cheeks of the boon companions ... While she is yellow in the cheeks of the cups.'
And for Ibn al-Rumi:
'She is Wars in the eggs of cups, but if she appeared ... To your eyes in the eggs of faces, then dragon's blood.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'You become by the face of wine and the bird of happiness ... A bay (Kumayt), and after mixing in the likeness of the rose.'
Al-Najim said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Circulate, O Salamah, the cup of wine ... And resemble with your singing the cooing of the turtledove.'
'And take it diluted, a coffee ... Pouring upon the night the garment of the day.'
'The cheek robs it of its redness (Jiryal) ... And gifts it to the eye on the day of hangover.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a slain one of intoxication lived for me if I called him ... To me responding, he might see his error as rectitude.'
'So he stood with remains of his hangover in his palms ... And his eyes from his cheeks had gathered roses.'
Al-Asha said:
'And a noble one of what Babylon ages ... Like the blood of the slaughtered, I robbed it of its redness.'
The narrators interpret this verse saying: I drank it red and urinated it white. Abu Nuwas was asked about it, he said: The meaning in it is like his saying:
'A cup, if it descends into the throat of its drinker ... Showed you its redness in the eye and the cheek.'
Chapter 35 On Wine Vessels
From the similes in wine vessels is the saying of Alqama bin Abdah:
'As if their pitcher is a gazelle on a height ... Covered (Mufaddam) with the Saba of linen, veiled.'
'Al-Fidam' and 'Al-Litham' are one, which is what you tied on the mouth of the pitcher or the mouth of a human. From that it is said a man is 'Fadm' as if there is a cover on his mouth. And 'Malthum' with a veil. Their pitchers in old times had legs, so they likened them to gazelles for the length of their necks and legs.
Another said:
'O Lord of a gathering of youths I drank with ... From Abd Shams in the peaks of the heights.'
'And as if their pitcher from its beauty ... Is a gazelle on a height in front of gazelles.'
Abu al-Hindi said regarding vessels:
'Covered with silk as if their necks ... Are necks of water daughters (birds) terrified by thunder.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And as if the pitcher of wine among them ... Is a gazelle on a height, overlooking, mad with love.'
'When the cupbearers urged him, he knelt to them ... So he wept over the cup of the boon companion and laughed.'
Ishaq al-Mawsili said:
'As if the pitchers of wine among them ... Are gazelles at the top of the two Raqmas, standing.'

'And they drank until as if their necks ... From softness, no bones were created for them.'
Abu Nuwas said similar to that:
'Riders gave each other drink on the saddles among them ... The cup of slumber, and the giver and receiver became intoxicated.'
'As if their heads ... While sleep places them on the shoulders, were not straightened by necks.'
Included in this chapter of good simile is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi describing a cup he gifted to Ali bin Yahya in verses some connected to others:
'And a wonder of wonders captivating ... Every mind and pleasing every eye.'
'It became fine in beauty and saltiness until ... No describer fulfills its right of description.'
'Like air without dust mixed ... With light, how thin that is and how pure.'
'Middle of size, not too big for a gulp ... Continuous, nor too small for a sip.'
'Not hasty upon minds, ignorant ... But forbearing from them without weakness.'
'The onlookers did not see in figure and form ... A horseman like it on the back of a palm.'
'In it is a scorpion color bent by ... The wise smiths the best bending.'
'Like the bending of sideburns on cheeks ... Of a gazelle proud of a mouth and a glance.'
He said regarding a cup in which he saw black wine:
'Ahmad gave me a second drink of Dushab (syrup) ... A drink that disturbed the blackness of youth.'
'You do not see me while the cup of Dushab is in my hand ... But you saw a falcon and a crow.'
Al-Buhturi said similar to that (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So a wine came, sour to him ... Hard on the desolate liver.'
'If its blackness is poured in the vessel ... Then the cup of the boon companion is an inkwell with it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'My brother, turn the cup of wine away from me, for no wine ... You exchanged for it black, pitch-dark, bitter.'
'As if in the hands of its drinkers when they got intoxicated ... Are inkwells of paper-makers filled with ink.'
From the beautiful simile is the saying of Al-Buhturi regarding a thinner vessel:
'That gift came to us and the wine ... Is of the best you volunteered to gift.'
'It wore the blueness of glass so it came ... Gold appearing in lapis lazuli.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'He went early with it yellow, Karkhi ... As if it burns in its cup.'
'So you think the water glass flowing ... And you think the cups water frozen.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And as if its joy and the joy of its cup ... Are fire and light restricted in a vessel.'
'Or a white virgin pearl covered ... A mountain upon a red ruby.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Who is for me despite the envier with a coffee ... Virgin, foster daughter of a tavern, virgin.'
'A wave of melted gold enclosed by ... A cup like the shell of the white pearl.'
This is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'So the wine is a ruby and the cup a pearl ... From the hand of a maid slender of figure.'
Chapter 36 On Narcissus
From the good said regarding narcissus is what Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
'A narcissus, its glance noticed me ... Resembling a dinar on a dirham.'
Ubaydullah bin Abdullah said regarding it (Munsarih Meter):
'It gazes with its eyes at you as ... The gazelles gaze when they fear.'
'Like rubies strung upon ... Emerald, above them is camphor.'
'As if they, while eyes watch them ... Are dirhams in the middle of which are dinars.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'I have narcissus, fresh of picking, as if it ... When we grant it eyes, is eyes.'
'Different in their form, for yellowness ... Is in place of blackness, and the whiteness is eyelids.'
He said, mentioning the cause that it is like an eye that does not blink, so the simile became complete:
'As if the narcissus mimics for us ... The eye of a lover always looking.'
'It does not blink ever out of its pity ... Fearing a look that falls short.'
Another said:
'And as if the eyes in the fresh narcissus ... Are eyes entrusted with sleeplessness.'
Ibn al-Rumi said preferring narcissus over rose:
'The cheeks of the rose blushed from preferring it ... Blushing, its ruddiness is a witness against it.'
'The rose, ruddy of color, did not blush ... Except that a stubborn opponent attributed virtue to it.'
'To the narcissus belongs the clear virtue, even if ... A refuser refused and a deviator deviated from the path.'
'The decision of the case is that this is leading ... The flowers of spring and that this is driving away.'
'Difference between two: This is threatening ... With the stripping of the world and this is promising.'
'And if you preserved it, you enjoyed a companion ... With its life, if a living one were immortal.'
'It forbids the boon companion from the ugly with a glance ... And is a helper upon wine and listening.'
'Seek with your mind among the beautiful ones its namesake ... One day, for you will inevitably find it.'

'While the rose, if you searched individually for its name ... There is not among the beautiful ones a single namesake for it.'
'These stars are the ones that raised them both ... With the rain of clouds as the parent raises.'
'So look at the two brothers, whoever of them is closer ... In resemblance to his parent, then that is the noble one.'
'Where are cheeks compared to eyes in preciousness ... and leadership, were it not for corrupt analogy?'
Al-Nashi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'The most specific qualities which ... It attained from close.'
'Eyes without faces ... Having pupils of gold.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the eyes of the fresh narcissus between us ... Are oil containers of pearls, between them is cornelian.'
'If the rain wet them, you thought their tears ... The weeping of eyes whose kohl is perfume (Khaluq).'
Ibn al-Rumi said asking for wine:
'Catch your trusted ones, for they have fallen ... Into narcissus with whom is the daughter of the grape.'
'For they are in a state, if you saw it ... You would glorify (God) out of wonder and joy.'
'Their basil is gold on pearls ... And their drink is pearls on gold.'
'O narcissus of the world, stay forever ... For suggestion and the circling of toasts.'
'Refined eyes, if they represented them ... Pearls of eyelids, peridot of stalks.'
Zubayr bin Bakkar recited to us:
'Suns and moons of flowers rising ... For the possessor of amusement in its sides, enjoyable.'
'Intoxicated, the winds bend them so they bend ... And some kiss some then return.'
'As if upon them from the flow of their dew ... Are pearls, except that they are brighter.'
'And the East wind rolls them down from it so as if they are ... Tears shed by separation, and separation hurts.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said in a poem of his describing all flowers:
'Do you not see the garden how it blossomed ... And spread the unrolled yellow cloak?'
'And the rose laughed at the anemones ... And embraced the branch, the embrace of a lover.'
'In a meadow like the suits of the bride ... And Khurram like the head of the peacock.'
'And jasmine in the peaks of branches ... Organized like pieces of pure gold.'
'And the cypress like rods of peridot ... Has drawn water from moist soil.'
'Upon meadows and rich soil ... And a stream like the polished file.'
'And the poppy hatched at a time and opened ... As if it is Korans with white pages.'
'Or like cups of crystal ... You imagine them embodied of light.'
'You see it after the spreading of the rose ... Like maces in the hands of the soldiers.'
'And the Azad lily, spread of robes ... Like cotton touched by some moisture.'
'And the fruits of coriander appeared in it ... As if they are skulls of ambergris.'
'And the ring of ox-eye (Bahir) around the myrtle ... A skull like the head of the deacon.'
'And pomegranate blossom like the redness of the rose ... Or like the combs of the roosters of India.'
'And chamomile like bright front teeth ... Their flowers were separated by the rain.'
From the good simile in it regarding blaming winter:
'And I forgot the sparks of the stove ... As if it is scattering of jasmine.'
'And it left the carpet after extinguishing ... Having black dots like the skin of the leopard.'
Likening ox-eye to the deacon's head is taken from the saying of Ibn al-Rumi describing a meadow:
'And a virgin meadow not spinster ... Every thundering sky was generous to it.'
'As if tongues are licking from it ... In it are suns of ox-eye, yellow.'
'As if they are skulls of deacons ... Its flower pleases you, bowing.'
'With a wakeful eye and a sleepy neck ... The pearl of dew is a horseman upon it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O how often I disputed with it ... The spirit of pure jars.'
'In a meadow as if it is ... The skin of a naked sky.'
Al-Ukhaytil al-Wasiti said:
'Watering for a land, if I sleep, it wakes me ... After calm in it, the knocking of bells.'
'As if its lily in every overlooking one ... Upon the fields are tails of peacocks.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I stayed in a distraction, best day and playground ... The cup circulates upon us among radiant youths.'
'I have fresh narcissus and cypress as if it is ... Figures of maids leaning in green waist-wrappers.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said mentioning a meadow:
'Surrounded by cypress like songstresses wearing ... Green silk on a moderate stature.'
'So as if they, while the wind struts between them ... Intend embracing then shyness prevents them.'
He has:
'And you see the branches when winds breathe ... Wrapped like the embracing of loved ones.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And meadows the earth struts in them ... The strutting of the girl in burdas.'

'Possessing embroidery which wall-surrounding clouds took upon themselves ... Intelligent, weaving it, and morning clouds.'
'She thanked the grace of the following rain upon the ... First rain, then the rain after the rain.'
'She praises the sky a praise ... Good of scent, spreading in the lands.'
'From a breeze as if its night travel in the ... Souls is the travel of souls in bodies.'
'An amazing sight, the greeting of a mate ... Its scent is the scent of the goodness of children.'
'Pigeons of winter call in it ... Like weeping women and like singing songstresses.'
Another said:
'To the meadow which the downpours of ... Clouds made laugh by weeping.'
'As if the anemones in it ... Are clothes soaked in blood.'
Al-Ukhaytil said:
'These anemones, I saw their redness ... Overlooking on their humble stalks.'
'As if they are a tear that wiped kohl ... Dust overflowed with it on the two cheeks of a shy one.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'So a clever cupbearer went around with a strainer ... Like the dagger of a rogue whose craft is killing.'
'And he carried a calendula above his ear ... Like a cup of cornelian in whose bottom is musk.'
Another said regarding the violet:
'And as if the fresh violet imitates ... The trace of slapping on the cheeks of the soft women.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said:
'Traces as if their meadows ... Are clothed in the banners of silk cloaks.'
'And as if their pools ... In them are tens in Korans.'
'And as if their flowers ... Shake with the stormy wind.'
'Fringes of maidservants meeting ... In them to fringes of maidservants.'
'Their night clouds spent the night ... Churning in their thundering, breaking ones.'
'And as if the flash of their lightnings ... In the air are swords of fencers.'
'Then they poured heavily like a ... Weeping woman with four shedding (eyes).' 
Al-Buhturi said:
'The free spring came to you strutting, laughing ... From beauty until it almost spoke.'
'And Nayruz has awakened in the darkness of the night ... Early roses that were yesterday asleep.'
'The coldness of dew opens it so as if it ... Spreads a talk that was before concealed.'
'And from trees the spring returned its clothing ... Upon it as you spread an embellished brocade.'
'It became lawful so it showed to the eyes a cheerfulness ... And it was a speck to the eye when it was forbidden.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The world became pleasing to who looked ... With a sight in which is clearing for the vision.'
'Oh for it as a favor, it has thanked ... It praised Allah for the blessings, the rain.'
'For the earth is in a meadow like the stripes of the Hibarah ... Adorned itself after modesty and shyness.'
'The adornment of the female addressing the male.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding a meadow:
'The face of the soil revealed to us a sight ... Like the bound cloth or like embroidery or like jewels.'
'Of white and yellow and red ... And a new one whose eyelids did not look.'
'The eye thinks it a mouth that did not open ... And opening, it almost did but did not blossom.'
'As if it is smiling, not showing teeth ... And the tears of pools did not become muddy.'
'As if they are dirhams in a spreading place ... Or like the tens of the spread Koran.'
'In it the dew is stopped, not dripping ... Like a confused tear in an eye socket.'
Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said, and some attribute these verses to Khalid al-Katib:
'My eye saw from him two sights as it saw ... Of the sun and the illuminating moon on the earth.'
'The evening he greeted me with a rose as if it were ... Cheeks added some to some.'
'And he disputed with me a cup as if its saliva ... Is my tears when sleep was blocked from my eye.'
'And he turned away, and the action of intoxication in his movements ... From the wine is the action of wind on the tender branch.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said:
'The rose did not miss a thing of you ... Goodness and beauty and no boredom.'
'It stayed until when we became intimate ... With its proximity, it hastened to move.'
Chapter 37 On Waters and Streams
From the beautiful simile in waters, streams, and pools is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'More delicious than the aged of Al-Rasatun ... And my coffee of Qutrabbul and Karin.'
'A gurgling from water of a night of Tishrin ... Like the luster of the sharpened Yemeni sword.'
Dhu al-Rumma said in similar:
'And the light of morning did not split until appeared ... Streams like cutting swords.'
Another said regarding water of strong flow:
'As if he who witnesses it loses it ... So it is a cure for the thirsty from what pains him.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'No dwelling is like the dwelling of Al-Duwayrah ... O house, may a downpour be generous to you and water you.'
'And as if a coat of mail poured from silver ... Is the water of the pool, your East wind ran upon it.'
Another said:
'Oh would that I knew, will I see the side of Al-Hima ... While its stream bed has grown its herbs, curly?'
'And will I ever come to water of a hollow ... As if the East wind tied a cloak on its surface?'
Muslim, Victim of the Songstresses, said:
'And water like the eye of the sun, not accepting speck ... If the East wind crept in it, you thought it rising.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And water like the horizon of morning, pure its main part ... I pushed the sandgrouse from it and lightened a chest.'
'If the wind deemed it ignorant, its speck roamed ... And stripped from its sheaths so it flowed.'
'So when they arrived at the water and its purity slipped out ... As the hands of polishers sheathed a blade.'
He also has:
'I remained at it given the first juice of coffee to drink ... By the hand of a gazelle with hunting eyelids.'
'On a stream, quenched, not concealing the speck ... As if its channels are the surfaces of files.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'On the sides of a filled stream ... White like the spread parchment.'
'Or like the surface of the famous blade ... Gliding like the terrified snake.'
Al-Ta'i recited:
'Read peace to the trickling water and say to it ... All drinking places since you were abandoned are blameworthy.'
'Watering for your shade in the evening and forenoon ... And for the coldness of your water, while waters are hot.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said mocking a water:
'And water, effaced of traces, empty ... Like a brain confused in a kohled eyelid.'
Another said:
'Is there to a drink in the sides of Munshid ... A way? For the water of Al-Lawahiq has worn you out.'
'It has clamors in the bellies as if they are ... If heard, the running of noble winning horses.'
'As if crushed musk was mixed with its taste ... If a taster tasted it one day on the board.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'And water far of time from people, altered ... As if locusts spit the water of the vast space into it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And empty water I knocked on in darkness ... The sandgrouse upon it, as if its altered water is oil.'
Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Yahya Tha'lab recited to us:
'And green like henna, overflowing its main part ... Distant are voices in it, cut off in the barren land.'
'I found the wolf howling at it as if he ... Is a dissolute one empty of all wealth and family.'
'So I said to him: O wolf, do you have use for a youth ... Who consoles you in the back of the mount and the saddle?'
Chapter 38 On the Description of Fire
Kuthayyir said mentioning a fire:
'I saw, and my companions were at Ayla at midnight ... While the descending Farqad star had set.'
'A fire for Azza that does not die down, as if it ... When we glanced at it from the distance is a star.'
Another said in description of a fire:
'As if the fire cuts from its light ... Gores of a jubbah of purple.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And kindlers who spent the night feeding the flame ... Satiating it with charcoal and wood.'
'Raising fires like trees of gold.'
Another said:
'And a barker seeking fire after the calm, I invited him ... With a red one like the dawn, glowing is its fuel.'
Jarran al-Awd said:
'And a fire like the magic of the oud, its light is raised ... With the morning by the gusts of shaking winds.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Over a fire satiated with thick wood ... When it blazed, it threw sparks.'
'So it tops the hill like the red ... Banner, piercing the darkness to every night traveler.'
Another said regarding the conquest of Heraclea:
'As if our fires at the side of their fortress ... Are dyed cloths on short ropes.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Al-Mu'tasim burning Al-Afshin:
'The secret of disbelief did not cease between his ribs ... Until he warmed at the secret of the fire-stick emitting sparks.'
'A fire, a flame assaults his body from its heat ... As you dyed the slit of a waist-wrapper with safflower.'
'Flames flew for it, its scorching destroys ... His pillars, a destruction without dust.'
'Kindled, raised for the greatest polytheist ... What its light used not to be raised for the night traveler.'
'He prayed to it alive, and was its fuel ... Dead, and enters it with the wicked.'
Chapter 39 On the Length of the Night
From the beautiful simile in the length of the night is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
'And a night like the wave of the sea lowered its curtains ... Upon me with types of worries to test.'
'So I said to it when it stretched its spine ... And followed with buttocks and rose with a chest.'
'Lo, O night, clear yourself ... With a morning, and the morning is not better than you.'
'Oh for you of a night, as if its stars ... By every twisted rope were tied to Yadhbul.'

...And as if a coat of mail cast from silver... is the water of the pool when the breeze blows over it. Another said: I wonder, will I see the side of the sanctuary... when its waterways have grown curly herbs? And will I ever sip the water of a hollow... as if the breeze has fastened a coat of mail upon its surface? Muslim (Sari' al-Ghawani) said: And water like the eye of the sun that accepts no speck... when the breeze steps into it, you imagine it rising. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: And water like the horizon of the morning, its fullness is pure... I pushed the sandgrouse from it and lightened a burden; When the wind bullies it, its motes swirl... and it is unsheathed from its scabbards and flows like a chain/sequins; When they arrived at the water and its purity was drawn out... just as the hands of polishers sheath a blade. He also has: I remained there being served the purest wine... by the hand of a gazelle possessing hunting eyelids; By a lush stream that conceals no speck... as if its channels are the surfaces of files. Ibn al-Rumi said: On the edges of a filled stream... white like an unrolled scroll; Or like the blade of a famous sword... slithering like a frightened snake. Al-Tai recited: Convey peace to the trickling water and say to it... 'All drinking places, since I left you, are blameworthy; May there be rain for your shade in the evening and morning... and for the coolness of your water, for [other] waters are boiling heat.' Ibn al-Mu'tazz said mocking water: And water with effaced traces, empty... like hot tear-fluid in an eye adorned with kohl. Another said: Is there a way to a drink at the sides of Munshid... for the water of the followers has tested you; It has clamor in the bellies, as if it is... when heard, the running of noble racing horses; As if crushed musk were mixed with its taste... when a taster tastes it one day upon a board. Dhu al-Rummah said: And water whose time with people is distant, stagnant... as if the locusts of the open desert spit into it. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: And empty water that I came to at dusk... upon it were sandgrouse, as if its stagnant content were oil. Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Yahya Tha'lab recited to us: And green [water] like henna, its fullness overflowing... sounds are distant within it, cut off by the drought; I found a wolf howling at it as if he were... an outcast, empty of all wealth and family; So I said to him, 'O Wolf, would you like a young man... who will share with you the back of the mount and the saddle?' Chapter 38: On the Description of Fire. Kuthayyir said, mentioning a fire: I saw, while my companions were at Ayla at midnight... and the star of the Farqad had set; A fire for Azzah that does not die down, as if it were... when we glanced at it from afar, a planet. Another said in the description of fire: As if the fire cuts from its brilliance... the gores of a jubbah made of purple. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: And kindled fires that spent the night igniting the flame... feeding it full with charcoal and wood; Raising fires like trees of gold. Another said: And one barking [seeking hospitality] after the calm, I invited him... with a blond [fire] like the dawn, its fuel glowing. Jarran al-Oud said: And a fire like the dawn of the wood, its light raised... with the morning by the gusts of violent winds. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: Over a fire satiated with thick wood... when it blazed, it threw sparks; So it tops the hill like a red banner... ripping the darkness for every night traveler. Another said regarding the conquest of Heraclea: As if our fires beside their citadel were... dyed cloths upon the ropes of bleachers. Al-Tai said regarding Al-Mu'tasim's burning of Afshin: The secret of disbelief remained between his ribs... until he burned in the secret of the glowing fire-stick; A fire whose heat assaults his body... a flame as if you had dyed the slit of a garment with safflower; Sparks flew from it, its scorching heat demolishing... his pillars, a demolition without dust; Kindled, it was raised for the greatest polytheist... its light was not raised for the night traveler; He prayed to it while alive, and was its fuel... when dead, and he enters it with the wicked. Chapter 39: On the Length of the Night. Among the beautiful similes regarding the length of the night is the saying of Imru' al-Qays: And a night like the waves of the sea lowered its curtains... upon me with all sorts of worries to test me; So I said to it when it stretched its spine... and followed with its buttocks and rose with its chest; 'O long night, will you not clear... with a morning? Yet the morning is no better than you'; Oh, what a night you are! As if its stars... were tied to Mount Yadhbul with every twisted rope.

'As if the Pleiades were hung in their place ... By ropes of flax to hard rocks.'
Al-Tirimmah said like his saying: "And the morning is not better than you." And he added to it:
'Lo, O night, become morning ... At Bamm, and the morning is not more relieving than you.'
'Although for the eyes in the morning is a rest ... By their casting their glances every cast.'
Similar is the saying of the other:
'O night, would that you were eternal forever ... There is no relief in the morning for a lover.'
Another said like his saying "by ropes of flax":
'I watch in the sky the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) ... And if I could, I would be a driver for them.'
'As if the night tied its two sides ... And its middle with strong ropes.'
Another said:
'A night prolonged, not separating from a direction ... As if it is hobbled over the face of the earth.'
'Morning did not leave my hand if I won it ... Even if a blaze and anklet appeared from it.'
Bashar said:
'O my two friends, what is the matter with the darkness, it does not leave ... And why does the pillar of morning not become clear?'
'Did the illuminating day lose its way ... Or is time a night as if it does not leave?'
'And the night prolonged upon me until as if it ... Is joined by two nights so it does not budge.'
Another said:
'As if the dark night is a blind hobbled one ... Confused in a wilderness of earth, unknown.'
'As if the darkness when it lowered its curtains ... Spends the night upon a night joined by a night.'
Ibn al-Riqa' said similar:
'And as if my night when its sun sets ... Is joined with the blackness of another like it.'
'I watch the stars, if a star sets ... I see another like the lamp roaming.'
Asram bin Humayd said:
'And a night long of two sides I crossed ... In grief while tears run pouring.'
'Its stars are weary upon it as if ... Its stars are fettered from moving.'
Another said:
'What is the matter with the stars of the night, they do not set ... As if they are pulled from behind them?'
'Stationary, nothing set in its west ... Nor did a star appear from its east.'
Al-Farazdaq mentioned the cause in the length of the night, saying:
'They say the night is long, and the night was not long ... But the one who weeps from longing stays awake.'
Bashar said:
'My night was not long, but I did not sleep ... And a phantom that visited exiled slumber from me.'
Al-Ajjaj said:
'The night prolonged for the one who did not sleep ... And the eye fevered the fever of the sick.'
Ali bin Muhammad bin Nasr bin Bassam said:
'I do not wrong the night nor claim ... That the stars of the night do not set.'
'My night is as she wished, if she was not generous ... It was long, and if she was generous, then my night is short.'
Bashar said:
'I say while my night increases in length ... Is there no day for the night after them?'
'My eye refused closing until ... As if its eyelids are short for it.'
From the beautiful speech on the length of the night, even if it has no simile, is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'Leave me to a tiring worry, O Umayma ... And a night I endure, slow of stars.'
'It hesitated until I said it is not ending ... And the one who tends the stars is not returning.'
Ibn al-Ahnaf excelled in his saying also:
'O sleepers around me, help ... Me against the night for reward and recompense.'
'Tell me a hadith about the day ... Or describe it, for I have forgotten the day.'
Sa'id bin Humayd al-Katib said:
'O night, nay O eternity ... Is tomorrow sleeping away from you?'
'O night, if you met what ... I meet in it or find.'
'You would have shortened from your length or ... Endurance would have weakened from you.'
'I complain to an unjust woman ... She complains of what she does not find.'
'Stopped upon her is my glance ... Stopped upon her is sleeplessness.'
The chapter in this is wider than we can confine in this section.
Al-Harith bin Khalid said:
'Come help me against the night, for it ... Upon every eye that does not sleep is long.'
Umar bin Shabbah mentioned that Al-Harith bin Khalid's verse is an origin in mentioning the length of the night.
Khalid al-Katib said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'You slept and did not pity the sleepless ... And the night of the lover is without end.'
'And you did not know after the departure of slum... ber what tears did to my eye.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Many a night as if it is Time in length ... Has reached the limit so there is no increase in it.'
'Having stars as if they are stars of ... Gray hair, not disappearing but increasing.'
Chapter 40 On the Palpitation of the Heart
