Another said regarding black women:
'Resembling youth and musk, I ransom ... Them with my soul from death and calamities.'
'How can the intelligent youth love the union of the ... White women, while white women resemble gray hair?'
Abu Hafs al-Shatranji said:
'Musk resembled you and she resembled it ... Standing in its color, sitting.'
'No doubt since your color is one ... That you are from one clay.'
Another said:
'I love black women for the sake of Tuktam ... And for her sake I loved whoever was black.'
'So bring me the like of musk better in scent ... And bring me the like of night better as a bed.'
Another said:
'And a faulter of the dark-skinned out of his ignorance ... Preferring the white women in argument.'
'O lowest of lovers, are you not ashamed ... To make camphor like musk?'
Abu Ali al-Basir said:

'The transformation of color did not disgrace her in my view ... It is a dye like the color of youth.'
A Bedouin said (Munsarih Meter):
'From her skin is her boot and her veil ... A Houri in other than the creation of Houris.'
Bashar said, although there is no simile in it, regarding a black woman:
'The mole is in a pure cheek ... So it earns it saltiness and beauty.'
'And pleases it to the eyes of its onlookers ... So how about if you saw the color as a mole?'
Chapter 47 On Embracing
From the simile in embracing is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'That is Ni'am, if she favored with a union ... We would have thanked in the union the favor of Ni'am.'
'She forgot the standing of the pebbles and our persons ... Are like a person, I threw the pebbles and she throws.'
Bakr bin Kharijah said:
'I saw your person in my sleep embracing me ... As the Lam of the writer embraces the Alif.'
Al-Buhturi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And I did not forget our night in embracing ... The East wind wrapped a branch with a branch.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if I embraced a basil ... Breathing in its cold night.'
'If you saw us in the shirt of darkness ... You would have thought us in one body.'
Ali bin al-Jahm excelled in his saying:
'May Allah water a night that joined us after a slumber ... And brought a heart close to a tortured heart.'
'So we spent the night together, if a glass ... Of wine were spilled between us, it would not leak.'
Bashar said, and Ibn al-Jahm took it from him:
'I was alone with her, water does not pass between us ... Until the morning, without me is a doorkeeper and curtains.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Long did leg wrap around leg for us until the morning ... In a veil of kissing ... And a waist-wrapper of embracing.'
Chapter 48 On the Taylasan (Shawl)
Al-Hamdawi said (Munsarih Meter):
'He comes to you in a torn jubbah ... The longest lifespans of its like is a day.'
'And a Taylasan like the mirage he wears ... Over a shirt as if it is a cloud.'
He has regarding the Taylasan of Ibn Harb good similes, among them:
'Indeed Ibn Harb was generous to me, clothing ... With a decrepit, old Taylasan.'
'Look at the abundance of its tearing ... As if it was torn in a funeral.'
'He threw it to him while it is rotten like one who ... Builds a building over a demolished one.'
'The glance splits it with its flashing ... The splitting of the heart of the infatuated lover.'
'Its abundance of tearing reminds me ... Of the scattering of people from the Season (Hajj).'
He also has:
'And a Taylasan, if you contemplated it ... You cut it by length and width.'
'As if my pity for it when ... I went early is my pity for my honor.'
'If it were some of the sons of Adam ... It would have been the prisoner of Allah on earth.'
By some Andalusians:
'Your servant Al-Warraq since he per... sisted does not take anything.'
'And upon him is a Taylasan ... Which Time has folded a folding.'
'Whenever he patched a star (hole) ... The Pleiades rose in it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding it:
'O Ibn Harb, you clothed me a Taylasan ... Darning is planted in it while it is salt marshes.'
'Cracks fly in length and width ... In it until as if they are rooks (chess).'
Al-Hamdawi said:
'And a Taylasan, if you contemplated it ... Persisted in tearing in obstinacy.'
'As if it, from the length of my darning it ... Owns me since it became in my ownership.'
He also has:
'O Ibn Harb, you prolonged my poverty by my darning ... A Taylasan you were rich from.'
'So it is in darning the family of Pharaoh in expo... sure to the Fire morning and evening.'
He also has:
'And a decrepit Taylasan, protected ... Against it is eating vinegar and herbs.'
'As if my ankles when they joined ... Upon it were, for fear of wind, in shackles.'
Ibn al-Rumi said in this meaning:
'And I have a thin Taylasan except that it ... Is firm to the gusts of shaking winds.'
'And that is only because it is torn ... Leaving the way for the wind without dispute.'
'I see it like the light of the sun by eye vision ... And it prevents me from touching it with fingers.'
'It complained of the heaviness of the name Taylasan for its weakness ... So I named it San (Law/Tongue?), so does that benefit me?'
Al-Hamduni said:
'A Taylasan that ceased not to be older in time ... Than Time, its darner has no trick.'
'And you see its weakness like the weakness of an old woman ... Of shabby condition, possessing poverty, supporting family.'
'Patches flooded it so it is like a city (Misr) ... Inhabited by strangers of every tribe.'
He has (Munsarih Meter):
'Say to Ibn Harb the saying of the blamer ... And I am not a liar in what I say.'
'Did you not see the darner trying me ... With his darning your gone Taylasan.'
'The generosity of decay annihilated it upon him as ... Passion annihilated the heart of Khalid al-Katib.'
Chapter 49

The slave of Banu al-Has-has looked at a woman laughing at him while he was being taken to be killed, so he said:
'If you laugh at me, then oh many a night ... I left you in it like the slit Qaba' (outer garment).'
A woman came to Al-Mughira bin Shu'bah with her husband seeking help against him and mentioning he is impotent. He said:
'Allah knows, O Mughira, that I ... Have trodden her the treading of the released stallion.'
'And took her the taking of the butcher his sheep ... Hurrying, slaughtering it for guests descending.'
Al-Mughira said: Indeed I see that in your characteristics. Similar to it is the saying of Al-Buhturi (Munsarih Meter):
'She did not step out the door of the hallway going out ... Except her anklet was with the earring.'
Abu Nuwas said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Be gentle a little, you have hurt me ... And joined my earring to his anklets.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding a songstress:
'O Ahmad bin Sa'id, if you saw her ... When palms are anklets for her legs.'
For Abu Nuwas:
'And a fawn, they do not weary of his proximity ... They have joined his earrings and his heels.'
Chapter 50
Al-Buhturi said regarding Ibrahim bin al-Mudabbir:
'You came near in humility and became far in rank ... So your two matters are lowness and elevation.'
'Thus the sun is far from being rivaled ... And the light and ray come near from it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And I saved him for time, I know that he ... Is like the fortress in it for whom there is a return.'
'And I saw him like the sun, if it is not attained ... Then its light and kindness are attained from it.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said:
'I fear and am shy and watch his promise ... Neither he starts with me nor I ask.'
'He is the sun, its course is far and its light ... Is near, and my heart is entrusted with the far.'
Another said:
'And indeed I and she and her visit to us ... Are like the sun, it reached us and we do not reach it.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'I saw you like the lightning, it is thought that it ... Is near, while the nearest of its rain is far from you.'
Shabib bin al-Barsa' said:
'And she was like lightning the eye watched its light ... And did not know after the watching where it pours.'
Chapter 51 On Fear and Confusion
Al-Tirimmah said:
'It increased me in love for myself that I ... Am hateful to every man of no benefit.'
'When he sees me he cuts the glance between him ... And me, the action of the knowing feigning ignorance.'
'I filled the earth against him until as if it ... From tightness in his eyes is the net of a hunter.'
The other said:
'As if the lands of Allah, while wide ... Upon the frightened terrified one, are the net of a hunter.'
The other said:
'It is conveyed to him that every hill ... He intends throws a killer at him.'
'As if the lands of Allah, while wide ... Upon everyone you sought, are the net of a hunter.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding a prisoner:
'He overlooked him so he remained out of confusion seeing ... The land as sea and the open space as narrow.'
'And he crossed the Tigris wading and as if it ... Is a cup spilled at the door of Al-Kahil.'
'Were it not for the agitation of fear in his vitals ... The flood would have sunk with him so he died drowned.'
Chapter 52
Dhu al-Rumma said mocking a man claiming lineage:
'If he were from Kalb, a pure core, I would have mocked him ... But I was informed he is not from Kalb.'
'But I was informed that he is stuck on ... As the crack of the cup is stuck [patched] from other than it.'
Abu Nuwas said mocking Ashja':
'He went out and his talk regarding it ... Is for one who wonders, a wonder.'
'To names which Ashja' names ... When he traces lineage.'
'He knows them and his brothers ... So all of them are defenders of it.'
'They have in their house a lineage ... And in the middle of the assembly a lineage.'
'As an unveiled woman is not hidden ... And she is hidden when she veils.'
He has:
'O claimer of Sulayma foolishly ... You are not of her, not even a fingernail clipping.'
'You are only stuck on like a Waw ... Stuck in the spelling unjustly to Amr.'
Hassan said:
'And you are a bastard added to the family of Hashim ... As the single cup is tied behind the rider.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And moving from a group into a group ... So as if your mother or your father is mercury.'
Chapter 53 On Generosity and Munificence
Abu Tammam al-Ta'i recited to us:
'So eat it beside the table if a ... Strong wind came early cutting the firm tent ropes.'
'And the father of orphans, they grow at his door ... The growth of chicks in a fertile shelter.'
Similar is the saying of Bashar:
'The birds fall where the grain scatters ... And the houses of the generous are covered.'
Al-Jahiz recited:
'People crowd at his door ... And the sweet watering place is crowded.'
Al-Ta'i said mourning Khalid bin Yazid (Mutaqarib Meter):

'And when the flag of his assembly is a watering place ... Fresh for those thirsty minds.'
'And his visitors for gifts are present ... As if their presence is for giving.'
For Abu Nuwas:
'You see people in groups to the door of his house ... As if they are legs of crawling locusts and locusts.'
Di'bil said regarding a man appointed over Sindh:
'And this sea used not to be crossed ... Except by one fearful of his sin or risking.'
'So he became for one who frequents your generosity, populated ... As if upon him are firm bridges.'
Chapter 54 On the Wind
Ibn al-Rumi said describing a wind:
'And a North wind cold of breeze ... Twisted upon the worried one with worries.'
'And breathed on him the breath of the worried ... Walking in the night with gossip.'
'Between the breeze of the earth and the nose.'
Similar is his saying regarding a wind:
'As if its breeze is the fragrance of lavender ... A succeeding rain followed it after the first rain.'
'A gift of a North wind blew at night ... For the branches of boughs, having a secret conversation with it.'
'If its breaths breezed early ... The empty hearted breathed for it like the sad one.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O many a night all of it is magic (dawn-time) ... Exposed of the full moon, sick of breeze.'
'The breaths pick up the cold of dew ... In it, so they gift it to the heat of worries.'
'I did not know the morning from its night ... For it did not appear except in the face of the boon companion.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'Dew anchored in your club and the winds ... Breathed a breath in your courtyard, weak.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'A North wind greeted you from us, its phantom circled ... A garden, so it exploded spirit and basil.'
'It blew early so the branch whispered to its companion ... Secretly with it, and the birds called out openly.'
'Doves singing on green drooping branches ... Rising with it and touching the earth at times.'
'You imagine its bird intoxicated from joy ... And the branch from his shaking his sides intoxicated.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'As if the wind and the rain whispering ... Their thoughts are blame and apology.'
'As if the circle of the Tigris when it came ... In its entirety is a crescent or a bracelet.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said in similar:
'The winds moved it so the plants moderated ... And its tall ones leaned with the short.'
'Seeking refuge some with some like people ... In repeated blame and apology.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said:
'And as if its flowers ... Shake with the stormy wind.'
'Fringes of maidservants meeting ... In it to fringes of maidservants.'
Chapter 55 On the Sideburn (Sudgh)
Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And a cupbearer obedient to his loved ones ... Against the watchers, strong of boldness.'
'And in the curve of the sideburn is a mole for him ... Just as the polo stick snatched the ball.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'As if the line of the sideburn in the heat of her face ... Is the remains of breaths with the finger of a creator.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'With the palm of a gazelle possessing sideburn hair and a lock ... And two sideburns (curls) like the two Qafs from the sides of a line.'
Mani said:
'The water of bliss in his cheek is saffron-dyed ... And the sideburn of him is like the curve of the Ra.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'A fawn wanders in the beauty of his image ... Languor played with the glance of his eye.'
'So as if the scorpion of his sideburn (curl) stood ... When it approached the fire of his cheek.'
He also said:
'I was afflicted with a fawn like the full moon in beauty ... Torturing me with types of coquetry.'
'The tunic of his cheek is a fresh rose ... And the Nun of the sideburn is dotted with a mole.'
Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Mawsili said (Hazaj Meter):
'Gazelles like Dinars ... Sweeping in the chambers.'
'Palm Sundays revealed them ... To us in wasp-waists.'
'And they scorpion-curled sideburns ... Like the tails of starlings.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said (Munsarih Meter):
'What is the matter with my beloved, lazy of thought ... And has shunned his beauty and decoration.'
'And the sideburn has turned away from his beauties ... Like a polo stick returning its hit.'
Chapter 56
Connected to that is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'He has an eye that shoots hearts and a cheek ... In which light opens from every side.'
'And his cheeks grew sideburn hair with two lines they straightened ... As writing marked in the parchment of a writer.'
In this meaning, even if it has no simile, is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'Growing hair around his rose gardens ... Beauty has struck upon his cheeks.'
'His cheeks, then the mole in his cheeks ... Are his Labbayk (response) coupled to his Sa'dayk (happiness).'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And a gazelle wearing a tunic ... In a Qaba', girded.'
'Allah adorned his cheek ... With a suspended sideburn hair.'
He has:
'As if his two sideburns on a moon on ... A branch on a sand dune, moist of soil, wet.'

'He smiled when I joked with him, so as if ... A veil of chrysolite was revealed from pearls.'
Similar to it for Al-Wathiq:
'When he rose with buttocks pulling him ... And his mustache turned green above the veil of pearls.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the line of sideburn hair above his cheek ... Is a field of myrtle on rose and eglantine.'
'And he drew his mustache above the veil of pearls ... With half a Sad and the Dal of the sideburn is like the Nun.'
Another said:
'He has from the eyes of wild beasts a sick eye ... And from the greenness of the garden the greenness of a mustache.'
'As if a skillful boy wrote it for him ... So it came like half of the Sad from the hand of a writer.'
Chapter 57 On the Description of Pools and Buildings
Al-Buhturi said to Al-Mu'tazz congratulating him on a building:
'When you completed deliberation and resolve ... You worked your opinion in building.'
'Pigeons were terrified while cooing above it ... From a sight dangerous to slip, frightening.'
'And as if the walls of glass in its air ... Are depths waving on the sides of coasts.'
'And as if the mosaic of marble when met ... Its composition with the opposing view.'
'Are tracks of clouds paved between tigroid ... And striped and convergent and similar.'
'May you enjoy it and live in the midst ... Of the house of your kingdom a thousand complete years.'
'And I saw Abdullah at the age which ... Counts the old man with his long time.'
'A young man, wisdom dignifies him so as if he ... Took dignity from the encompassing gray hair.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And a dome of a king as if the stars ... Listen to it with their secrets.'
'It has balconies as if the spring ... Clothed them with the novelties of its flowers.'
'So they are like morning drinkers who went out ... For the festival of Christians and their breakfast.'
'So among one binding her hair ... And one repairing the knot of her belt.'
'And a fountain, its revenge is in the sky ... So it does not fall short of its revenge.'
Al-Buhturi said describing a pool:
'O one who sees the beautiful pool, its sight ... And the friendly women when their dwellings appeared.'
'What is the matter with the Tigris like the jealous competing with it ... In beauty at times and at times boasting.'
'As if the Jinn of Solomon who undertook ... Its creation, so they were precise in its meanings.'
'So if Bilqis passed by it from the side ... She would say it is the Palace (Sarh) in representation and simile.'
'Delegations of water pour into it rushing ... Like horses coming out of the rope of their race.'
'As if white silver flowing ... From ingots runs in its channels.'
'If the East wind topped it, it showed it tracks ... Like coats of mail, polished are its edges.'
'If the stars appeared in its sides ... At night, you thought a sky was installed in it.'
'The confined fish does not reach its limit ... Due to the distance of what is between its far and near.'
'They swim in it with winged middles ... Like birds swooping in the air with their wings.'
'As if it, when it cleared in its pouring ... Is the palm of the Caliph when its valley flowed.'
Abu Awn al-Katib said (Munsarih Meter):
'A pool of amusement a king built ... Its sides continue to shine with him.'
'So the yellowness of gold dust in its sitting places ... Is to the flash of silver and alabaster.'
'Like the face of a virgin frightened by shame ... So her cheek in its whiteness is red.'
'It overflowed so it remained smiling revealing foam ... Like pearls of a necklace scattering from its string.'
'Then it flooded onto the gardens as ... The palms of Ja'far overflow with generosity.'
'As if it, when it seeks water then wa... ters the meadow from the rain of the Tigris, is more abundant.'
'Drinkers whom the vines hosted, so they are ... Sons of its grapes which are pressed.'
Ibn Abi Tahir said:
'A fountain emitting water from it ... As you melted white silver.'
'The earth rained the sky with it.'
Chapter 58 On Scarcity
Zuhair said describing a desolate land:
'And a blind desert not crossed ... Except by the courageous possessor of a guiding heart.'
'Barren, I dozed in it while not sleeping ... And the arm of the one casting the chest (camel) was my pillow.'
'And I knew it is not an abode of residence ... So like the clap with the palm was my sleep.'
Another said:
'My eye does not taste sleep from remembering you ... Except hastily like the sleep of the night-traveling bird.'
Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
'I do not taste sleep except scarcely ... Like the sipping of birds the water of small puddles.'
Another said in similar:
'And sleep like the sipping of birds we spent the night tasting ... On the wood of saddles above the she-camels.'
Al-Farazdaq said:

'They cleared from eyes that slumbered not at all (Kalla wa La) ... With the morning when the call of the rewarder called.'
Jarir said:
'And a sleeper of a desert I sent to night travel ... And sleep is sweeter to him than the harvest of bees.'
'The descending of the riders in it is not at all (Kalla wa La) ... Hasty, so they do not bring a saddle close to a saddle.'
Abu Nuwas said (Mudari' Meter):
'You left of me a little ... Less than the little.'
'Like the particle indivisible ... Less in pronunciation than La (No).'
Another said mourning his son:
'Ahmad became having a house in the soil ... And a house became empty of him from his family.'
'So as if his birth and his death ... Were a voice calling so a voice answered.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'Beware of the world, its deception ... How many a righteous one it toyed with so he became corrupt.'
'What is between its joy and its sadness ... Except as a man stood and sat.'
Hassan bin Thabit said on the death of Abdullah bin Rawaha after the death of Ja'far, may Allah be pleased with him, mourning his death (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And your delay from your two companions was ... Like the bridled horse while not saddled.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So I likened the speed of their days ... To the speed of a bow called Quzah (Rainbow).'
'It colored traversing in the sky ... So that was not complete until it vanished.'
Chapter 59
Abu Uyaynah said regarding his cousin:
'Let not Yazid count among the sons ... Khalid, for indeed Khalid is not a son.'
'And if he passes riding, people think ... Upon his back is a sack of straw.'
He has regarding him (Mutaqarib Meter):
'If he speaks in a gathering ... You see spit on the lower lip tuft.'
'It flows, and how ugly is he riding ... As if on his back is a pad.'
He has regarding him:
'The horse goes early with Khalid ... So as if he runs with a waterskin.'
'A goat bleating more than the goats ... As if his beard is a fly-whisk.'
Chapter 60 On Palm Trees
Al-Abbas said:
'I rejected in Basra the people of wealth ... Indeed I am rejecting of their likes.'
'They covered their bunches with harvest ... As if the fever of their palms is shaking.'
Al-Jahiz recited in the description of palm trees:
'It brings out at the emergence and shaking ... Spadix like the ears of white dogs.'
Abd al-Samad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said describing unripe dates:
'As if it is in the fresh branches ... Emerald appearing on crowns.'
'Until when two months were complete for it ... And the clusters of bunches hung down.'
'They excelled with ruby and coral ... I saw it different of colors.'
'Of intense red, purple ... And bright yellow like fires.'
'Like wreaths on the songstresses.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding palms:
'You imagine what they renewed of plants ... Wings not spread.'
'As if they are tails of swift camels ... Then they exchanged for vessels.'
'Guarantors for the white honey ... Like pieces of ruby, ripe.'
'Capped with pure gold.'
Umarah said describing palms:
'I set up a Lord for them for the two eras and was not ... Like one who was stingy with dirhams regarding their cultivation.'
'So they came exceeding in growth as if they are ... On the bank of a flood from the floods of the non-Arabs.'
'As if the sound of splitting of fiber in their fronds ... Is the sound of the squeaking of the Mays wood over the strong camels.'
'And the root is not what you watered its struck vein ... With water, while sleeping from fixing a branch.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'Of those drinking the water in the low ground, drinking ... With their roots before the drinking of throats.'
Another said regarding palms:
'They struck the root in the spring of a well ... They sought its fresh water until they quenched.'
'As if their branches with every wind ... Are virgins pulling each other by the locks.'
'Daughters of Time, not fearing drought ... If no grazing beast remains, we remain.'
For another:
'It comes out from its cover when it descends ... Like the appearance of the gray-haired from a worn garment.'
Al-Rabi' bin Abi al-Huqayq the Jew said:
'And palms in abundant watercourses ... Bring out the spadix like the likes of palms (hands).'
Chapter 61 On Turning Away
Al-Asha said:
'Yazid lowers the glance from me as if he ... Contracted between his eyes on the cupping glasses.'
'So let not what contracted between your eyes expand ... And do not meet me except while your nose is rubbed in dust.'
Ibn al-Abbas quoted when he saw Ziyad:
'If you saw me, you turned away from me ... As if the sun turns from my direction.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'A young woman with a face whose ugliness strikes the eye ... He has an appearance like the sun in the eyes of the ophthalmic.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said (Hazaj Meter):
'So when gray hair arrived ... With two types of arrival (roses).'

'I addressed, so she turned away a solitude ... From the pain of turning away.'
'As eyes of the ophthalmic turned away from the sun ... Hurrying.'
Another said:
'If I squinted and I have no squint ... Then broke the eye without defect.'
'You found me twisted, far of persistence ... Carrier of what I carried of good and evil.'
'Like the moving snake at the base of the stone.'
Chapter 62 On Courage and Softness of Nature
Al-Buhturi said:
'Smiling to the heroes while he is their conqueror ... And for the sword is an edge when it assaults and a luster.'
'Life and death, one is their end ... Likewise the flood of water quenches and drowns.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'It is a world like a snake spitting poi... son even if the touch softened.'
Al-Buhturi said to Abu Sa'id:
'With a magnificent one from Tayy, as if his shirt ... Is buttoned upon the two Sheikhs Zayd and Hatim.'
'Generosity and might like thunderbolts and rain ... If they gathered in a cumulus cloud.'
Ibn al-Rumi said to Abu al-Husayn (Munsarih Meter):
'You never left me from your favors the ... Bright nor from your wars the biting.'
'You dispense rain in its thunderbolts ... And at times in its pouring buckets.'
Abu al-Shis said:
'And like the sword, if you softened it, its flat softened ... And its edge, if you roughened it, is two roughs.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'If she struts, her two sides emit fragrance ... As the East wind strutted on the garden.'
'And her coquetry is beautiful while death is in it ... And the polished sword may be considered beautiful.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding songstresses:
'Of the brown supple ones if they became lank ... And the turn of death is in the brown supple ones.'
'Resembling spears, shafts of backs ... And wounding in hearts without a spearhead.'
'So is there from a strike or from a spearhead ... Like an eye or like a mouth or like a fingertip?'
Al-Surayhi said similar:
'Misery and bliss meet you from his traits ... Like fire, in its nature is burning and light.'
Chapter 63
Al-Hutay'ah said mocking his mother:
'Step aside and sit far from me ... May Allah relieve the worlds of you.'
'A sieve if you are entrusted with a secret ... And a stove upon the conversers.'
Ka'b bin Zuhair said:
'And she does not hold to the covenant she made ... Except as sieves hold water.'
Mahmud said regarding his servant:
'The most resembling of one who entrusts the secret to his slave ... Is like the thrower of sand between the sticks of a sieve.'
Another said:
'May it be hard on me for morals you were branded with ... Among creation, O Faludhaj of the market.'
'You are impatient with the secret if you are singled out with it ... Until it is seen spreading like blowing in the trumpet.'
Chapter 64 On the Lineage of the Mean
Muhammad bin Munadhir said:
'So be harsh on the lineage of the mean for indeed ... The lineage of the mean to Al-Zubayr is glass.'
Hassan bin Thabit said:
'And the trust of the Murri where I met him ... Is like the glass bottle, its crack is not mended.'
Al-Asha said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So she separated and left in the heart ... A crack upon her distance so it flew.'
'Like the crack of the glass bottle, the palm of ... The craftsman cannot make it return.'
Abu Uthman al-Najim said mocking:
'You have an honor chipped of glass ... And a face smooth of iron.'
Another said:
'And I have not seen like turning away a better sight ... If it was from one whom one does not fear regarding connection.'
'And she swore an oath like glass, thin ... And she swore only to break it for my sake.'
Another said:
'If they made me swear the Ghamus (false oath), I granted them ... An oath like the names of the torn cloak.'
'And if they made me swear by divorce, I returned her ... To the best of what she was as if she was not divorced.'
'And if they made me swear by manumission, then ... The mean one of my slave knew he is not freed.'
In the thinness of the oath, from beautiful simile is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'They asked me for the oath, so I was terrified of them ... So that they acknowledge that terror.'
'Then I passed it like the descending of the tor... rent falling from the high place.'
Chapter 65 On Frost and Foam
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And the white of the frost became as if it is ... Upon the tops of the plants, teased cotton.'
Al-Arji said:
'As if the falling of snow, what it pelted with ... On the earth, is cotton or flour being sifted.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a land:
'I was sleepless in it while the riders, their heads inclining ... Wade the shallows of slumber while they have heaviness.'
'The ice of the night covered them until as if they are ... Falcons revealed from their perches by the moon.'
Abu Nuwas said describing the foam of the camel (Madid Meter):

'His beard gets clothed with foam ... So his two veins to his nose.'
'Then the eye socket is turbaned with it ... Like the turbaning of the white stripe in its usher tree.'
'Then winds blow it away as ... The cotton of teasing flew from its bowstring.'
'An-Nasilan': Two veins next to the nose of the camel. 'Nakhratuhu': Tip of his nose. 'Al-Hajjaj': Eye socket. 'Al-Ushar': A plant, when opened has like white veins called 'Al-Fuf'. 'Al-Fuf': Whiteness at the base of nails. 'Burd Mufawwaf': Striped. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding she-camels:
'Their lips overflowed with foaming ... So as if they are usher trees splitting it.'
Tarafa said regarding his she-camel:
'You see between her jaws when she roared ... Foam like the web of the spider extended.'
Chapter 66
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking (Munsarih Meter):
'Isa's table is from half a lupine bean ... And his two bowls are from two halves of a lentil.'
'From an atom, an atom are his loaves ... Hidden from the eye so it is sought.'
'If sifted with silk, it would have leaked ... From the gaps of the weave, not held back.'
'If you preyed on the loaf, he moaned for it ... As if a lion there preyed on him.'
'As if every morsel eaten ... Is snatched from his hands, stolen.'
Abu Nuwas said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'He brought us a bread having sourness ... Resembling dirhams in its ornament.'
'Its taste sets the eater's teeth on edge ... And it sticks in the throat from its roughness.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding Ibn Abi Sahl bin Nawbakht:
'And his bread is only like the jackal, his son sees him ... And did not see the jackal in the rugged grounds nor the plain.'
'And his bread is only like a western phoenix ... Pictured in the carpets of kings and in proverb.'
Bashar said:
'The dinar of the family of Solomon and their dirham ... Are like the Babylonians surrounded by demons.'
'They do not appear nor is their meeting hoped for ... Just as you heard of Harut and Marut.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I ate a loaf at Musa's so he bored me ... And it was like my concern from a western beloved.'
'He wants an eater whose decrease of his food ... Is like the decrease of writing from dusty dust.'
Chapter 67 On the Impossible Act
Al-Farazdaq said:
'So you became, from what you have done, like a grasper ... On water, his fingertips did not return with anything.'
Another said:
'And whoever trusts the world is like a grasper ... On water, the gaps of fingers betrayed him.'
Muslim said:
'And indeed I and my overlooking you with my ambition ... Am like the seeker of butter from water by churning.'
Al-Najim said:
'You did not obtain by your churning water except ... Froth when you threw froth with ignorance.'
Abu al-Atahiya said (Munsarih Meter):
'You became not knowing the beautiful nor ... Distinguishing between the ugly and the good.'
'Indeed he who hopes for your generosity is like one who ... Milks a male goat out of desire for milk.'
Ibn Marwan said regarding a heavy servant of his (Munsarih Meter):
'He slows until I almost think he ... Encountered a male goat so remained milking him.'
Another said:
'And indeed I and my seeking my need from you ... Am like the melter of fat from the dog's tail.'
Ibn Hazim said (Munsarih Meter):
'He increases in meanness upon praise as ... The stench of dogs increases with rain.'
'Indeed he who hopes for your generosity is like ... The washer of excrement from his garment, fuming.'
Another said:
'So I became from Layla in the morning like a looker ... With the morning at the heels of a setting star.'
'Lo, you have only left, O mother of Malik ... An echo, wherever the wind goes with it, it goes.'
Chapter 68 On the Cupper
Another said regarding a cupper:
'A house his father built for him ... As if it is in the market a mole.'
'In it are horses, crouching ... They will not be resurrected until the Resurrection.'
'In it is terrified whoever gets an... gry from a boy or a girl.'
He said regarding the cupping glass:
'And a green one, not of the daughters of coo... ing, its beak snatches the skin.'
'Like the slit of the eyes of sandgrouse ... When they fall from their tracks.'
Khalaf bin Sa'id said mocking the chamberlain of Nasr bin Sayyar (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And your weapon was in a basket ... A cowrie shell hangs in its strap.'
'The weapon of a man leaving the human ... As if behind his ear is a Hayaqa'ah (noise/blow?).'
'With every biter, if you rode ... As if you fed it a tumor.'
Another said mocking the son of a cupper:
'O son of one who writes on the ne... cks without an inkwell.'
'He used not to write on them ... Other than the script of Alifs.'
Another said regarding the son of a cupper:
'Your father is a father who ceased not hurting people ... Pecking their necks as the falcon pecks.'

'He has a noose in it are thirty shaved ones ... Their views are white and their bodies red.'
'If the scribes one day crooked their lines ... Then a line of his is never crooked.'
Another said:
'And the grandfather of Khidash in his writing was ... Of the most writing of people, O Harun, for the Alif.'
From the beautiful said about him, even if it has no simile, is the saying of Ibn Kunasa (Munsarih Meter):
'Your father, most cunning is the carrier of his baldric ... How many a brave brown (skin) and how many a hero.'
'He takes from his money and from his blood ... He does not spend the evening in fear of an avenger.'
Chapter 69 On the Wound of the Tongue
Imru' al-Qays said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And that is from news that came to me ... And I was informed of it about Abu al-Aswad.'
'Even if from the spreading of other than him it came to me ... And the wound of the tongue is like the wound of the hand.'
Al-Akhtal said:
'I silenced Banu al-Najjar from you, the high ones ... Of Ma'add knew, and they were for long braying.'
'Until they submitted while they are in pain from me ... And the saying penetrates what needles do not penetrate.'
He has:
'And a clarifier (poem) from the bone with a sharp sword ... Repels from you the imagination of the broad man.'
'Your sword or your tongue, and the ... Wide wound is like the most capacious of words.'
Jarir said:
'My tongue and my sword are both sharp ... And the sword has a less harmful impact than my tongue.'
Al-Basir said:
'Indeed I seek refuge for you that you be a target ... For arrows of an archer, if he shoots he kills.'
Another said:
'And the wound of the sword heals so it recovers ... And the wound of time is what the tongue wounded.'
Hassan said:
'My tongue and my sword are both sharp ... And my tongue reaches what the sword does not reach.'
'By the life of your father, the good one, O Sa'd, never was dull ... Against me my tongue in calamities nor my hand.'
Similar to this, even if it has no simile, is the saying of Yazid bin Mufarrigh:
'Water washes what you did, and my poetry ... Is firm regarding you in the worn bones.'
Chapter 70
Nahar bin Tawsi'ah said:
'Khorasan was a land when Yazid was in it ... And every door of good things was open.'
'So it exchanged a saddle after him, pinching ... As if his face is sprinkled with vinegar.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking Al-Khallal, husband of Qustantin:
'If you see him bending his side ... Leaning in the saddle from excess arrogance.'
'High-nosed from his pride ... So if he sniffed vinegar he would bleed.'
Al-Muhallabi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And if the people came to you in need ... You cracked for two years in illness.'
'And you meet them always frowning ... As if you bit on a whey cheese (Maslah).' 
A Bedouin said regarding his cousins:
'I lost my masters who are as if they are ... Boils on my face bursting upon me.'
'If I say the disease died between me and them ... A wood-gatherer from them came to another seeking fire.'
Al-Ta'i said mocking:
'And a king in his pride and nobility ... And a commoner in his saying and deed.'
'I offered my praise regarding him seeking his giving ... So he cut the rope of my hope from his connection.'
'He wonders at my wondering at his miserliness ... As if I came to him with his dismissal.'
Chapter 71 On Pots
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And the neighbors knew that our pots ... Are guarantors for provisions while the wind is gusting.'
'Emptied into bowls as if their basins ... Are pools of the desert, of them full and half.'
'You see around them the seekers as if they are ... Upon an idol in Jahiliyyah devoted.'
Ma'n bin Aws said regarding a pot:
'When the kindlers leaned towards it, you saw it ... For the speed of its hospitality while it is ignited with thick wood.'
'You heard a clamor for it when it boiled ... Like the growling of camels roaring when they are startled.'
Umayyah bin Abi al-Salt said:
'And his pots in his courtyard ... For the guest are filled, overflowing.'
'And as if they, with what they are charged ... With and what they heated with, are co-wives.'
'Froth and gurgling like the gur... gling of stallions when they strut.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said boasting:
'And the sword is the shepherd of my camels in the drought ... Handing them to pots boiling.'
'Like the nights, allowed with pouring rain ... Trotting in them with thick fuel.'
'Their trotting in the march under the saddle.'
Another said:
'As if the sound of the boiling towards it ... Is the jumping of old men to old women.'
Chapter 72 On Gluttony
Ibn al-Rumi said to Ibn Hajib the poet when he invited him and others and hid from them out of sorrow:
'And a crowd came to you ... Every quick one, hungry, tired.'
'Unless they meet you, you meet for them ... The eating of orphans who have no earner.'

'From every sharp-gutted, gluttonous ... Eating what the calculator does not calculate.'
'His jaws are like the two eras (morning/evening) of his time ... Both of them in his affair are diligent.'
'As if the chicken in his hand is ... A prey whose lion is trained.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding a glutton:
'So as if the youth gathers mounts ... That fell or blocks breaches.'
'A stomach, first, like the mill of the seed ... -oil presser, throwing grain and throwing flour.'
Another said:
'So you strike the five of your hand in Tharid (dish) ... With mouthfuls from you, shrinking in departure.'
'As if an inkwell in the throat when ... It murmured is the sound of thunder in a cloud.'
Tha'lab recited:
'He gobbles mouthfuls and ransoms his provision ... He throws into his heart like sandgrouse.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the palms of the people in his bowls ... Are sandgrouse a roaming one did not scare from water.'
Tha'lab recited regarding a glutton:
'You see every loose-trousered one as if he ... Covers a roof or feeds a water-camel.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Ibn al-Mudabbir:
'I did not find my excuse for the trick... ster regarding it, the subtle.'
'Other than a belly of yours beg... ging when you became persistent.'
'O enemy of provision, O sna... ke of Moses, the swallower.'
Another said:
'My eye has not seen an eater like him ... Eating with the left together and the right.'
'His fingertips play in the bowl ... The play of the chess player with the Shah (King/Rook?).'
A Bedouin said: I never saw my grandmother Zaynab eating but I imagined she was throwing to a human behind her.
Chapter 73 On Mentioning Loved Ones
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'Lo, by the One who, if He willed, would not have created distance ... If you were absent from my eye, you were not absent from my heart.'
'Longing makes me imagine you until as if ... I whisper to you from my proximity even if you were not near me.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I do not care for thoughts ... And eyes I guard against.'
'I have from your mention a mirr... or in which I see your face.'
He has similar:
'They say to me while the distance is between me and them ... Layla became far from you and the cause of proximity ended.'
'So I said to them, while love is exposed by weeping ... If she parted from my eye, she has dwelt in my heart.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'And I was not angry at him then glanced at him ... Except I was pleased and beauty stood excusing him.'
'Nor did I remember him except as if he had ... Inside the heart an image-maker painting him.'
From the beautiful and witty speech in this meaning is the saying of Al-Hakam bin Qanbar:
'If you are not with me, then the mention of you is with me ... My heart sees you even if you were hidden from my sight.'
'The eye sees who it loves and loses him ... And the eye of the heart is not devoid of looking.'
Al-Najim said:
'If Ahmad went away from my eyes absent ... He is not absent from the eye of the heart.'
'He has an image in the heart distance did not cut ... And hands of calamities did not snatch.'
'I turned to a person of his, not distant ... His dwellings are between the vitals and the chest bones.'
'If the distance of his dwellings grieved me ... And my paths narrowed upon me in his love.'
From the good simile in that is what Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
'And she turns an eye in a page of silver ... Its turning tends the fruits of souls.'
'Indeed I conceal her mention so as if she ... Without the boon companion is my boon companion in my session.'
Chapter 74 On Love
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'So leave the lover from blame, for it is ... The worst medicine for a pained, anxious one.'
'Do not extinguish passion with blame, for it ... Is like the wind inciting the fire to burn.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'They departed, so my weeping was a full year ... Then I refrained, such is the rule of Labid.'
'More worthy for the ember of anguish, its extinguishing ... With tears, is that it increases in length of burning.'
He also said:
'She kindled upon you a meteor of fire in the vitals ... With blame at midnight, the sister of the family of Shihab.'
'Blame resembling madness, as if ... The foolish woman read half a book with it.'
Al-Khammar said (Munsarih Meter):
'They said you praised the Imam, I said to them ... I fear I will not limit him with description.'
'And how can he be given for praises who ... Abu al-Samt was to him a novelty?'
'As if our reciting his poems ... Is halves of books not harmonious.'
The best thing mentioned in this meaning is the saying of Al-Buhturi, even if it has no simile:
'I found yourself from my self in a status ... Which is the purity between water and wine.'
'I praise you because I did not find anyone ... Blaming you, and what does the blamer claim?'
Chapter 75
Al-Nimr bin Tawlab said:

'So if my clothes are torn from wear ... Then I am like the blade of the sword in the worn scabbard.'
That resembles the saying of Ibn Haffan:
'By my life, if He resurrects in the abode of my exile ... My clothes because eating places narrowed on me.'
'Then I am nothing but the sword, its scabbard wore out ... It has an ornament from itself while it is bare.'
He also has:
'Men reproach me for my sharpness foolishly ... So I consoled myself, returning and coming.'
'That I am like the sword, best when seen ... And most feared when met if it is unsheathed.'
Labid said:
'So I became like the sword, its scabbard wore out ... The era of the blacksmith aged while the blade is cutting.'
Abu Haffan said:
'Durr wondered when she saw my gray hair, so I said to her ... Do not wonder, for the rising of the full moon is in the darkness.'
'And it startled her wonder that I went in rags ... And Durr did not know that the pearl (Durr) is in the shell.'
Chapter 76 On the One-Eyed
Yahya bin Aktham appointed two one-eyed men to the judiciary of the West and East sides, so Di'bil said:
'I saw of the major sins two judges ... They are a tale in the two horizons (East/West).'
'They divided blindness in halves by decree ... As they divided the judiciary of the two sides.'
'And you think of them one who shook a head ... To look into inheritances and debt.'
'As if you put a jar on him ... And opened its spigot from a single eye.'
Another said:
'And between us always is a blind man we compose ... Allah may create blind men from the one-eyed.'
Some of them revealed this meaning describing a one-eyed woman and her lover is one-eyed:
'She is one-eyed on the right and this ... Is one-eyed on the left, an old waterskin agreed with a cover (Shenn).'
'Between their persons is a blind man when ... She sat on his right singing.'
Another said:
'Did you not see me and Amr when we run ... To needs, we have no equal.'
'I walk with him on the right of his hands ... And between us is a blind man.'
Chapter 77 On the Description of Fish, Lawzinaj, and Others
Ibn al-Rumi said asking for fish:
'And daughters of the Tigris in your courtyard ... Are captive in every battlefield.'
'Invaded with the likes of armors and some... times with the like of piercing thorns.'
'White like ingots, nay ... Filled with fat like the Akak (lizards/fat?).'
'They dispense with the oil seller for their fryer ... And perfume the grillers with grease.'
'Their appearances were beautiful and helped them ... A taste like the untying of the knots of drawstrings.'
He has asking for Lawzinaj from Ibn Bishr in a poem:
'Lawzinaj does not miss me from you ... When it appears it pleased or caused wonder.'
'Desire did not close its doors ... Except Zulfat refused to be veiled.'
'If it wished to go in a rock ... The scent would mock a path for it.'
'It rotates with puffiness in its bowl ... A rotation, you see the oil for it as a spiral.'
'Helped in it an appearance informing ... Considered beautiful, assisted a considered sweet.'
'Dense of stuffing although it is ... Thinner of skin than the breeze of the East wind.'
'Like the beautiful goodness in his singing ... Complete so he became a striker (proverbial) enchanting.'
'As if its robes were cut ... From the eyes of rain when it bubbled.'
'It is thought from the thinness of its crust ... To share with the grasshopper in wings.'
'If a mouth were formed from its baking ... It would be the bright lustrous-toothed.'
'Of every white one the youth loves ... To make the palm a mount for it.'
'Oiled, blue, buried ... Gray, imitating the blue-gray.'
'Neither if the eye saw it, it recoiled ... Nor if the molar topped it, it recoiled.'
'Almonds were tasted for it, so no bitterness ... Passed over the taster but he refused.'
'And critics critiqued the sugar ... And consulted the gilded in its critique.'
He said describing a chicken:
'And a scalded, yellow, Dinar-like ... In price and color, a strong youth led it to you.'
'A Jawdhabah (pudding) started roaming in its fat ... So the core of almond came in it with sugar.'
'Yes, the sky there, its downpour remained ... Pouring, and yes the earth remained raining.'
'We remained peeling its skin from its meat ... So as if gold dust is peeled from silver.'
'And Qata'if (pancakes) came after that, delicate ... The uvula is pleased with them and the larynx is pleased.'
'The faces of the Tabarzad (sugar) laughed upon them ... The tear of eyes is squeezed from the oils.'
Ali bin al-Zayyat said:
'But what I see has consumed me ... With him of food on the table.'
'And stuffed eggplant you see ... Floating like ambergris in Ban oil.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding visitors:
'We did not know of present food ... We prepare it for the surprise of visitors.'

'Like two prepared foods in them ... Is a resemblance of the righteous and the wicked.'
'Heads and loaves, bright, grand ... Were brought out from a boiling hellfire.'
'Like the face of the people of Paradise smiled at us ... Coupled with the faces of the people of Fire.'
He said regarding grapes:
'And Raziqi (grapes) snatched (slender) of waists ... As if it is storehouses of crystal.'
'Guaranteed musk to the chests ... And in the tops rose water of Jur.'
'The glare of heat did not leave of it ... Except light in vessels of light.'
'It has the taste of gathered honey ... And the coldness of the touch of the waist of the cold one.'
'And the whiff of musk with camphor ... And the thinness of water on chests.'
'If it remained over time ... It would earring the ears of the beautiful Houris.'
'Without unique pearls and without beads ... I went early to it while the birds were in nests.'
'And the possessors excused in early rising ... And the dew is like scattered pearls.'
'Of beneficial in them and of cautioned ... Among youths from the children of Al-Mansur.'
'Fuller to the eye than full moons ... Until we came to the tent of the watchman.'
'So he swooped like the hungry of falcons ... Before the rising of the sun for sprinkling.'
'With the obedience of the willing not the forced ... Then we sat the sitting of the joyful.'
'Between two rows of lined trees ... On the edges of a filled stream.'
'White like the spread parchment ... Gliding like the terrified snake.'
'Then he brought us weak (soft) udders ... Filled with confined honey.'
'Sufficient for you as a cluster of appearance.'
He has regarding it:
'And Raziqi snatched (slender) of its waists ... Ripened musk to the bottoms.'
'As if it is storehouses filled ... With rose water in which musk is dregs.'
Chapter 78 On Admonition
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Sadness for a world, its inhabitants are only ... A hidden group.'
'How many a people its sweetness deceived ... From its bitterness except the intelligent.'
'So they rushed into its honeycomb ... And perished like flies.'
Abu al-Atahiya said (Madid Meter):
'Every thing has an admonition in it ... It would admonish man if he reasoned.'
'The world is only like a stage ... Man settled in it and departed.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'And man's life was a driving to death ... And his days before death are stages.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'O my brother, do not forget the graves ... For they are a promise for you.'
'And as if a thing the eye ... Did not attain the hour it is lost.'
Al-Qatami said:
'And I see death as traps for men ... A net used repeatedly for the one who was not caught.'
Tarafa said:
'By your life, indeed death, whatever the youth missed ... Is like the slackened tether whose two ends are in the hand.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'Lo, O death, I saw no escape from you ... You came so you did not deviate nor favor.'
'As if you attacked my gray hair ... As gray hair attacked my youth.'
He has:
'And as if he whom his pit hid ... A figure of him did not appear to an onlooker.'
'For the hand of death in its subtleness ... regarding the treasure of every compassionate one is a search.'
He has:
'And as if he whom hands buried in the soil ... Was not rich in love when his burier returns.'
'A body that will be ruined when his soul exits ... Like the house ruined when its dweller exits.'
He has:
'And death is not hidden from anyone ... Of whom I see, yet as if it is hidden.'
'And I passed by the graves and did not ... Distinguish between the slave and the master.'
Chapter 79
Bashar said:
'Al-Rabab desires your nearness and fears ... The eye of a slanderer and dreads his listening.'
'You are from her heart the place of a drink ... She desires drinking it and fears its headache.'
Ibn Harmah said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Abu Khalid loves praise ... And fears the gift of the praiser.'
'Like a virgin desiring the pleasure of marriage ... And fearing the assault of the marrier.'
He has similar:
'So you are in praise like the virgin, pleases her ... The touch of men and fear bends her heart.'
'She shows joy at that while she is pitying ... As the Parting (head) fears the hissing of the snake.'
Kuthayyir said:
'She grants a little scant while she is pitying ... As the Parting fears the hissing of the snake.'
Chapter 80 On Satire
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Ibn Abi al-Jahm al-Katib:
'O son of Abu al-Jahm, bundle this kindness ... For in it is a novelty of novelties.'
'O body of the hill and O face of the target ... O dung of the elephant and O meat of the shell.'

'O jar of the house, decree and loan ... O night of the Inn when the Inn leaks.'
'O war of Ab (August) for the dwellers of rooms ... O bad measure and high prices and bad dates.'
'O omen of bad luck and O omen of destruction ... O ice of salty water in which are carcasses.'
'O pottery of the oven, O worst of pottery ... O blockage in the two nostrils from worms.'
'O repentance of poverty and O tooth of senility ... Whoever complains of passion and infatuation.'
'Then I am towards you in hatred and passion ... The closer of them to you is misery and illness.'
'Your house is a house dirty with every dirt ... Chastity and honor do not meet in it.'
'Rather, clitorises and foreskins meet in it ... How many a bird you neglected until it clipped wings.'
'The best of what bad arrogance barked with ... You ceased not from your time in the worst protection.'
'It grants you injustice after injustice ... You have no successor in your hatred if you die.'
Al-Najim said:
'O son of Abu al-Jahm, listen slowly ... Novelties I gifted in haste.'
'From the points of solid poetry, selected ... Drowning in a vast sea, not shallow.'
'O likeness of well water in coldness and heaviness ... O night of abandonment, abandonment of boredom.'
'O pulley of the lover came with blame ... O separation of friends, O blocking of the gap.'
'O distress of labor pains and O weight of the mountain ... O confusion of the destitute whom tricks exhausted.'
'O denial of the recovering from the most cunning illnesses ... O strength of despair and O weakness of hope.'
'O slowness of provision and O nearness of term ... O Saturn of time and Mars of states.'
'O speck of eyes, not kohl of eyes ... O jasmine of sickness, not rose of shame.'
'Nay, O fertilizer of the latrine truly no likeness ... O every mentioned thing hateful and stingy.'
'I swear were it not that I have laziness regarding you ... Poetry would have been serious in you at times and jesting.'
'Tearing your honor the tearing of old rags ... You ceased not from your time in the worst place.'
'Fear after fear follows you from it ... You have no likeness in your hatred if you die.'
'Except your sons, the mange-scabbed, the foolish, the low.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Gloom rose over the Diwan ... Since the son of his youth took charge of it.'
'O crow of separation in o... men and gutter of impurity.'
'O book of divorce ... And condolence for his calamity.'
'O example of worries ... And agonies and gloom.'
'O loaf the gro... cer returned dry and hard.'
'A writer too, so what pa... ssed over the head of writing.'
Ibn Bassam said mocking his brother:
'O rising of the watcher, O separation of a mate ... O creditor who came on an appointment.'
'O stagnation on a day of clouds and summer ... O faces of merchants on the day of depression.'
Al-Atawi said:
'I came to you longing, so I did not see a doorkeeper ... Nor a sitter except with a frowning face.'
'As if I am a creditor demanding payment or as if I am ... The rising of a watcher or the rising of a beloved.'
Chapter 81 On Growing a Beard
Sa'id bin Humayd said regarding a boy who grew a beard:
'Why didn't you, with the water of your face, desire ... The softness of youth, little of sideburn hair?'
'So now when a beard appeared on your cheek ... It took away your beauty the fill of the grasper's palm.'
'Like the first juice, the wine of its squeezing returned ... After deliciousness, vinegar of sour wine.'
Ibn Bassam said regarding his brother:
'O you whom his beard announced to the brothers ... You turned back while people are approaching and turning back.'
'You were among those whom onlookers smile at ... Hearings and sights are lowered before you.'
'By Allah, what a youth his death came ... And everything has a time and a measure.'
'His death came so his sideburn turned black ... As the house turns black after the dead.'
Sa'id bin Wahb said (Munsarih Meter):
'What is the matter with you, O gazelles of Wajrah, or ... What is the matter with you, O calves of the wild cow?'
'They died but were not buried to be counted ... So in them is a lesson for the one who takes lesson.'
'As if they, after a joy that was erased ... Are riders upon whom are the turbans of travel.'
Mus'ab said:
'A beard shook hands with the sides of your cheek ... Left it while it is black of sides.'
'So as if the line of hair in its sides ... Is night staying upon stars of day.'
Chapter 82 On Shortness of Stature
Al-Najim said regarding Al-Aziz (Hazaj Meter):
'Lo, O pawn of chess ... In value and stature.'
'The whole of you has become small ... Except the rear and the head.'
'So your Waj'a' (pain/anus?) does not cease ... To be sought for the abundant.'

'And the palm of the huge in your head ... Is like the mole or the beauty mark.'
'Indeed a person erred who count... ed you, O Tartur (tall cap/small man), a scholar (Allamah).'

'Indeed Ibn Bassar has a stature ... With its length is the beak of a chick.'
'A thread cuts him and satisfies the one who ... Surrounds him of it with a Tassuj (weight unit).'

He has regarding him:
'The deficiency of brothers reduced his affair ... While he is the brother of humiliation and deficiency.'
'As if he is the flea, did not miss him ... In smallness of body and pinching.'
Al-Massisi said regarding a short man:
'You cut a long cloak for him ... And a leaf from the leaves of mulberry.'
'Rich, I see him in his mother's womb ... Formed from the sperm of a flea.'
Al-Najim said regarding Al-Aziz:
'And absent of opinion, weak, deceived ... Stumbling from blindness in darkness.'
'Competing in knowledge while he is outnumbered ... His outcome from it is scattered dust.'
'In the body of a sparrow and the dream of a sparrow.'
Hassan said mocking Banu Abd al-Madan:
'Leave the strutting and walk a natural walk ... Indeed men possess nerves and masculinity.'
'There is no harm in the people regarding length and shortness ... Bodies of mules and dreams of sparrows.'
Then he praised them and said:
'And we used to say when we saw ... One of body who is counted and of tongue.'
'As if you, O one given a tongue ... And a body, are from Banu Abd al-Madan.'

Ibn Abi Hafsa said (Munsarih Meter):

'She remains in the shirt from shortness ... Like a small bird (Sa'wah) in the hollow of a cage (Qaffa'ah).' 
'Short of stature, squat ... Her stature is the stature of a bubble.'

'Small of build, squat ... The cap throws her into the forgetfulness.'
'Her breath kills her sitters ... Due to the proximity of her sipping place to the farting place.'

'And a short one, the sun ... Does not make a shadow for his stature.'
'People stumble over him in the road because of his lowliness.'
He has regarding Ibn Ammar:
'Indeed Ibn Ammar has a stature ... Close of parts to parts.'
'Poverty and his addiction humbled him ... So length became width in him.'
'The eye does not see when he appears ... Of him except the head on the ground.'
Chapter 83 On Heavy People (Bores)
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:

'You are to me like the water of your well in sum... mer, heavy, upon it is severe cold.'

'O many a day I remained grazing its sun ... And as if it is in the air a tear of a fearful one.'
'I consorted in it with a group who were a speck ... To the eye, not met with a blinking eyelid.'
'They were winter in it except that I ... From its sun am in the hottest of a summer day.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding a bore:
'And a bore, as if he is the weight of debt ... Every eye is burdened by him rising.'
'Allah loaded His earth with its two weights (Thaqalayn - Jinn & Men) ... And created him as an addition to the two weights.'

'A bore observing us from near ... If a nosebleed pleased him, he pained.'
'His appearance has a prick in the vitals ... Like the touch of cupping glasses on the cupped.'
'I say to him when he comes: May he not come ... Nor a foot transport him to us.'
'I lost your imagination not from blindness ... And the sound of your speech not from deafness.'
'Cover with whatever you wish from my sight ... Even with the cloak you are veiled with.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And a bore whose sitter is in agony ... An hour of him is like the day of separation.'
'Allah decreed his death since a time ... And death loathed his soul so he is remaining.'
'I do not name him by his name, it sufficed me ... That he alone is the hated of Iraq.'
Chapter 84 On Crows
Regarding crows, some poets said:
'Did a dwelling in Khayb excite you ... And a dwelling in the height of the dune?'
'As if the croaking crows at its sides ... Are youths who came from Abyssinia and Nubia.'
'They land as a group and fly separately ... When the sun intends setting.'

'And there ran between them on the morning they departed ... From Dhu al-Abariq a croaker, shouting.'
'Convulsed of sciatica, drooping of wing, as if he ... In the house, following the departing ones, is shackled.'

'Those whose separation I expect departed ... And the piebald crow ran at their separation.'

'Burnt of wing, as if the jaws of his head ... Are shears, cheerful for news, fond.'
Another said:
'And a crow shouted separation, croaking ... As if he uproots a grief from his mouth.'
'Penetrating below the uvula, entering.'

Al-Basir said:

'She waited a little while trembling in fear ... As the sun waits when it becomes straight (noon).'

'And she turned away as youth turned away, slow ... The soul folded a flank against her out of her despair.'

A Bedouin said:
'It is lawful for Layla to terrify his heart ... With abandonment, and Layla's sins are forgiven.'
'So she declined the declination of the sun from its settling place ... So who will inform me in which land is her setting?'
Al-Buhturi said:
'She approached at separation for a time of parting ... The approach of the sun inclining to the afternoon.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said:
'And I looked at separation and did not find ... For death, if separation was lost, a messenger.'
'Indeed calamities, if visualized, would not be ... A seeker of departure by separation or sought for departure.'
'The Hour (Resurrection), the separation emerged, so as if ... You connected the hours of Resurrection in length.'

'The residents lightened so they went from you or left early ... And an intention disturbed them, in its turning is change.'
'As if I am a drinker on the day he became alone with them ... Of coffee which Homs or Jadr contained.'
Similar to this is much. Qays bin Dharih said, and his father forced him to divorce his wife Lubna:
'So oh my sorrow and my pain returned to me ... And the separation of Lubna was like mutilation.'
'The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me ... So oh Allah for the obeyed slanderer.'
'So I became in the morning blaming myself ... For a thing and it is not possible [to undo].'

'The standing of an hour shook him so as if ... In every limb of his is a heart beating.'

'She called me openly to her love ... And did not know that I am her lover.'
'So I went, and for longing from my parting ... To my feet are tongues speaking.'

'It hides then breaks from the barley of its head ... Like the clipping of the fingernail from its clipper.'
Another said regarding a slave girl:
'As if there met the paper when she wrote ... From her three pens on a pen.'

'Knowledgeable of the ends of matters as if he ... With snatched thoughts hears or sees.'
'If he takes the paper you think his right hand ... Opens blossoms or strings jewels.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Ta'i regarding a book:

'So how much in it of subtle meaning ... And how much in it of splendid wording.'

'Blackness like the covert feather of the crow ... And pens like the sharpened spears.'
'And paper like the glimmer of the mirage ... And words like the days of youth.'
Hajzah bin Abi Sulalah said:
'From a book as if it is hairs ... In the middle of a cheek, a sideburn signaled with them.'
'Or like the engraving of henna in the palm of a vir... gin, covering protected her face with it.'

'The hand wrote you whose treasure is sove... reignty, not a dirham nor a dinar.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said:
'And a note came to you folded ... As if it is a cheek upon a cheek.'
'Wasted of lines turned ... From the salt of jest to seriousness.'
'A casting of black in white as ... Crushed musk was crushed in the rose.'
'O writer whose blame handed me ... To him, sufficient for me from you is what I have.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'By your life, the sword, sword of the brave ... Is not more fearful than the pen of the writer.'
'It has a witness, if you contemplated it ... You would appear on its hidden secret.'
'The tool of death is in its two sides ... So who is like it in the fear of the monk?'
'The spearhead of death in a side ... And the sword of death in a side.'
'Did you not see in its chest like the spearhead ... And in the butt like the sharp cutting sword?'

Chapter 89 On Similes with Exception of Something or Reduction of Something
From similes with exception of something or reduction of something is the saying of Al-Akhtal describing wineskins:
'They unloaded so they dragged raised ones as if they are ... Men of the Sudan who did not wear shirts.'
'Al-Shasi': The one raising his legs, and 'Al-Shaghir': The one raising one of them.

'And he brought out the wineskin from its shop ... Raising the two legs, bound of knees.'

'And jars like a row of men ... Were set up to dance the Dastband.'
He also has:

'And you see them while they are prostrate ... Empty among the boon companions.'
'Like heroes of wars ... Killed in them as noble ones.'
Al-Najim said:
'And a wine like lightning except that it ... Transgresses against times with shining.'
Awf bin Muhallim al-Khuza'i said:

'Like the full moon except that she ... Transgresses against the light of the day.'
Abu Nuwas said:

'As if in its cup is a mirage ... Imagined by the desolate deserts.'
'As if it is that when it glows ... If yellowness did not mix with its color.'
'Night does not descend where it settled ... So the time of its drink is day.'
He also said (Munsarih Meter):

The Author said:
Simile, although better in poetry and more difficult for the poet because he intends hitting the simile, chooses words, guards against grammatical error and absurdity, adorns speech and confines it with rhyme, yet literati, wits, wise men, contemplators, jokers, and effeminates have correct similes and wonderful meanings. We will mention a selected collection of them then return to poetry. And through Allah is success and strength.
Chapter 90 On Anecdotes (Lata'if)
Abu al-Harith described the sycamore of Ja'far bin Yahya, saying: It was a clothes-stand from where I met it, terrifying.
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'If you were of anything other than yourself, you would not be ... To be anything but a clothes-stand in a clothes-stand.'
'Oh would that I bad a patch from the skin of your face ... So I could cut from it a hoof for the Ashjab (limping horse?).'
This is the saying of Mansur bin Badhan al-Isbahani (Mujtath Meter):
'Oh would that the hoof of my sandal ... Was from some of the skin of your face.'
'I mock some of you with some ... Who can withstand your chest?'
Anecdotes

The author of Kalila said: The world is like salt water; whenever the drinker drinks more, he increases in thirst.
Ahmad bin al-Mu'adhdhal said to his brother Abd al-Samad: You are like the extra finger; if cut it hurts, and if left it shames.
Al-Jammaz used to not let more than three enter his house due to its narrowness. He invited three, but six came to him. They stood man by man behind the door. He counted their legs from behind the door and let them in. When they got into his house, he grumbled. They said: What is the matter? He said: I invited people and did not invite cranes standing on one leg, one leg.
The author of Kalila said: Manners remove intoxication from the wise and increase the fool in intoxication, like the day increases the sighted in sight and increases the bat in bad sight.
Abu Abdullah Ja'far bin Muhammad, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Manners to the fool are like fresh water to the roots of colocynth; the more it is watered, the more bitter it becomes.
Al-Jahiz said: An effeminate entered the bath and saw a man with a large penis and much hair. He said: Look at the Caliph in a velvet rug.
A man said to some chiefs: You wrote for me to So-and-so, so it was as if you wrote from you to you.
It was said to an effeminate who used to drink the milk of she-donkeys: How did you wake up? He said: Do not ask about one who woke up as the brother of the female donkey.
The author of Kalila said: A position attained does not make the wise arrogant, like the mountain which stormy winds do not shake, while the slightest position makes the weak arrogant, like the grass moved by the slightest wind.
Another said: Ibn Abbas used to strut in his speech as a man struts in his walk.
The author of Kalila said: Company of the good bequeaths good, and company of the wicked bequeaths evil, like the wind; if it passes over stench it carries stench, and if it passes over perfume it carries perfume.
A man said to a wit: Describe to me the feast of So-and-so. He said: It was as if it were the time of the Barmakids in its beauty.
A man said to a man: Describe the earthquake to me. He said: Like a horse that shook then returned.
The author of Kalila said: Whoever advises one who does not thank him is like one scattering his seed in salt marshes, and whoever advises an arrogant one is like one signaling to the deaf.
He also said: The virtue of the possessor of manners is not hidden even if he hid it with his effort, like musk which is hidden and covered, then that does not prevent its scent from spreading.
Al-Jammaz mentioned a man and said: His standing up among us was like the falling of an ember from winter, due to his coldness.
The author of Kalila said: A man of chivalry may be honored without wealth, like the lion who is feared even if crouching, and the rich who has no chivalry is not feared even if rich, like the dog who is despicable to people even if collared and ankleted.
Some wise men said: Whoever does not accept from his advisors what is heavy on him of what they advise him in, his affair's outcome is not praised, and he is like the sick person who leaves what the doctor prescribes for him and intends what he desires.
An old woman said, having seen Talha on the Day of the Camel: Who is this whose face is like a Heraclian dinar? They said: This is Talha. Then she saw Al-Zubayr and said: Who is this who is like a speckled snake licking its lips? It was said: Al-Zubayr. Then she saw Ali, peace be upon him, and said: Who is this who is like Kisra then was restored? They said: Ali bin Abi Talib, Commander of the Faithful.
The author of Kalila said: Affection between the righteous is slow to break, fast to connect, like a gold vessel which is slow to break, easy to restore. And affection between the wicked is fast to break, slow to connect, like a pottery vessel, the slightest thing breaks it then there is no connecting it.
A delegation spoke before Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik and they did not know anything. After them, a man of miserable appearance spoke and was eloquent. Sulayman said: His speech after their speech was like a cloud that laid dust.
Al-Mu'alla bin al-Zayyat described a man and said: He was like the tongue of a snake in his intelligence.
Ibn al-Rumi said: The month of Ramadan between Sha'ban and Shawwal is like a wooden bead between two pearls.
Abu Sulayman al-Tunburi said: Sha'ban is a road that does not lead through.
Another said: The companion is like the patch in the garment, so seek him matching.
The author of Kalila said: The might of the strong enemy is not repelled by the like of submission and humility, just as the grass is only safe from the stormy wind by its yielding to it and bending with it wherever it inclined it.
He also said: The enemy is not to be trusted nor slackened even if he showed beauty, for water, even if its heating is prolonged, that does not prevent it from extinguishing fire if poured on it.
A thief entered upon a sailor, so he described him to his neighbors saying: Tall like the mast, black like the ship's tar, and his thigh is like the rudder. Every craftsman speaks from his craft, as a sailor was once asked: How much remains of the day? He said estimating: A pole's length of sun.
The grammarian Al-Mazini heard a rumbling from a man's belly, so he said: This is a hidden fart.
Sa'id bin Humayd said: The work of the Sultan is like the bath (Hammam); he who is in it wants to get out of it, and he who is outside it wants to enter it.
The author of Kalila said: The world is like the silkworm; it does not increase in wrapping silk on itself except it increases in distance from exiting it.
A man described Ibn Muhriz the singer, saying: As if he was created from every heart, for he sings every human what he desires.
Some wise men said: The intellect is like the sword and experience is like the whetstone.

An effeminate looked at Musa bin Isa, and Al-Mansur had appointed him after him, then appointed Al-Mahdi and put Musa after him. He said: This is the one who was tomorrow, he became the day after tomorrow.
Another said: He who goes to the scholar without tablets is like the one striving to war without a weapon.
The author of Kalila said: The sinner does not like his affair to be examined due to the ugliness revealed from it, like the stinking thing, whenever it is stirred it increases in stench.
Ali, peace be upon him, said: The world is like the snake, soft to touch but deadly poison in its fangs.
Mazbad saw a man with a large nose having hair, so he said: As if his nose is a bag full of shoelaces.
It is said: The woman is like the sandal, the man wears it when he wishes, not when she wishes.
Anushirvan said: Patience is bitter (Sabr) like its name, and its outcome is honey.
Abu Tammam al-Ta'i said:
'And I accompanied my days with patience, sweetened for me ... Its consequences, and patience is like its name, bitter (Sabr).'
Some said: The supplicant without action is like the archer without a bowstring.
A man described the blessing of a people saying: Blessing stuck to them until as if it is from their clothes.
Ibn Mas'ud said: The rememberer of Allah among the heedless is like the fighter behind those fleeing.
An effeminate looked at a short man on a small black donkey and said: He rode a wineskin of syrup (Dibs) and came walking along with people.
Similar (Munsarih Meter):
'As if his legs while the hobble is on them ... Decreed upon him falling into the lasso.'
'The most similar thing I saw to its rider ... Is a fisher with a hook who went early on a wineskin.'
The author of Kalila said: Whoever does good for immediate reward is like one throwing grain to hunt birds with it, not to benefit them.
Ibn al-Rumi looked at a white broken cloud in the sky. He said: As if it is cotton teased on a blue lining.
Mazbad looked at a black Medinan man fucking a white Roman boy. He said: As if his penis in his ass is a goat's trotter in a bowl of rice.
Ibn al-Rumi, when asked to liken the kidney of a kid, said: As if it is a bean. And he said the chickpea resembles the peach.
Ubada likened jasmine to the yolk of an egg (Khurmiyyah?), and the waves of Tigris in the south wind to the humps of camels.
The author of Kalila said: If the noble falls, he is not lifted except by the noble, like the elephant if it gets stuck in mud, it is not uprooted except by elephants.
Abu al-Ayna said: I was coming to Muhammad bin Harun while he had a crowd of his brothers, and I found him the lowest of them in voice. I said to him: Your eating of Tifl (clay?) is visible in your house.
Ibn Mukarram presented to Al-Basir a side of roast not cooked. Abu Ali said: This is not a side, this is a reed lattice.
Abu al-Ayna mentioned the children of Musa bin Isa and said: Their thousand are graves erected not towards the Qibla.
Ubada looked at a black slave girl wearing a yellow headcover. He said: As if she is a charcoal whose head ignited.
Chapter 91 On Mixed Similes and Single Verses
From mixed similes and single verses is the saying of Muslim mourning Yazid bin Mazyad:
'A grave in Bahrain whose trench hid ... A danger, dangers fall short of it.'
'So go as went the morning clouds of a rain ... Praised by the plain and the rugged terrains.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Buhturi mourning Abu Sa'id:
'And go as went with its shining light ... The sun of the day, and darkness followed.'
Al-Hasan bin Mutayr said mourning Ma'n:
'A youth, people lived in his kindness after his death ... As the pasture returned after the torrent to its course.'
Al-Buhturi said praising Ibn Tulun (Munsarih Meter):
'When he rose in the splendor of his appearance ... I saw upon him in beauty his tester.'
'Like the rain, his essence does not reach ... Some of what his effect went reaching.'
Another said mourning a man:
'So he died and left of the inheritance of his giving ... As the heavy rains left for the animals.'
Another said regarding a parasite:
'And an Arab casting off the halter ... More imposing (Atfal) than night upon day.'
'More fixed in the house than the wall ... He drinks with the small and the large.'
'As if he, in the house, is the lord of the house.'
Abbas bin al-Mashuq said:
'O inheritor of sponging from a father ... I judge with skill and gentleness.'
'If you made the needle a cloak for him ... He would pass like lightning through the hole.'
'You eat the provisions of the sons of Adam ... You are indeed created without provision.'

Al-Buhturi said regarding Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Ibrahim:
'The police was adorned with him when came ... To him from it the prohibition and command.'
'As if the spear in his palm ... Is the star of darkness escorted by the full moon.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'If you saw him behind the spearhead falling with ... It, you would see a sharp one behind a sharp one.'
'And you would liken this and that to two meteors ... At night falling with a swoop.'
He has describing a pool:
'As if the water daughters (birds) in the expanse of its surface ... When its current rose and elevated.'
'Are carpets of Kisra spread in a courtyard ... To attend a delegation or gather a gathering.'
'It shows you a spring in autumn and a garden ... On a deep water, a novelty of the matter innovated.'
Zuhair said:
'You see him when you come to him rejoicing ... As if you are giving him what you are asking him.'
Ibn Harmah said:
'We praised you for the kindness you did ... As the night traveler praised the night travel when he reached morning.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'All the traits in you are your beauties ... Morals and creation resembled each other in you.'
'As if you are the citron tree, was good together ... In fruit and blossom, and the wood and leaves were good.'
Al-Ta'i said mocking Uthman:
'Do not be fond of mentioning Muhammad ... The length of glory and its width forbid you from him.'
'For as if your honor in smoothness is his face ... And as if your face in ruggedness is his honor.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
