'Say to him who greeted so revived ... A dead one he thinks alive.'
'What would harm you if you kept ... For me in the cup something?'
'Do you think I was anything but ... Like who was before in it?'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'As if I am with you, you have met my initiative ... With clumsiness, stumbling in it the stumbling of a blind man.'
'Like one protecting against the flame of fire, so he prepared ... For it, out of ignorance, two shields of naphtha and sulfur.'
'So it was a help against him what he sought help with ... And his hands scattered him what a scattering.'
Ibrahim bin al-Abbas said regarding Ibn al-Zayyat similar:
'And I and my preparing Muhammad for my time ... Am like one seeking extinguishing a fire with a blower.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'O son of the false coins which I see ... Flew so were hunted by the palm of Qurtum.'
'Exposed the exposure of food publicly ... At every time to a Muslim.'
'And all of them saying: Bon appetit ... Not satisfied to tread on it with a toe.'
For Al-Musayyab bin Alas (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Kings spend the night on her threshold ... And Shayban, if she blamed, blames.'
'And like honey with wine are their morals ... And their minds are sweeter than both.'
'And like musk is the scent of their stations ... And the scent of their graves is better.'
For Abdah bin al-Tabib mourning Qays bin Asim al-Minqari:
'Peace of Allah upon you, Qays bin Asim ... And His mercy as long as He wills to have mercy.'
'A greeting from one you granted a favor from you ... If he visited your land from a distance, he greeted.'
'And Qays's death was not the death of one ... But it was the structure of a people that collapsed.'
For Al-Ta'i regarding Al-Afshin:
'How many a blessing of Allah was with him ... So as if it was in darkness and captivity.'
'It was clothed with the locks of his meanness so it shrank ... Like the shrinking of the beautiful woman in rags.'
For Ibn al-Rumi asking a gift from a man who came from Siraf:
'I swore by the wine when it worked ... And the flute and the lute clapped.'
'If the Oud (wood/lute) came to us and its followers ... And the best of them is the green ambergris.'
'Indeed our poetry would begin praising with it ... Multiples of what the incense burner praises with it.'
'And if camphor came, we would say a hand ... White like camphor, not denied.'
'Or a ship came to us from you ... Red like the flame or blond.'
'Squeaking, but it is solid ... The scorpions of the house are terrified of it.'
'It did not squeak except we have its speech ... With thanks, we do not tire or it tires.'
For Ibn al-Mu'tazz describing a rooster (Munsarih Meter):
'A chanting bird announced the morning ... It cried out from the night after it reached the middle.'
'Reminding of the morning drink, it shouted at us ... Like a preacher who stood upon a pulpit.'
'It clapped either out of joy for the light of dawn ... Or out of sorrow for the darkness.'
He also has describing a rooster (Munsarih Meter):
'And it crowed on the wall looking out ... Like a horse mounted by horsemen.'
'Then it began asking the Euphrates about the family of ... Azraq, of them is a mouth (gap) and a beak.'
'Raising a head at times and lowering it ... As if the comb of it is a saw.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'I lost you, O son of Abi Tahir ... And I fed your bereavement to a poet.'
'For you are neither hot nor cold ... And between these two is only the tepid.'
'And you likewise feed the sou... ls the supper of the tepid thick.'
He has regarding him (Mutaqarib Meter):

'I lost you, O son of Abi Tahir ... And I gulped your bereavement before supper.'
'For the coldness of your poetry is not the coldness of drink ... Nor is the heat of your poetry the heat of roast.'
'It fluctuates before you between arts ... So neither for cooking nor for grilling.'
Others said:
'And poetry like the dung of the ram, tore between it ... The tongue of a pretender in poetry and confused.'
The other said:
'Do you not see that my poetry traveled from me ... And your poetry around your house does not travel?'
He has regarding the fart of Wahb (Munsarih Meter):
'O fart that wears out time while it ... Does not cease to be one of the new novelties.'
'The owner of the post sent it as ... Some hills of Uhud collapsed.'
'It traveled without burden or fatigue ... The travel of enduring rhymes, roaming.'
'As if the winds flew with it ... So they attached it to every possessor of distance.'
'If his news were like his fart ... Then it would suffice him the provision of the post.'
He has regarding that:
'Abu Hasan Wahb greeted Abu Hasan ... With a fart that flew his beard as tufts.'
'Then it continued and traveled in the lands for him ... As if it was sent from his rear as a proverb.'
He has regarding him:
'O Wahb, possessor of the fart, do not despair ... For anuses have breaths.'
'And fart for us another without shyness ... As if you tore a paper.'
He has regarding another:
'A fart in your nape, the lis... tener thinks it a garment of silk being cut.'
Ali bin Jabalah said (Hazaj Meter):
'Humayd is the refuge of the na... tion in the East and in the West.'
'As if people are a body and h... e is of them the place of the heart.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Abu Sa'id when he was imprisoned:
'And these days are nothing but stages ... So from a wide dwelling and from a narrow dwelling.'
'And calamities have refined you, and only ... Pure gold clarified before you by smelting.'
Al-Khath'ami said to Malik bin Tawq:
'Let not the slanderers think your imprisonment a spoil ... For to the return is the end of the arrival.'
'And you were nothing but the sword unsheathed in war ... So praised for a time then returned to the scabbard.'
Ibrahim bin al-Abbas said:
'And if Allah rewards a man with good ... Then may He reward a brother of mine, noble, generous.'
'I called him out of distress, so as if ... I called out of a night having a morning.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'Our mounts spent the night to you with us ... Treading the people of fire and barking.'
'So as if their hands, bloody ... Are searching their night for a morning.'
For Al-Buhturi praising Ali bin Murr:
'Do not blame the gift given, his ambition ... And how can looking tire the eye of the looker?'
'He mediated time in states, so no smallness ... From the accidents that befall nor greatness.'
'Like the spear, its cubits are ten and one ... So no length harms it nor shortness.'
'And ascending in the hills of glory, he ascends them ... As if he, for the calmness of heart, is descending.'
'He ceased not preceding until his envier said ... He has a short path to the heights.'
Similar is his saying:
'And if Abu al-Fadl borrowed a character ... For noble deeds, then from Abu Ya'qub.'
'Honor followed, elder from elder ... Like the spear, tube upon tube.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking a man who was with Ibn Ubaydullah bin Sulayman using a poem from which we mentioned verses of simile:
'I was sleepless as if I spent my night on embers ... Watching slumber between Arcturus and Vega.'
'And why not, when a despicable pig insults me ... So he decrees upon my sleep and I close my eyes on compulsion.'
'I will complain to the denier of denial, Qasim ... So he will look into my matter with the two eyes of a falcon.'
'And I burdened myself regarding you every great thing ... Until I tasked myself with intercession from Amr.'
'So my answer was that I was blocked, and thus ... Is the answer of the seeker of rain from a grave.'
'A youth whose face is like abandonment, no connection after it ... And as for his nape, it is connection without abandonment.'
'And the empowerment of his rope crooked Amr ... As the hand of the boy crooked the line.'
'And Amr twisted for me an ivy of a thicket ... And prolonged, so he does not care for length nor estimation.'
'And they nicknamed him River of Buq (Horn) arbitrarily ... And in the scoundrel are resemblances from the horn and the river.'
'For the stature is of length like a crooked river ... And for the nose of him is the tone of the horn in disbelief.'
Al-Mutalammis said:
'And do I have a mother other than her? If I left her ... Allah refused except that I be a son to her.'
'And I was nothing but like the cutter of his palm ... With a palm he has another, so he became mutilated.'
'When he led the palm with the palm, there was not ... For him a catch in that it separates, so he refrained.'
'His hands, this one struck the death of this one ... So the other did not find against it an advance.'

'So he lowered his head, the lowering of the snake, and if he saw ... A passage for his fangs, the snake would have bitten.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said in this meaning (Munsarih Meter):
'I did not commit a sin, so if you claimed that ... I committed a sin, it was not intentional.'
'The hand of its owner may strike the eye ... Yet he does not see cutting it as guidance.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The month of fasting, even if its sanctity is great ... Is a long month, heavy of shade and movement.'
'It walks slowly, but when it seeks us ... Neither Al-Sulayk approaches it nor Al-Salakah.'
'As if it is a seeker of revenge on a horse ... Hard in the trail of a sought one on a mare.'
'I blame it except a time in which I praise it ... From Isha' until the roosters crow.'
'If it were a master and we were like slaves to it ... It would be a stingy master, bad of ownership.'
He also has:
'Ramadan, the deviators claim it is blessed ... They spoke truth, by your grandfather, it is indeed long.'
'A month, by my life, its little is not little ... And likewise the blessed, there is no little in it.'
'The days prolong in it with its effort ... So as if the era of yesterday in it is a year.'
'If it were for those crossing a distance ... I would have thought the span of it a mile.'
Ibn Abi Uyaynah said mocking:
'Like a father, for the truth of saying when I met him ... And informed him what is in him, I silenced him with a stone.'
'Your father is a rain for us, we live in his shade ... And you are a locust leaving nothing nor sparing.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'Smells in your mouth are a falling thing not withstood ... And the face of you is a powder in which is soreness.'
'And you did not speak except you said an obscenity ... As if your jaws are scissors for honors.'
'Whenever you spoke, arrows from you are sent ... And your mouth is your bow and honors are targets.'
Similar to it which resembles simile from metaphor is the saying of Ibn Haffan:
'Do not sit conversing on the roads ... If you are one day fearful for your eyes.'
'The hooves of horses are bows and their arrows ... Are smooth stones and the targets are in the pupils.'
For Marwan bin Abi Hafsa:
'Banu Matar on the day of meeting are as if they are ... Lions having cubs in the thicket of Khaffan.'
'They protect the neighbor until as if ... Their neighbor has a home between the two Arcturus stars.'
Better than it is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi regarding Abu al-Saqr:
'You meet them while the spears of Al-Khatt are around them ... Like the lion, Khaffan clothed it with thickets.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding Al-Rashid:
'An Imam who fears Allah until as if he ... Hopes for His vision morning and evening.'
'High-nosed, long of forearms, as if ... The baldril of his sword is wrapped with a banner.'
He has regarding Muhammad al-Amin:
'Long of fingers, when he gathers his robe with his baldril ... He covers the skulls while the row is standing.'
Ibrahim bin al-Abbas said mocking (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So be however you wish and say what you wish ... And flash lightning right and thunder left.'
'Your meanness saved you, the safety of the fly ... Its filth protected it from being reached.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Sa'id the Little:
'O man deceiving himself ... In the group of literati and generous ones.'
'With the verse he recites its quarter or half ... While bread is blamed at his place and water.'
'His deception with the buxom girls is a lock of hair ... Dyed with greens and henna.'
'Do not lie, for your meanness is fading ... Like the fading of that gray lock.'
And for Bishr bin Abi Khazim:
'For indeed you and your praising Bujayr ... Abu Laja' are as Al-Ala' (bitter tree) was praised.'
'People see it green from afar ... But bitterness and refusal prevent it.'
Similar is Ibn al-Rumi blaming Al-Tawzi:
'He is not who settled in the place which you ... Are in of generosity and loyalty.'
'He offered the promise to friends obediently ... And refused after that the offering of sufficiency.'
'So he became like the willow, leafing to the e... ye and refusing fruiting with all refusal.'
Al-Alawi al-Kufi said:
'He loved the blamers because passion alienated him ... From his sleep, so as if sleep is sleeplessness.'
'Passion left of him a body like air, wasting ... The wind breathes in it while it is missing.'
'As if his tear, its beginnings run ... As it overflows on its last, returned.'
'I followed it with a breath whose paths bleed ... As if it is cut from the fever of vitals.'
Similar is the saying of the other (Madid Meter):
'A breath whose paths bleed ... And a moan I do not control.'
'And what I hide of burns ... The tongue of the tear exposes it.'
Ali bin al-Jahm said:
'Do you not see the day, how sweet are its characteristics ... Cloud and clearing and lightning and thundering.'

'As if it is you, O whom I do not mention ... Connection and abandonment and bringing near and distancing.'
Another said:
'As if the eyes of the people when they see him ... Are eyes of weak birds that saw a hawk.'
'And like pure honey to the companions of his affection ... And a poison he makes the haters taste, deadly.'
Similar is the saying of some regarding the killing of Amr bin Sa'id al-Ashdaq:
'As if Banu Marwan if they kill him ... Are vultures of birds gathered against a falcon.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Mujtath Meter):
'Contemplate the fault, a fault ... What is in what I said is doubt.'
'And poetry is like life, in it ... With youth is gray hair.'
'So let people overlook it, for their stabbing ... In it is unseen (Ghayb).'
'Until Jarir lives ... For his fault or Nusayb.'
Like his saying "And poetry is like life in it" is his saying (Munsarih Meter):
'Beautiful patience, for it is the virgin of ... Life, and there is no escape from its heats.'
'But ah for it, destitute ... May Allah protect us from its obstacles.'
Similar is his saying:
'And Time is only like its son, in it is early morning ... And midday, blameworthy of heat, scorching.'
Al-Buhturi said praising:
'You protected me from assembly whose first are not named ... Except on the morning of insults.'
'Of curly palms (stingy) not curly (hair) ... And angry faces not angry (brave).'
'They strutted the strutting of the waterless cloud and walked ... In the sides of thoughts the walk of the mirage.'
Similar is his saying:
'I knew you, if you promised, you promised a promise ... Waterless, and if you flashed, you flashed deceptively.'
Al-Khansa said mourning her brother Sakhr:
'Noble, bright-faced, the guides follow him ... As if he is a mountain peak on its head is fire.'
'Like the Rudayni spear, his secret did not run out ... As if under the fold of the cloak is a wall.'
Abu Zubayd said regarding his boy when he followed a war in which he was killed:
'And you have warmed at the heat of their fire ... As the cold one warms from freezing cold.'
'A palm having a remaining breath shoos away from him ... Birds hovering like the visitors of a wedding.'
'Soon they will rise over his body ... For they are of the lapping and the biting.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'O Banu Wahb, by Allah, baffled for you ... Are calamities and their times.'
'It angers the enemies that you are a group ... The preponderance of its scale became clear.'
'And the binding of the tips of your pens ... Is like the tips of the spears of its knights.'
'If they guaranteed the preservation of our properties ... It is as preserving an eye like its eyelids.'
Abu al-Atahiya said similar:
'And a man has a protector protecting him ... Just as the protector of the eye is the eyelids.'
For Abu Nuwas regarding Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi':
'As if the overflow of his hands when you ask him ... Is the door of the sky when it opened with rain.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Al-Hasan bin Wahb (Munsarih Meter):
'Abu Ali, his morals are blooming ... Following a rain, and his spirit is holy.'
'And a pit for speech he opened ... While people are foreign in the like of it, dumb.'
'He pierced its vitals with a speech, appearing ... As if it is from him a stab of stealth.'
'Our days in his shadows always ... Are a season of spring and our time is a wedding.'
'Not like people who have become the rust of ... Life, as if the world with them is a prison.'
'In distance from them is closeness of relief and the ... Loneliness from their likes is the intimacy.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking Khalid:
'Convey to Khalid that you are for in... sult and for wounds in your skin a tearing.'
'A fart in your nape, the lis... tener thinks it a garment of silk being cut.'
'Meanness stuck humiliation to your nose until ... They are equal, humiliation and the cutting.'
'That is under the mucus, humiliated, and this ... Is a boil of humiliation that is not lanced.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Banu Humayd:
'Graves at the ends of the frontiers as if ... Their locations of them are locations of stars.'
Similar is the saying of the other:
'Poverty threw the youths until as if they are ... At the ends of the horizons of the lands, stars.'
Al-Ta'i said mourning Humayd al-Tusi:
'And escaping death was easy, but returned him ... To it the bitter preservation and the rugged character.'
'And a soul that loathes shame until as if it ... Is disbelief on the day of fright or short of it is disbelief.'
This is taken from the saying of Abd Yaghuth the Jew [sic - Abd Yaghuth al-Harithi?]:
'And if I wished, a high-chested mare would have saved me ... You see behind her the short-haired excellent horses following.'
'But I protect the right of your father ... And the spears were snatching the protectors.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Banu Humayd:
'My covenant with them is the earth shines if they descend ... In it and the world gathers if they gather.'
'And Time laughs from them revealing masters ... As if its days from their beauty are a Friday (Jumu'ah/gathering).'

'Whoever did not witness Abu Nasr and his killer ... Has not seen a hyena in whose jaw is a predator (lion).'
'Why the gloating publicly over lions of war ... Patience annihilated them when panic preserved them.'
Aws bin Hajar said:
'Unarmed, staying in the unknown alone ... Blindly until they ask the morrow what is the matter.'
'If you were the passing of nights, you would have been ... Like a secret night, no crescent and no full moon.'
Al-Akhtal said:
'As for Kulayb bin Yarbu', they have no ... Visiting nor chest at the noble deeds.'
'Left behind, and people decree their affair ... While they are in absence and in blindness of what they perceived.'
Jarir said regarding Banu Laja':
'And the affair is decreed while Taym is absent ... And they are not asked permission while they are witnesses.'
'And indeed, if you saw the slaves of Taym ... And Taym, you would say which of them are the slaves.'
Another said like the poetry of Aws:
'If you were a land, you would be soft, easy ... And if you were a night, you would be the companion of the full moon.'
'And if you were water, you would be water of a cloud ... And if you were sleep, you would be the nap of dawn.'
Another said:
'If you were water, you would not be sweet ... Or were a horse, you would not be swift.'
'Or were meat, you would be dog meat ... Or were a sword, you would be not sharp.'
Al-Mubarrad recited:
'If you were water, you would not be pure ... Or were a wind, it would be the West wind.'
'Or were a cloud, you would not be rainy ... Or were marrow, you would be thin marrow.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'Do you refuse, Yusuf, the invitation of the belittled ... Woe to the one who carried you nine months.'
'Clitoral, her clitoris like the bone of her arm ... Steaming, then she came with a blind stinking one.'
'And you spend the night between facing and turning ... Like the road for a comer and a goer.'
'Like the two hired men of the saw pulling it ... Disputing in a split of pine.'
He has regarding Abu al-Hasan (Munsarih Meter):
'Intellect was crafted from his stillness, a crafting ... Pleasing, and intelligence was crafted from movement.'
'Brother of deeds, as if the flowers of stars ... Of the night are printed on his coins.'
'As if the rain is from the dew of his hand ... And the lightning is from his cheerfulness and his laugh.'
For Ali bin Muhammad al-Alawi (Hazaj Meter):
'And a house we have built, sol... itary like the solitary star.'
'We raised it upon pil... lars of Indian rods.'
'On a ridge of sand like ... The gradations of a curly nape.'
For Abu Nuwas:
'And a tent of a watchman at the head of a high place ... The hands of one who seeks it intend slipping.'
'We put the burdens in it at the scattering of a midday heat ... Crossing (Aburiyyah), blazing without a wick.'
'It waited a little then returned with a mix ... Of shade in worn dry grass, scant.'
'As if she has between two sides of an ostrich ... Its breast shied away from a kneeling place and a resting place.'
He mentions that he intended the tent of the watchman at the time of midday heat and Aburiyyah means the time of Sirius the Crosser which is in the middle of the sky in intense heat. His saying 'Ta'ayyat qalilan' means the sun moderated in the air then inclined and 'Fa'at' from 'Fay'' and 'Zhill'. 'Zhill' is what the sun did not fall on, and 'Fay'' is what it was on then inclined from. 'Zhill' is for the morning and 'Fay'' for the evening. 'Al-Iba'': Tips of reeds. He likened the watchman's tent to an ostrich not kneeling.
Muslim bin al-Walid said:
'So I swore to forget the callers to passion ... And the eye surprised her while the veil is falling.'
'So she covered with her hands the fruits of her chest ... Like the hands of prisoners weighed down by shackles.'
Al-Buhturi said mocking (Munsarih Meter):
'As if in his mouth is a morsel that tied ... His tongue so it twisted on crookedness.'
'He moves his head, you imagine him ... Having stood from a sneeze on a high place.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Upon me is a heavy debt, you are its payer ... O you who burdens me my debt is my hope in him.'
'Do not make me like the hoper of rain, the driest of it ... While only he who hopes for it hopes for the wide step (rain).'
Al-Najim said regarding Ibn Khabbaz and mentioned his mother:
'Her anus turned gray with the boys of a vulva ... She rubbed it like the beard of the baker.'
'Her vulva and her wide anus are like the two ... Seas but they did not separate with a barrier.'
'My wonder at the houses of the family of Khabbaz ... Is like the houses of chess, all are Munaz (taken?).'
'How many penises we saw heading for their testicles ... Like the heading of the current to the walnuts.'
Al-Hutay'ah said:
'And I praised you deliberately to guide you ... So that you have firm rope and strong building.'
'So I did not possess that your souls were ... Like a hater of men who hated my clothes and my dressing.'
Al-Buhturi said praising:
'A cloud if he gives, a fire if he assaults ... He has the might of the Indian sword in the shaking of the branch.'
'We sought refuge in his kindness so as if we ... For our protection in it sought refuge in a fortress.'

Al-Ta'i said regarding Abu Sa'id:
'Your smiling while colors are eclipsed became ... The smiling of morning in dark gloom.'
'Thus is your brother the dew (generosity), if he were human ... He would not be found for the blink of an eye other than smiling.'
'You returned the luster of my face in its page ... The return of polishing to the splendor of the sharp cutting sword.'
'And I do not care, and the best speech is its truest ... Whether you saved the water of my face or saved my blood.'
Hattan bin al-Mu'alla said:
'Were it not for little daughters like the down of sandgrouse ... Crowding around me from some to some.'
'I would have had a wide roaming place ... In the land of length and width.'
'But our children among us ... Are our livers walking on the earth.'
A Bedouin said regarding his children:
'Indeed chicks from behind Al-Ahshar ... I left them, their eldest is like the youngest.'
'Incapable of trickery and earning ... My memory to them is like the taste of sugar.'
'And their passion for me is like the passion of the one-eyed ... For his eye, if it goes he will not see.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'He has a wife, he has partners in her ... Like travelers the road gathers them.'
'A hundred others are lawful for her husband ... Because his share of her is little.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'O night, how lo... ng it was except for the shortness of prostitution.'
'I revived it and killed it ... And folded it the folding of the cloak.'
'Until I saw the sun fol... lowing the full moon in the horizon of the sky.'
'So as if he and as if she ... Are two cups of wine and water.'
And for Ibn al-Mu'tazz similar:
'When I saw the full moon in ... The horizon of the sky and it had risen.'
'And I saw the horn of the sun in ... The horizon of setting and it had dangled.'
'I likened that and this ... And I see their likeness most clear.'
'To the face of the beloved when he appeared ... And the back of the beloved when he turned away.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'My eyes, be scarce and do not pour ... My calamity is too great for weeping.'
'Your leaving the disease hidden ... Is more truthful of the health of loyalty.'
'Indeed sorrow and weeping of old ... Are two matters like disease and medicine.'
'And seeking medicine is only ... Seeking a way to survival.'
'And seeking life after a friend ... His brotherhood of purity lied.'
Al-Ta'i said asking Abu Sa'id for sympathy for his son:
'A crescent for us, his light was appearing ... So our eyes are set up when will he initiate it.'
'He is the sword, sharp, his scabbards wore out ... And was lost until everything notched him.'
For Al-Muhallabi mocking Khalid bin Yazid son of his uncle:
'You were nothing but like the meat of a dead animal ... Necessity called to eating it.'
Mahmud al-Warraq said:
'I blamed you first until when ... I tested other than you, the blame returned as praise.'
'So I did not praise you for good but ... I saw other than you worse than you indeed.'
'So I returned to you in need, humiliated ... Because I did not find from that an escape.'
'Like an exhausted one who considered eating a dead animal great ... So when forced, he returned to it running.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'My Lord, give me justice from Time for I ... Have no victor over it except You.'
'People go low and a group rises ... Who separated from peers from every side.'
'By my life, if we contemplated them ... They did not rise but floated like carcasses.'
'Carcasses floating on the sea of wealth ... While the hidden things of shells do not float.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'O you who asks me about a group ... The meanness of deeds increases them in elevation.'
'Thus carcasses of the dead when they rot ... And cavities of water cast them, they rise floating.'
He has similar:
'A time the value of the low rose in it ... And the noble fell, his honor lowers him.'
'Like the sea, its pearls sink in it ... To the bottom and its carcasses float above it.'
Di'bil said mocking Al-Hasan bin Wahb:
'O who turns a scroll (Tumar) and spreads it ... What is in your heart of love for scrolls?'
'In it is a resemblance of a thing you are pleased with ... Length for length and roundness for roundness.'
And for Ibn Bassam mocking Banat Tumar:
'For Banat Tumar over their peers ... Is a virtue that will appear in them and become clear.'
'They will insert their father out of their love ... So the Sheikh is buried in their asses.'
Another said similar, who is Al-Baladhuri:
'O Wahb, O filth of the presence ... You fart in the assembly of the Emir.'
'I likened his scroll to a penis ... That exceeded in the desire of penises.'
Another said:
'Your pulpit which you left ... Yesterday is still from you like a menstruating woman not purified.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'The earth menstruates from the footsteps of Bura... n even if between Zamzam and Al-Hatim.'

'The most obscene slander and satire for Bura... n is purification like stoning for the stoned.'
'She is the specter of imagination haunting the people of the ... Earth from among departing and resident.'
'She is at night everything you see ... Standing in the darkness like the hill.'
'She does not tire of kneeling or the birds ... Falling on her back like some roots.'
And he mentioned the width of the vulva, saying:
'It encompasses the seven regions entirely ... While it is two fingers of a region.'
'Like the conscience of the heart devouring the world ... And the two sides of a chest contain it.'
Regarding her he says on the tongue of a Mithqal (weight):
'Then you tried with the little Mithqal my belitt... lement, but you increased me only in magnification.'
'Like the one who lowered the torch to hide ... While it is closer for him to blazing.'
Al-Buhturi said praising:
'I counted but did not reach a limit for your virtue ... And do the night travelers reach a rising place for the sun?'
'And I was not in describing you except like a dotard ... Measuring the tracts of the wide earth with cubits.'
Abu al-Samh said:
'We drank at the top of the monastery until as if we ... Were kings possessing what is between Hit to Egypt.'
'So when the sun of the day appeared and shone ... Wealth cleared from us and we returned to poverty.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Akhtal:
'When my friend gave me drink then gave me drink ... Three glasses having a roar.'
'I went out dragging my tail from me as if I ... Over you, O Commander of the Faithful, am an Emir.'
Ibn al-Dahhak said:
'And like the white rose he greeted with a rose ... From the rose walking in tunics like the rose.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'Just as wearing out wears out the new garment ... So the glancing eyes wear out the man.'
This is of good simile. Among the best proverbs in that is the saying of Al-Ta'i:
'And the length of a man's stay in the tribe wears out ... His two brocades, so go abroad you will be renewed.'
'For I saw the sun increased in love ... To people because it is not eternal upon them.'
Ishaq bin Abi Rabi' said:
'And I enjoy what I desire while death is before it ... Like the drinker of poison in a silvered vessel.'
'So my illnesses are about to pierce with an illness ... That separates between me and my nurse.'
Ibn al-Rumi said addressing Banu Sulayman bin Wahb:
'And you are the Tall Palm which grew high ... Of old and the root and the branch of it were blessed.'
'So if the heart (Jumar) withheld its spadix from me ... Let not the frond hit me with the two edges of its thorn.'
And for Al-Ta'i boasting of his people:
'They passed and as if the noble deeds with them ... Due to the abundance of what they recommended of them, are laws.'
'They extend with the cutting white swords, hands ... And they are equal, and the cutting swords.'
He said mentioning Amorium when it was burned:
'You returned the pitch-black night in it while it is forenoon ... A morning of flame chases it in its middle.'
'As if the black robes of darkness desired ... Away from its color or as if the sun did not set.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Al-Hasan bin Makhlad:
'And master of politics, middle ... Between ease and strictness.'
'Not the inexperienced in the clu... b nor the empty when alone.'
'Like the sword, cutting while it is un... sheathed and feared while it is sheathed.'
Ibn al-Rumi said praising Sa'id bin Muhammad similar to this:
'He has an assault hidden in tranquility ... As the Indian sharp sword hid in the scabbard.'
'If he sheathed it, hearts settled in their place ... And if he unsheathed from it, the muscles trembled.'
Marwan bin Abi Hafsa said:
'And opinion is like the sword, blunt if you strike with it ... In its scabbard, and if you unsheathed it, it cuts.'
And for Ibn al-Rumi:
'Is there a judge, just of judg... ment, fair to me against an unjust woman?'
'She spent the night with whispers on her outside ... From a clear one like the stars.'
'And for my inside from her are whis... pers from worries like adversaries.'
'Difference between the two sta... tes of the connector and the cutter.'
'How much between the whisper of the je... welry and between the whisper of worries.'
Another said:
'And indeed the speech of a man out of its essence ... Is like arrows falling having no arrowheads.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Mutawakkil al-Laythi:
'And poetry is the core of man, he displays it ... And speech is like the locations of arrows.'
'Of it is the one falling short of its target ... And penetrating ones taking the stake.'
Makhlad said mocking:
'I see you looking at me askance ... As beautiful women looked at gray hair.'
'You sharpen the pupils at me in rage ... As if I am forgiveness in your eyes.'
Jarir said:
'A people, if they get angry, their noses are crushed ... The crushing of the mender the asses of nails.'
Another said:

'So there is not in Al-Harish nor Uqayl ... Nor the children of Ja'dah any generous one.'
'Those are a group like the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) ... Stationary, not moving with the stars.'
Another said:
'You see the Sheikh of them milking the penis with his ass ... As the hungry baby milks the breast.'
Bashar said:
'Abu Ahmad, my waiting has been long, three ... And your promise is a disease like the disease of the pleurisy.'
'Relieve me with despair or with hastening a need ... And come with it, generosity is not forbidden.'
'Otherwise show me with it a face of exit ... Suffice with clarification from an eloquent and a mute.'
'And do not be like the virgin on the day of her marriage ... When asked permission regarding herself, she did not speak.'
Similar is the saying of Muslim (Munsarih Meter):
'O guest of Musa, brother of Khuzaymah, fast ... Or take provision if you have not fasted.'
'He lowered his head when I came praising him ... So he did not say No, grace be upon me, nor Yes.'
'So I feared if he died that I would be retaliated for him ... So I stood seeking salvation from near.'
Another said regarding frogs:
'And crippled ones, and they have legs ... Like the sitting of the fucker when he ejaculates.'
Al-Buhturi said praising:
'Peace, even if peace is a greeting ... Then your face without return suffices the greeter.'
'Do you not see the tide of the Euphrates as if it is ... Mountains of Sharawra came in the sea swimming?'
'And it was not of its habits except that it ... Saw a character from its neighbor so it learned.'
Abu Nuwas said when he left drinking:
'My share of it became when it circulated ... That I see it and smell the breeze.'
'So as if I, and what I improve of it ... Am a sitter (Qa'idi - Kharijite sect) adorning arbitration.'
'He could not bear carrying weapons to wa... r so he advised the capable not to stay.'
Abbas al-Massisi said (Munsarih Meter):
'Four of the Mu'adhins of Aleppo ... Their melodies did not miss clamor.'
'As if at the call their throats ... Are camels beaten in them with wood.'
'Ugly is the voice of the Imam after them ... Hitting us in the rows with knees.'
'You think some mules striving ... Turning in a creation on the pole.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'You see the great work if he takes charge ... Of its policy like a slave seeking to be sold.'
'If he is sold nearby, upon him ... Otherwise absconding is an intercessor for him.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding the swallow:
'Drink at the sight of the swallow when it appeared ... A cup from whose edges sparks fly.'
'Most beloved to me of birds, when they appeared ... They came driving to you the light and the flowers.'
'As if their voices in the air flying ... Are the sound of shears when they cut hair.'
Ibn Munadhir said:
'And Al-Thaqafi, if he was generous, he clothed him ... And his figure startled you, is nothing but a phantom.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'You are nothing but a phantom whose specter roamed ... And my satire of you is nothing but the rambling of a sleeper.'
He also has:
'And even if I do not mock you except like a dreamer ... Seeing what sleepers see so he rambles.'
'Because you are devoid of equal, and only ... My conjecture shows you to me while I contemplate.'
'If you were a fixed thing, then a dust mote ... Diminishes in the eye of certainty and becomes small.'
Di'bil recited:
'I offered praise to men other than their money ... An ugly opposite and a wording not good.'
'So I did not win from them except as carried ... The leg of the mosquito from the pottery of brick.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'I was afflicted with praising the misers as if I ... Am stingy with praise towards the generous noble ones.'
'And I was, having hoped for kindness to a giver ... Like the seeker of gift from a friend who does not connect.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Ibn Ghiyath, scribe of Sa'd the Chamberlain:
'I say to Ibn Ghiyath when I saw for him ... A Sheikh, his meanness contains him not the Sheikh.'
'Why are you proud, cleanliness makes him arrogant ... And why is your father, upon him is humiliation and dirt?'
'He said: Do not blame us for our disparity ... For we are books, our fathers are drafts (Nusakh).'
He also said:
'And in proverbs is ample room ... The salt marsh may bring out the long-branched palm tree.'
The meaning in this simile is for Ahmad bin al-Husayn al-Mutakallim in his saying:
'The singing of men is copies (Nusakh) drafted by women.'
For Ibn al-Mu'tazz in the cemetery of Al-Mahallah:
'And inhabitants of a house, no visiting between them ... Despite the nearness of some in neighborhood to some.'
'As if rings of clay are upon them ... So they have no breaking until the Resurrection.'
It is taken from the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'And I neighbored a people, no visiting between them ... And no connection unless it be Resurrection.'
Abu Uthman al-Najim said:
'I saw Isma'il in his medicine ... Incapable of a disease and its acquisition.'

'He kills whoever he treats with speed ... As if he was inserted to hasten him.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'And as if Su'da when she bid us farewell ... And the tear had risen to flow.'
'A fawn, the singing girls advised regarding him ... Until they tied an earring in his ear.'
Al-Buhturi said to Sa'd, chamberlain of Ubaydullah bin Yahya (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And you darkened when you wore black ... Darkness of night whose rider did not travel.'
'And when we attended for the permission of the Wazir ... And the curtain or its side was lifted.'
'We remained casting conjectures about you ... Are you his cupper or his chamberlain?'
He said regarding him when he reconciled with him then broke (Mutaqarib Meter):
'We trusted Sa'd, but it did not succeed ... Neither Sa'd's honesty nor his treachery.'
'And his dark horse surpassed his color ... So he and his workhorse came equal.'
'And how is my repose to his absence ... While the color of my hand with him is his color?'
Al-Ta'i said:
'The white camels will be with me and the night at a youth ... Much of mention of satisfaction in the hour of anger.'
'Like the rain, if you came to it its first part fulfilled you ... And if you moved away from it, it was in pursuit.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I saw you showing in war equipment ... And a fighter does not prevent spoils from you.'
'So you are like the bee aiming its thorn ... And it does not prevent the fruit pickers from what it carries.'
Abu Nuwas said regarding Ja'far bin Yahya:
'I wondered at Harun the Imam and what ... He loves and hopes in you, O creation of the wolf (Silq).'
'A nape behind a face that was elongated as if it is ... The nape of Malik fulfilling worries on Thabaq (?).'
Al-Ta'i said:
'Al-Hasan bin Wahb ... Is like the rain cloud in its pouring.'
'In the prime of his dew ... And the prime of his youth.'
'And a suit he was clothed in ... Like jewelry in its inflammation.'
'So I extracted praise ... Like honey in its combs.'
'So he went in my praise ... And I went in his clothes.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding Sa'id:
'I do not claim for Abu al-Ala a virtue ... Until his enemies hand it to him.'
'Equal are the mark of his deed and his following rain ... Like the rain, its farthest is brother of its nearest.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'I forgot then how many a hand you have that resembled ... The hand of proximity, it returned a mad lover to distance.'
'And of a time you clothed me as if it ... When its days were mentioned was the time of the rose.'
Ahmad bin Yusuf al-Katib said regarding Musa bin Abd al-Malik:
'Do not blame me, O Abu Ja'far ... Blame of friends is of meanness.'
'An anus of his infused with redness ... As if it is the cheek of a suppressed one.'
Similar to that is the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'Do not blame him for continuing tears ... For meanness is the blame of the friend to the friend.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And a blessing from him I wore ... As if it is the border of a new cloak.'
'Of those which if a grateful one slackened ... Stood for their giver in the place of the preacher.'
Like this, even if it has no simile, is the saying of Nusayb:
'So they turned and praised with what you are worthy of ... And if they were silent, the bags would have praised you.'
This is like their saying: The tongue of the state is more eloquent than the tongue of complaint.
Al-Buhturi said:
'If Ishaq bin Kundajik praises with me ... A land, then all game is in the belly of the wild ass.'
'If he cut, he hit the joint without missing ... Or spoke he succeeded, or poured he was abundant.'
'And the promise is like the fresh leaf, bent ... In it are branches, and its success is to bear fruit.'
He mentioned in it his scribe Ibn al-Fayyad and said:
'He performed upon me what is upon him as a source ... For the matter at difficulties and a source.'
'Accepted, from wherever he came I thought him ... For his acceptance in the soul, he came announcing good news.'
Another said:
'And flies defecated on him until ... As if his defecation is dots of ink.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Convey to you Banu Tahir ... Doctors of the Caliphate for its disease.'
'You rose the rise of the stars of the sky ... So a storm upon us like their storms.'
Abu Nuwas said mocking:
'And I did not leave of Aylan except ... As the razors left of the clitoris.'
'And Kahil and Banu Qu'ayn said ... Your mercy, we are not people.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'If the legs of his wife were her hands ... Mercy covering her would not have missed her.'
'Since her legs were created raised ... As if they are asking forgiveness of Allah.'
Similar is his saying:
'They do in it a righteous deed ... Allah raises it to the lowest.'
'People ask forgiveness with their hands ... And they ask forgiveness with legs.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said (Munsarih Meter):
'So how many an embrace for us and how many kisses ... Snatched in fear of a watcher.'

'The pecking of sparrows while fearing ... The scarecrows, the ripe dates.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'The garment of the one who died is upon his heir ... And upon the one who died is a garment of clay.'
'And as if the thing of what has passed ... And ended is the peck of a sparrow that pecked.'
Abu Nuwas said describing the ship:
'O you who prepared resolving on departure ... Intending Baghdad without a sailor.'
'In the belly of a girl who sufficed you with her movement ... The strutting of every tall and high one.'
'So as if she, while water butts her chest ... And the bamboo stick is in the hand of the sailor.'
'Is a black one of the eagles rushing to the darkness ... Falling with a sound and clapping of a wing.'
Al-Jammaz said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'If you cannot have intercourse ... And you were fond of the love of adultery.'
'Then you are in that like the whetstone ... It sharpens the iron but does not cut.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And Al-Numayri gave a fatwa to his pimp ... And the fatwa of Al-Numayri is debauchery and stuttering.'
'For you are a blacksmith sharpening the weapon ... And you have nothing of the killing.'
Another said:
'Dirty of shirt, thick ... Of other than its weft is its warp.'
'And his undergarment is of his hair ... So as if he is of the skin of a sheep.'
Al-Asha said:
'And you were stripped of a kingdom and wealth you gathered ... As spindles were stripped of their threads.'
The Arabs say: More stripped than a spindle and more clothed than an onion.
Abu Nuwas said regarding the Barmakids:
'They planted the planting of palms trustingly ... And they did not harvest except as vegetables are harvested.'
Ibn al-Rumi said congratulating Abu al-Saqr on an Eid al-Adha in which was Nayruz:
'Be happy with a festival of a brother of worship and Islam ... And a festival of amusement, open-faced, smiling.'
'Two festivals, Adha and Nayruz, as if they are ... Two days, your deeds of misery and favor.'
'Of a sprinkler with what souls are revived by ... And a barrier between souls and bodies.'
'Likewise are your two days: a day whose gift is rain ... Upon the poor, and a day whose sword is bloody.'
'I saw the nobles of Allah's creation made ... Heads for people, and you are the eyes of the heads.'
'You are stars of a sky that has no setting ... And those are more noble than fires of flags (mountains).'
'And every thing feared you so it clothed itself in a tunnel ... As if it is in its intestines a letter of Idgham (assimilation).'
Mansur bin al-Faraj said:
'If you come to him, your quarter becomes fertile from him ... While the earth is barren like the cheek of the beardless.'
'He sought praiseworthy deeds striving, and they are ... Those not contained by a seeker who did not strive.'
Ibn Abi Hafsa said regarding Ibn al-Mu'tazz (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And I trace lineage in your praise as a fifth ... And I hope not to be the last.'
'He sought praiseworthy deeds striving, and they are ... What bequeathed you your crown and the throne.'
Al-Ahwas said:
'Indeed I am envied for what you know ... I grow on hatred and malice.'
'Indeed I, if men are hidden, you find me ... Like the sun not hidden in any place.'
Al-Kumayt said:
'I found people other than Banu Nizar ... And I did not dispraise them as middle and low.'
'And indeed they are brothers to us, but ... Fingertips of a palm do not equal.'
Al-Buhturi said similar:
'And your thought of natures if they equaled ... Is like your thought of fingertips equaling.'
Kuthayyir Azza said:
'And she was regarding cutting the connection between me and her ... Like one vowing a vow she fulfilled and dissolved.'
'And I and my infatuation with Azza after ... I relinquished what was between us and she relinquished.'
'Am like the hoper for the shade of the cloud whenever ... He settles from it for a resting place, it vanishes.'
Al-Farazdaq said:
'And indeed a man striving to corrupt my wife ... Is like one striving to the lion of Al-Shara to urinate on it.'
'And short of the urine of the lion is valor ... And the extension of hands whose length prevents injustice.'
Similar is the saying of Al-Tirimmah:
'O Tayy of the plain and mountains, your appointment ... Is like the seeking of game in the den of the lion.'
'And the lion, whoever seeks game in his courtyard ... Limps with his soul from the end of the body.'
Jamil said:
'The heart loves you as long as we live, and if I die ... My echo follows your echo among the graves.'
'Indeed I am looking at you for what you promised ... The look of the poor to the rich wealthy.'
Al-Hutay'ah said:
'Do you hide the love of Hind from all people ... While what is hidden by that is not hidden?'
'So you have nothing but looking at her ... As the poor looks at the rich.'
Al-Buhturi said mocking:
'And a prince whom I wrestled from his kindness ... So I found a tough rock blinded by its blindness.'
'Newness driving away stinginess from its edges ... Like the sea pushing its salt from its water.'

Al-Massisi said, and a man gifted him a light dinar:
'The dinar of Yahya is excessive in deficiency ... In it is the mark of the mint of deprivation.'
'Its appearance is thin and its imagination is thin ... So as if it is a soul without a body.'
'Or a lover whose beloved became fond of his abandonment ... So he melted him with the heat of abandonment.'
'He gifted it concealed to a veil ... So I found it more hidden than concealment.'
He has regarding it:
'The dinar of Yahya, that filth ... As if it came from prison.'
'And in the blowing of the wind it mimics for us ... The turning of the dancer in the wedding.'
'Sickness has played with its body ... So it is a phantom, stopping of breath.'
'As if it is in the palm due to lightness ... Its amount is from the yellowness of the sun.'
Umayyah bin Abi A'idh al-Hudhali said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'O Fatimah, may you be greeted with happiness ... When did we know you? May you not be distant.'
'As if in my eyes from passion for her ... Is a speck rubbed with the kohl stick.'
Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah said:
'So when we stood together I knew what was with her ... Is like what is with me, the matching of the sandal to the sandal.'
'She said and relaxed the side of the curtain: Only ... My family is with me, so speak without fear.'
Al-Buhturi said mocking Ibn Ahmad bin Salih:
'The donkey went mad, so how little is what ... He acquires of acceptance or skill.'
'So as if the low one commits what he committed ... Of ugliness in a bet or race.'
'His hands engineered, instead of what ... He seeks, the engineering of the door closing.'
He has (Munsarih Meter):
'And hidden ones in obscurity we tes... ted them so the forbidden dispraised its earner.'
'They were like the thorns of the Tragacanth, its shep... herd hates it and its gatherer refuses its pleasure.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'The slanderers did not lower you from a rank ... With me, nor did a backbiter harm you.'
'As if they praised and did not know ... You to me with what they faulted.'
From it in simile is his saying:
'If I came you did not come, and if I did not come ... You came, so this from you to me is a sin.'
'As if you, even if you do not ... Lie in the appointment, are a liar.'
Bishr bin Abi Khazim said:
'Lo, convey to Banu Lam a message ... For miserable is the stopping place of the stranger's mount.'
'If they make a contract for a neighbor they betray him ... As the rope deceived the bucket.'
This is contrary to the saying of Al-Hutay'ah:
'Those are a people, if they built they perfected the building ... And if they covenanted they fulfilled, and if they tied they tightened.'
Jarir said:
'I used to think there was fabrication in Taym ... And among them a wise one after what they plotted.'
'Until Taym exposed itself to me to mock it ... As the anus of the one shitting stones exposed itself.'
Similar is his saying:
'As if Banu Tuhayyah, the offspring of Salma ... Are stones of a shitter throwing at dogs.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'You do not see his legs except ... An Alif embracing a Lam.'
'Sleeping, a penis did not rise ... So when he slept, it rose.'
Similar is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'O ornament of the writers of Diwans ... And philosopher of the wide-eyed virgins.'
'As if his thighs when joined ... And the penis is in it, are the knot of twenty.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking Al-Akhfash (Munsarih Meter):
'He did not say poetry nor narrated it, so not ... Its fox was he, no nor its lion.'
'So if he says: I narrated, then like the ... Notebook ignorant of all it held.'
Al-Atawi said:
'And how many said: Wish. So I said: A cup ... Circulated by a branch on a sand dune.'
'And a boon companion we dropped conversation with ... Like the glance of the scoundrel or the lowering of the watcher.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And my hand is moist for peace ... With attainment, and moist for war with blood.'
'I preceded my envier to my pride ... Like your preceding with the glance the step of the foot.'
Bashar said:
'Do not make me like cumin in a farm ... If water misses it, promises suffice it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said similar (Munsarih Meter):
'How many a haughty one proud of his wealth ... The misguiders misled him before me.'
'I made him with satire a pepper ... While you made me, his wish, cumin.'
Another said:
'And we are cousins, despite that between us ... Are carpets in which are hatred and competition.'
'And we are like the crack of the eye, if given a mender ... He leaves it while its defect is conflicting.'
Al-Mubarrad recited similar:
'And in us if it is said we reconciled is mutual grudge ... As the hairs of the mange-scabbed grew on the scab.'
'Al-Jrab': Camels having mange, and its time becomes old so its fur grows on it. 'Al-Nashr': Mange. It is said 'Nashira al-ba'ir'. He says: So we, even if we reconciled after enmity, the grudge is in its state in the hearts. Similar is the saying of Al-Akhtal:

'Indeed the grudge, you meet it even if old ... Like the mange, it hides for a time then spreads.'
'Al-'Arr': Mange. A man 'Ma'rur' i.e., defected. Similar is the saying of Zufar bin al-Harith:
'And the pasture may grow on the dung of the soil ... While the sores of souls remain as they are.'
'Ad-Dimn': Urine and dung behind houses, if rain comes on it, it grows grass. Ibn al-Rumi said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And how many a spot I thought a garden ... So I found it a dung-heap with grass.'
'So I was calculating ... So when I calculated, calculation effaced the calculating tool.'
Al-Buhturi said regarding the race track:
'O beauty of the start of horses in their earliness ... Shining like stars in their darkness.'
'As if created in their fame ... A shaper who improved their forming.'
'From the grace of the nation in their management ... Carrying crows on their backs.'
'As if they, while the rope is in their chests ... Are falcons rising in their straps.'
'Men became honored by their assault ... Until when they leaned to their manager.'
'And turned descending in their slope ... The swooping of birds to their nests.'
Abu Hafs al-Basri said:
'I have a need that appeared, I intended with it ... Trust and boldness, Abu Ya'la.'
'I lightened it so its load would be light ... And it comes while it is easy, quick.'
'So it became heavy until I saw for it ... The heaviness of pregnancy, it decreed upon the pregnant.'
'So I abandoned him and forgot it out of disdain ... That he be a master for my blessing.'
Abu Alalah Imam al-Hamdawi said regarding a donkey (Munsarih Meter):
'O asker about the donkey of Tiyab ... That is a donkey ally of ailments.'
'As if he, while the tail-strap takes him ... From every side, is the shying of syrup (Dushab).' 
'The beauties of the rectum he loves ... If he appears rising from the door.'
Al-Ta'i said:
'And what is the benefit of one who spent the night yesterday thirsty ... If the sky of today prolonged its flow?'
'And favor with procrastination is only like a friend ... You became consoled of her when her visiting place became distant.'
Abu Hafs al-Basri said:
'The door of Abu al-Saqr bin Bulbul has a state ... Like what you narrated of the rest of the states.'
'When it ended, it was not known who was its lord ... Nor what he offered nor what he did.'
'The henna design of Al-Aruba resembled it, she dyed ... So when the week passed, its design faded.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking Al-Akhfash, Al-Mubarrad's boy (Munsarih Meter):
'As if I am with the wretched one apologizing ... When the rhymes hurt his ear.'
'He recites the covenant to me on the day of that, and the ... Covenant is a dye he reversed so it faded.'
Bashar said similar:
'Glory be to Him who created passion for those of trial ... It was nothing but like dye, so it faded.'
For Ibn al-Rumi:
'What we met of the wit of Wahb's fart ... It made the people of our age poets.'
'It is to me like the generosity of Fadl bin Yahya ... Except that it does not revive the poor.'
Similar is the saying of a butcher who was at the door of Al-Fadl bin Yahya:
'What we met of the generosity of Fadl bin Yahya ... Made all people poets.'
Abu al-Adhafir said:
'It taught the mute ones that they spoke ... Poetry about him, and the misers generosity.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Malik bin Tawq:
'What is the matter with me, I see the wide dome locked ... Before me, and for long I have found its lock ugly.'
'As if it is the Garden of Paradise displayed ... And I have no pure deed so I enter it.'
Al-Jamal al-Misri said:
'If a sickness befalls you, befall it ... And call Abu Ja'far for his calamity.'
'He knows what his companion complains of ... As if he roamed in his joints.'
Al-Ta'i said mentioning the death of Al-Mu'tasim and the rise of Al-Wathiq:
'A breaking like the return of the glance you have mended ... O son of Caliphs, what a mending.'
'Peoples have not seen a sun before it ... Set without following them with darkness.'
Similar is the saying of Abu al-Atahiya regarding Al-Amin after Al-Rashid:
'The eye weeps and the tooth is laughing ... So we are in a funeral and in a wedding.'
'The riser Al-Amin makes us laugh and ... The death of the Imam yesterday makes us weep.'
Abdullah bin al-Zubayr said regarding the sandgrouse:
'She turns in listening a head as if it is ... An orphan of walnut the nutcrackers missed.'
Imru' al-Qays said:
'Lo, if there are no camels, then goats ... As if their horns, the sticks polished them.'
'Going at evening as if they, from what they hit ... Suspended by their hips are buckets.'
'When their milker stood, they bleated ... As if an announcement of death came to the people in the morning.'
'So they fill our house with Eqt (dried curd) and ghee ... And suffice you of wealth satiety and quenching.'
Al-Buhturi said:

'The phantom of Mawiyah the circumambulator ... Kept an eye sleepless for her, and how?'
'There shakes from behind her a dune ... Her weak waist is tired by it.'
'And there shook in her cloak a branch ... Moderate, its figure is slender.'
'A maid among women, tender ... As if she is, in lightness, a servant boy.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Abu Sahl al-Nawbakhti, and he had cut off flour he used to provide him:
'O Abu Sahl, your praise is listened to ... And your generosity is hoped for and sought.'
'You have a current (Jar - salary/river), whenever I said it flowed ... And I longed for it, it was said: it stopped.'
'A joy from which sorrow results ... And safety from which fear is gathered.'
'Do not be like Time in his actions ... Whenever he gives his gifts, he gathers (takes back).'
Al-Ra'i said:
'And you see the Abyssinian in the middle of our houses ... Joyful when he obtains a meal one day.'
'Greasy, small-eared, as if the scalp of his head ... Was seeded so its sides grew pepper.'
'Al-Dasam': Pure blackness. A Bedouin said to his wife:
'You seek divorce while you are with me ... In a life like the sunny place of the North wind.'
Ibn al-Rumi said praising Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin Ubaydullah bin Sulayman (Basit Meter):
'A people who settle, in glory and honor ... And in wealth, the place of helmets and shields.'
'They settled in the place of both from every skull ... Defending and benefiting and shading the moist.'
'His sides shake at praise, he hears it ... Out of the shaking of glory not the shaking of mirth.'
'As if he, while asked and praised ... Ishaq sang to him and the strings are in clamor.'
Bashar said:
'If they saw her, they would not blame for weeping ... A generous one whom a haloed full moon gave wine.'
'And how can one forget she whose speech is as if ... In my ear, even if criticized, is a hanging earring.'
Ibn Harmah said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And I, and my leaving the generosity of the noble ... And my striking a stingy fire-stick with my palm.'
'Am like one leaving her eggs in the open ... And clothing the eggs of another with a wing.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'Lo, how ugly is the assembly, the rejecters ... The rejection of boils in the gathering.'
'As if the extraction places of their molars ... When they grinned are carcasses of the beetle.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'As if the Siwaks in his jaw ... When they are forced, uproot perfume.'
Another said:
'Banu Umayr, their glory is their house ... And every people, for them is glory.'
'As if they are desert truffles ... They have no before nor after.'
Tarafa said describing the ship:
'Her bow splits the bubbles of water with it ... As the gambler divided the dust with the hand.'
In it from beautiful simile is his saying:
'I see the grave of a miserly groaner with his money ... Like the grave of a strayer in error, corrupter.'
'I see two mounds of dust, upon them ... Are plates of stones, hard, arranged.'
'By your life, indeed death, whatever the youth missed ... Is like the slackened tether whose two ends are in the hand.'
'I am the lean man whom you know ... Active like the head of the snake, glowing.'
Like his saying "I see the grave of a miserly groaner" is the saying of Ibn al-Ziba'ra:
'And gifts are scarce among us ... And equal is the grave of a rich or a poor.'
And for Abu al-Atahiya:
'And I passed by the graves and did not ... Distinguish between the slave and the master.'
And for Abu Nuwas (Mujtath Meter):
'O eye, what is the matter with you, when ... You sickened a body, you settled.'
'So you were like the Jew ... In his deed, nay you exceeded.'
'He was needed one day ... He said: This is Saturday.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said mourning Ubaydullah bin Sulayman:
'They decreed what they decreed of his affair then advanced ... An Imam for them while the bier is before him.'
'So they prayed over him humbly as if they are ... Standing in rows for peace upon him.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking a woman:
'When she gave birth she was like the sender of hardness ... Leisurely it slipped out and he almost did not feel.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'And the pupil of an eye I deceived ... Deceiving as the cross-eyed looked.'
'Divided between the face of the beloved ... And the eye of the watcher when he neglects.'
Al-Mu'ammil said:
'And the people are like sticks (Ouds), some of them excel ... Some, thus an Oud surpasses an Oud.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'And by my father is one whom I came to visiting ... So he increased me in love upon my love.'
'And his illness yellowed his face ... So he became like the dinar from my right (Haqqi - box?).'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I do not have cheerfulness for the frow... ner out of excess of his confusion.'
'Rather I meet him frowning ... Scowling in the like of his state.'
'I am like the mirror, I meet ... Every face with its likeness.'
Al-Mubarrad recited:

'May Allah curse "No, by No" ... She was created the creation of the shears.'
'She cuts the beautiful ... And refuses generosity.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking Al-Raqaq and mentioning his mother:
'She tempts the penises if the night darkens ... Wider than the hoop of the millstone and smoother.'
'She swallows what the whale of Jonah swallowed ... If the arrow of a blind man aimed at it, he would hit.'
'If he hardened after you from him, no, he did not harden ... When he meets the hooded monk.'
'She grasps him the grasp of an archer a handle ... Until when he was worthy to vomit.'
'And his jugulars swelled and he stiffened ... Like the neck of the male ostrich when arched.'
'And she was pleased with him in sight and touch ... She returned him into her wombs inverted (taxes?).'
Another said regarding women he plays with:
'Thus without obscenity ... The play of fasting with the apples of orchards.'
Ibn Awn al-Katib said:
'Fasting came to us in the spring, so why did it not choo... se a month from the rest of the quarters?'
'And Sha'ban turned away except remnants ... Like the herpes from the blood of the frightened.'
'So as if the spring in fasting is a necklace ... Above a chest the excess of the mask covered.'
Abu Ali al-Basri said:
'And a night of obstruction, no sleep in it ... I was sleepless in it until the breaking dawn.'
'The roof of a house prevented me sleep in it ... As if its sky is the eye of the yearning one.'
'The clouds connected while it is a house ... And repelled while it is the middle of the road.'
'The eyes of our neighbors overflow upon us ... If they look at the thin cloud.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I will turn away from what Time turned away from ... And drink it pure even if a blamer blamed.'
'For I saw the cup, O Salm, a friend ... She protected me while my head is turbaned with gray hair.'
'I connected so she was not stingy to me with her connection ... And she had been stingy with connection, using kunya and concealing.'
'And it is of the cutter of pleasures that some of them came ... To compel a time that displeased him, so he is more compelled.'
Ibn al-Ahnaf said (Munsarih Meter):
'I am deprived of you because of what I say, while ... The lovers attained by it from those they loved.'
'Until as if I am a wick set up ... Illuminating for people while it is burning.'
Ibn al-Rumi said mocking:
'A Sheikh of ours nicknamed Abu Hafsal ... Horned like the foolish mountain goat.'
'A Sheikh adorned upon his confirmation ... With the ornament of the one-eyed and the cross-eyed.'
'His eyes were equal in his face ... The worst two loads on a camel litter.'
'I was informed in his house are women ... Wearing the garment of night like the work clothes.'
'Doing in it a righteous deed ... Allah raises it to the lowest.'
'People ask forgiveness with their hands ... And they ask forgiveness with legs.'
Al-Farazdaq said a verse he swore by divorce that Jarir would not invalidate, which is:
'For indeed I am Death who is descending ... By your soul, so look how you try him.'
Jarir started rolling in the sun until the sun almost set, then he said: I am Abu Hazrah, the wife of the wicked one is divorced. And he said:
'I am Time, Death perishes and Time is eternal ... So bring me the like of Time, something to match it.'
That reached Al-Farazdaq, so he said to the one who informed him: I asked you but to conceal this hadith.
Another said:
'And the saying, you do not own it if it grew ... Like the arrow, the archer who shot does not own it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said reproaching:
'I showed affection until I did not find one showing affection ... And I bored my pens with repeated reproach.'
'As if I draw near with you the son of a Jinn ... If the pull draws him near to the chest, he goes further.'
Al-Jahiz recited:
'The night of fleas is a night I do not enjoy ... For death is easier than the night of fleas.'
'As if they and my skin when they were alone with it ... Are orphans of evil disputing over inheritances.'
Another said:
'As if the nape of Harun when he stood turning back ... Is the nape of a spider, from her rear a thread was pulled.'
'Oh would that Harun was on the back of a scorpion ... And Harun had neither slipper nor sandal.'
Di'bil said:
'If he faulted me, he faulted only his discipliner ... So he faulted himself when he faulted his manners.'
'And he was like the dog his trainer trained ... For his hunting, so he attacked and hunted his dogs.'
Sa'id bin Humayd said:
'A brother to me, his brotherhood is like the days of life ... Colored in many colors are its conditions.'
'If I was absent from him for a trait so I mocked it ... I remembered from him a trait I do not fault.'
Bashar said:
'Rest to a dwelling you are pleased with ... Time has gone and you are alone.'
'You hope for tomorrow, and tomorrow is like a pregnant woman ... In the tribe, they do not know what she will give birth to.'
Al-Mubarrad recited (Munsarih Meter):

'Move your hands which I thought ... No doubt in what I see are of wood.'
'Why do I see people taking and giv... ing and enjoying property?'
'While you are like the donkey, your skin does not ... Feel pain from the touch of the tongues of Arabs.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And our children are like limbs, whichever ... We lost, the tragic separation was the loss.'
'Does the eye after the ear hear like it ... Or the ear after the eye guide as it guides?'
Another said:
'Indeed she who carried you nine months ... Is in the dhimma of accidents since you did not succeed.'
'Itching flared in her ass so as if ... Maps of the seeker of marriage turned on it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said (Munsarih Meter):
'I aspire like the eagle in the sky (Sakak) and do not ... Incline his inclination to the carcasses.'
For Al-Khalil (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So your hands were not created for generosity ... And their miserliness was not an innovation.'
'So a hand from good is clenched ... As a hundred grasped seven.'
'And a hand, its three thousands ... And its nine hundred are a law for it.'
Al-Alawi said:
'O idol cast from silver ... In his cheek is a fresh apple.'
'As if the kiss in his cheek ... In beauty, from its delicacy, is a bite.'
Another said:
'No wonder is more wonderful than what I see ... People rise and I go down.'
'I have become a lean body in the bed of passion ... As if I am a line above it.'
Ibn al-Rumi said describing a woman:
'All my day is cloudy from her eye sockets ... And the night is sunny from her while it is cloudless.'
'As if she, while the smoke of aloeswood covers her ... Is a sun upon which are clouds and darknesses.'
'Al-Uthan': Smoke. 'Uthan al-Nadd': Its best.
Al-Najim said regarding a boy:
'As if he, when he appeared in a dirty jubbah ... Is an illuminating full moon upon which are pieces of smoke.'
Mutammim bin Nuwayra said mourning his brother:
'And every youth among people after the son of his mother ... Is like one of his hands falling from the rope.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'You search for his news so as if ... I dug up his echo after the third burial.'
Similar is his saying:
'I praised you with the like of your scent dead ... On the day after a day the wood smells foul.'
The wife of Rawh bin Zinba' said to her husband:
'I praise you with what I knew, for indeed I ... Praise you with the like of the smell of the sock.'
Al-Mubarrad recited to us similar:
'How did a scroll come to me from you ... Its address sealed like the scorpion?'
'So I knew that evil is in its key ... So I broke its seal from the like of the smell of the sock.'
Written on it was Isa's writing.
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Abu al-Saqr:
'What is the matter with me with you, as if I planted pebbles ... In a year of drought and the back of the earth is smooth rock.'
'Is there a time for my planting so I wait for it ... Until it grows as there is a time for planting?'
Ali bin Jabalah said regarding the blaze:
'And people are like horses, whether dispraised or praised ... So the possessor of markings is like the possessor of blazes among people.'
Suwayd bin Abi Kahil said regarding it:
'It is the adornment of the face for the man as ... The beauties of piebaldness adorned the horse.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'She looked so she hit the heart with her arrow ... Then she turned away from it so it almost wandered.'
'Woe to him, if she looked and if she turned away ... The falling of arrows and their extraction is painful.'
Similar is his saying:
'For her glance while it is turned away is like its falling ... In the heart when its falling frightens the heart.'
'She repels with the glance, not like the arrow, turning it ... Away from me, but like the arrow she extracts it.'
Abu al-Shis said (Munsarih Meter):
'And a companion I had and I was to him ... More compassionate than a father to a child.'
'We were like a leg a foot runs with ... Or like a forearm attached to an upper arm.'
'Until when my hand sought support from his hand ... I was like one seeking support from the hand of the lion.'
Al-Hamduni said regarding a skin describing the stench of its armpit:
'Say to her do not rub it, for it does not ... Benefit striking the drum under the cloak.'
'How can it be hidden when it spotted the ... Underpants from it like the black bile.'
Abu al-Najm the Rajiz said:
'Indeed the youth becomes for illnesses ... Like the target set up for arrows.'
'A shooter missed and a shooter hit.'
Another said (near Mutaqarib):
'And while he dodges and they shoot him ... They shot so they hurried him from dodging.'
A Bedouin said describing his armpit:
'As if my armpit, when the time was long ... Is a whiff of a jar from the pickles of the villages.'
Amr bin al-Sharid said:
'O our neighbor, indeed calamities take turns ... Upon people, they hit all the mistaken.'
Ibn Abi Uyaynah said:

'I came to you visiting to fulfill a right ... So the walk prevented from you and the veil.'
'And you are a group, among you is a brother of mine ... As if his brotherhood is the mirage.'
'And I am not falling into the pot of a people ... Even if they hated, as the fly falls.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Sulayman al-Tahiri:
'As if Baghdad, since she saw ... His appearance, is a wailing woman beating her face.'
'Facing from him and turning back ... A face of a miser and a nape of a defeated.'
Muslim said regarding Ibn Jami':
'For I and Isma'il on the day of his separation ... Are like the scabbard on the day of fear, the blade separated from it.'
'If I come to a people after them or visit them ... Then like the wild beast, the drought brings it near the hunting.'
Another said:
'Eloquent when he complains of passion to other than her ... But if he meets her, then not eloquent.'
'As if you are thirsty seeking a water source ... If he attains quenching, then not swallowing.'
Another said:
'And they said: If you wish you would forget her ... I said to them: As if I do not wish.'
'So how, when her love hangs in my heart ... As buckets hung by ropes?'
Similar is the saying of Al-Ahwas:
'Affection has been fixed in the chest from you ... As fingers are fixed in the palms.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The most enjoyable kindness is what came from a friend ... Who counts the loan to friends as an obligation.'
'I bear the matter, and it is a heavy burden ... For friends, the bearing of some of me some.'
Harun bin al-Hasan bin Sahl said:
'For the drinking of wine a place in my heart ... I likened it to the visits of the beloved.'
'Would that wine lasted for me my life ... So I drink it and run in sins.'
Another said describing a male ostrich entered a meadow:
'And as if from the flower of lavender and dew ... And chamomile upon him is a sheet of a bridegroom.'
'And if his flies hummed around him ... He listened to it like a fearful apprehensive one.'
Antara said describing a meadow:
'And the fly was alone in it, so it is not leaving ... Singing like the action of the humming drinker.'
'Trilling, rubbing his arm with his arm ... The strike of the bent one on the mutilated fire-stick.'
Ibn al-Rumi said describing a plant:
'And the spring fly sang during it ... As the intoxicated urged a raised cymbal.'
'So the buzzing of the fly was there ... Upon the singing of birds a rhythmic beat.'
Bakr bin Kharijah said:
'And overbearing on the wine, he went early to it ... Among youths skilled in the morning drink of wine.'
'So every palm he saw he thought a cup ... And every person he saw he thought the cupbearer.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I sought an increase from you by blame ... and sympathy, but you exempted with one of the calamities.'
'So I was like one arranging a cloud imagined ... Rain, so it struck him with one of the thunderbolts.'
Al-Ahwas said:
'So I said: Indeed Abu Hafs, there reaches me ... From him a gift that sufficed me debt and travel.'
'And worry fled from me after there attended ... From him settled [gifts], not their loom chests.'
'So I was among you like one rained on in his town ... So he was pleased that he gathered the homelands and the rain.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Abu Hafsal abandoned me unjustly ... So our enemies became joyful.'
'I joked with him in some of his days ... So he became in puffiness like the pregnant woman.'
'I have no sin, rather on his wife ... When she defecated in my lower beard.'
Similar is his saying:
'You showed me the rope of arrogance, so carry ... A load for which you spend the night in a night of labor.'
By Bakr bin al-Nattah mocking Abu Dulaf, and it is said it is by Mansur bin Badhan al-Isbahani:
'O Abu Dulaf, indeed the poor with his eye ... Is for who hopes for the gift of your generosity and expects it.'
'I see for you a locked door, inaccessible ... If they opened it from you, then misery is inside it.'
'And indeed you are not ashamed of meanness for that which ... You are stingy with the thing which you are eating.'
'As if you are a drum, wonderful of sound, impressing ... Empty of goods, desolate its entrances.'
'And the most amazing thing in you is greeting once ... Upon you, based on my opinion, and that you accept it.'
Al-Hamdawi said mocking a man who gave him sour wine to drink:
'You drank wine and gave vinegar to drink ... Indeed you exceeded the mean ones in deed.'
'A wine that was for the oppressed for an era ... The livers of the boon companions crumble from it.'
'So my liver from it is Khaniz (pickled meat), as if I ... Gulp when I drink it the hot water (Hamim).'
'More similar to your face, for it is a face ... Frowning, grim, that will not be desired.'
'If they coupled a thousand bulls with your face ... They would become from its sourness jelly.'
Ibn al-Rumi said similar:
'Indeed by my life, you retaliated from every molar ... That was committing crime against you in your Zaghfan (type of food/bread?).'

'You did not find a trick for us when we wronged ... You, so you rewarded us by drinking your jars.'
'A taste of it ignited us resembling ... A boredom that afflicts you from your guests.'
'We have wished it, so save it for your Sikbaj ... And the calamities of your times.'
'And take it on your table as condiment ... For it is more worthy of vinegar than your boon companion.'
Al-Nazzam said:
'O shining one who filled the eyes ... So their glance does not rise.'
'He topped the sun of the forenoon ... Until as if the sun is a shadow.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The fire in his cheeks burns ... And the water in his cheeks flows.'
'Two opposites have been gathered as if they are ... My tear pouring and my anguish burning.'
He has mocking Sa'id:
'We found you a land whose seeds are many ... Hard its streams, few its dwellings.'
'You grew tall with the stalk of the palm unjustly, so rejoice ... Your trunks will rise with you shortly.'
Bashar said: Al-Majnun erred in his saying:
'Lo, Layla is only a bamboo stick ... If they touched it with palms it softens.'
He said: If he claimed she is a stick of butter or a stick of brain, that would be an error that he made her a stick. Why not as I said:
'And wide-eyed of tears from Ma'add ... As if her speech is the fruit of Paradise.'
'When she stood for her prayer she bent ... As if her bones are of bamboo.'
Another said:
'As if the moles in his face ... Are stars that surrounded the full moon.'
Ibn al-Rumi said considering Abu al-Saqr slow:
'My praise is the staff of Moses, and that is because I ... Struck with it the sea of generosity so it became shallow.'
'So oh would that I knew if I struck the rock with it ... Would it send forth for me from it streams pouring?'
'So that which showed, you see the sea dry ... And split springs in the stones pouring.'
'I will praise some of the researchers, perhaps he ... Even if analogy is consistent, will be generous.'
Al-Jahiz recited:
'The speech of Banu Zutt if you met them ... Like the chirping of locusts in the Arfaj (Mutaqarib).' 
Another said:
'As if Banu Ralan when their gathering came ... Are chicks among whom Sawiq is thrown.'
Another said:
'A slave girl, in her skin is a fish ... As if she is wearing the skin of a whale.'
'You think her, from the weakness of her voice ... A fly in the grip of a spider.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And he sang, as if your voice in your no... se is the sound of the wasp in the hollow of a furnace.'
Another said:
'You enabled yourself of my heart so you resolved to kill it ... Without seriousness from you, and the soul goes.'
'Like a sparrow in the hand of a child burdening it ... Entrance to the pools of death while the child plays.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'As if my eyelid upon the darkness, offering it ... To the hashish, are the tips of shears.'
'If my night is a night having no end ... Then my eyelid does not bend for closing.'
Abu Awn al-Katib said:
'I seek refuge for you from a night spent in it ... Your friend a night until the morning.'
