'As if I am a scribe who betrayed money ... So the Imam handed him to Najah.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'And the sufficiency of dye for the owner of gray ha... ir is the sufficiency of charms for the sickly.'
Similar is the saying of Abu Dhu'ib:
'And when death sinks its claws ... You found every amulet not benefiting.'
Al-Ma'mun said:
'Return the cup to me, for you both ... Do not know what wine avails.'
'If you tasted what I tasted, it was not mixed ... Except with your tears from passion.'
'There is nothing like its blessings when it included ... Except the inclusion of a mouth on a cheek.'
'If you do not drink with me ... Fearing punishment, I drank it alone.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'Progeny of light which touch does not perceive ... When it appears, the full moon and sun close their eyes to it.'
'By it desires became, a desire gathers them ... As if the souls of people in his love are one soul.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I am a stranger in a land with no noble people ... Like the strangeness of the black hair in the gray hair.'
Bashar said:
'The promise of the generous urges his giving ... Like the rain, its thunder precedes its rain.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The enemies step over deliberately to giv... ing like the pouring of rain without lightning.'
He has (Munsarih Meter):
'My provision for two months, four have known it ... Exceeding ten.'
'And the excess of the knot is like the hump for it ... If cut, it left on its back a sore.'
'And how is the carrying of the sterile its rider ... No how, when his travel cut him with it.'
'So leave for my provision its hump with it ... For you are more worthy of honoring its dignity.'
Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi said:

'I imagined her among the safflower-dyed women ... A rose in anemones.'
'You are my apple, and in you with the ap... ple are two pomegranates on a Ban branch.'
'I do not see in other than you what is in you of per... fume and of joy and of basil.'
'So if you are mine and in you is what is in ... you, then what is my need for the garden?'
Another said:
'White in red clothes like a rose ... White between anemones.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'As if the hands of their mounts when they trotted ... Tread on the heat of my face or on my sight.'
'I have of longing what if the least of it ... Were poured into water, it would not be drunk due to turbidity.'
For Habib bin Isa al-Katib, grandfather of Ibn Awn:
'We were alone a famous night ... The talk was good and secrets were effaced.'
'In every moonlit night, as if its whiteness ... For the night-talkers when it split is a day.'
'So as if it was upon us an hour ... And thus the nights of lovers are short.'
Similar is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'A night whose two ends almost met ... In shortness, and it is the night of Christmas.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I likened the redness of his face in his robe ... To anemones in wild thyme (Namam).'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Ibn Dalil the Christian when he promised him a sandal:
'Fulfill the promise, for the best of your prom... ises is what your credibility came after.'
'Let not the one you promised be, when you meet ... him, a speck your eye ducts reject.'
'Do not change color, the changing of the mule in the san... dal, and let not your taste differ to me.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding the donkey of Sulayman the physician:
'This donkey is among donkeys a donkey ... Upon whom a necklace and a bridle wailed.'
'So as if movements from him are stillnesses ... And as if his advancing is retreating.'
Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi said describing the trellis of the vine (Mutaqarib Meter):
'From a daughter of a vine the Naba... t (farmers) continue making from it a trellis, a trellis.'
'If you faced it, you thought it ... Green cloaks clothed in engravings.'
For Ibn al-Mu'tazz describing a vine:
'Until when the heat of August boiled its cauldron ... With a collapsing from the heat of the sun, burning.'
'Its clusters remained coming out of leaves ... As the Zanj sat with knees up in green waist-wrappers.'
Another said:
'Love is infatuation until the ... Soul of the lover intends it, so he meets death like play.'
'Its beginning is from a casual glance ... Or a joke ignited in the heart like the flame.'
'Like fire, its beginning is from a spark, so if ... It blazed, it ignited the gathered wood.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn al-Ahnaf:
'Love, the first of what it is, is for a need ... That brings it and fates drive it.'
'Until when the youth storms the depths of passion ... Matters come that are unbearable, great.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'I spend the evening and morning from remembering you ... And as if I have a touch of madness (Mass).'
'And as if I, from what prolonged in me ... Of you of sickness, was painted with Wars.'
'And I have become weary of life when ... It contained me and you turned away from my soul.'
For Abu al-Najm al-Katib Habib bin Isa, grandfather of Ibn Awn:
'So oh my wonder at a human image ... The whiteness of the sun covered it in the yellowness of the moon.'
'So she came as the pearl, its color shines ... Like the basil of the garden for smelling and sight.'
'A sick wind reminds me of your scent ... Ran with the breeze of the meadow in the darkness of dawn.'
Bashar said similar (Munsarih Meter):
'A yellow saffron-dyed one appeared to my heart ... She poured upon us from her beauty a seduction.'
'As if she is a flowering meadow ... Gathering perfume and a beautiful sight.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The ink of Abu Hafs is the saliva of the night ... As if it is the colors of the darkness of horses.'
'It flows to the brothers the flow of the torrent ... Without weight and without measure.'
'As if it is from the river of Dujayl.'
Abu Nuwas said in a poem:
'So I stood up strutting, turning it ... And the flute burst forth with the cymbal.'
'Then I leaned on its back (buttocks) ... As if I am a bird on a tower.'
'So there was play from us for an hour ... And the carder burst forth in carding.'
Ishaq al-Mawsili said (Hazaj Meter):
'Gazelles like wild cows (Ya'afir) ... Sweeping in the chambers.'
'And they turned back with buttocks ... Like the waists of wasps.'
Ibn Abi Rabi'ah said:
'They face each other like full moons on bran... ches in a heavy weight of buttocks.'
'With waists imitating the waists of was... ps, weak, intending to break.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:

'O many a secret like the fire of the rock, hidden ... I made its revealing die from me so it revived me.'
Abu Nuwas said (Madid Meter):
'And a cousin who does not reveal to us ... We have worn him on his grudge.'
'Hatred hid in him for us ... Like the hiding of fire in its stone.'
Another said:
'Watering for a night passed, how good it was ... Were it not for separation and disturbance at dawn.'
'Indeed the messenger who comes without promise ... Is like the cloud that comes without rain.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'So take it, embroidered, you embellished it ... And fingertips wove it what a weaving.'
'In a shape taking the adorned letter ... As if its lines are branches of thorns.'
Al-Alawi said:
'A striver with a cup between my boon companions ... Like the branch of squeezed water.'
'As if he strives for my passion for him ... What is between them in the fold of my vitals.'
'I am jealous of his standing whenever ... He said to the toucher of the cup: My master.'
'Until they became, while they are my brothers ... From intensity of jealousy, my enemies.'
Al-Buhturi said:
'I did not imagine my blessing betraying me ... The betrayal of dew, it settled then moved.'
'A time whose events play with me ... The play of the violent wind with the trembling spear.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding praying for rain (Munsarih Meter):
'I said when he shouted raising his hand ... Leave the creatures for Allah protects them.'
'And be certain of quenching from Him just as ... The heavy load of buckets slowed the filler.'
Ibn al-Rumi said blaming a man he asked for wheat (Mutaqarib Meter):
'I asked you for grains for the Kashk of pots ... A companion to those new characters.'
'As if I asked you for the love of hea... rts, that which is behind the pericardium.'
'I asked for two Qafiz of wheat ... So you were generous with a measure of refusal, full.'
Ibn al-A'rabi recited:
'When the askers came to him, lit ... Upon him were lamps of cheerfulness and joy.'
'He has for those of need a grace as if it is ... Locations of water of the rain cloud in the barren land.'
Ibn al-Rumi said praising:
'The luck of his hands from their reward became ... Like the luck of his eyes from a face having beauty.'
'So people do not see in a day his beauties ... Multiples of what he sees of them in a time.'
He has:
'May I be your ransom, I did not ask ... You that reward for the shroud.'
'I asked you for it to wear it ... While my soul is still in my body.'
'And procrastination with it has been long ... And I feared the accidents of time.'
'So your opinion regarding the gift with it ... Is your guardian, O brother of favors.'
'And do not make it a yarn whose ... Weaver settled to Aden.'
'Lo, and make it complying with ... The beauties of your beautiful face.'
'Precise like your acumen wh... ich became finer than accumens.'
'Firm like your opinion, inde... ed it and determination are in a horn (coupled).'
'Pure like your honor, in... deed your honor is not possessing filth.'
'And do not think yourself exhausting it ... Praise is sufficient as a price.'
'And suffice you if you are stingy with it ... With the loss of praise in fraud.'
Al-Buhturi said praising:
'And if you saw the characters of the two sons of Sa'id ... They delivered to you the characters of the two sons of Makhlad.'
'Like the two Farqad stars, if a looker contemplates ... The position of a Farqad did not rise above a Farqad.'
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'I passed by a baker flattening the thin bread faster than the return of the glance. Between seeing the dough in his hand like a ball until it spreads and becomes like the moon is the duration of a moment. I likened the speed of its spreading to the speed of the circle in water into which a stone is thrown. So I said: I do not forget':
'I do not forget a baker I passed by ... Rolling the thin bread the speed of the glance of the eye.'
'Between seeing it in his palm as a ball ... And seeing it round like the moon.'
'Is but the amount of what a circle spreads ... In the surface of water into which is thrown a stone.'
Al-Ta'i said regarding Iftar:
'They watched the tops of a palm tree so as if they ... Watched the crescent for the night of Iftar.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding bedbugs:
'I spent a night, all of it I did not blink ... Its bedbug is like the plucked nap.'
'The skin leaps behind the cloak ... Until is seen in it like the shape of the Koran.'
'Or like the sprinkling of dissolved safflower.'
Yahya bin Nawfal said:
'We called upon Allah the Possessor of Blessings when ... The authority of slaves prolonged upon us.'
'To remove what is with us of bad state ... By Maslamah the Blessed or Sa'id.'
'So we were, while the Caliph when he threw us ... On sincerity with the iron lock.'
'Like the people of Hell when they sought help ... They were helped with boiling water with pus.'
Bashar said:

'When Al-Mahdi went early among his people ... Or went at evening among the family of the Messenger, the angry ones.'
'The good (Al-Ma'ruf) appeared to you in his face ... Like the water on teeth (Zulm) running in the folds of the buxom girls.'
Abu al-Atahiya said:
'And perhaps the youth feared ... What there is no escape from cautioning.'
'Like the one protecting against the drops of the clou... d while around him in the earth is a sea.'
Another said (Munsarih Meter):
'Abd al-Aziz was deprived in his she-donkeys ... And in his workhorses and in his camels.'
'The workhorse of Abd al-Aziz is shaken of ... Creation, the so-and-so is above his price.'
'As if he, while whips take him ... Is a brother of gravity who closed eyes on his grudges.'
Abu al-Najm said:
'He approaches the stream like the stream ... He throws into his larynx like the cauldron.'
'As if the sound of his hurried gulping ... Is a boulder you rolled in stones.'
Dhu al-Rumma said:
'So they treated a heat from their insides ... With anxiety like the middles of the successive sandgrouse.'
Another said (Mutaqarib Meter):
'So I advise you with the stabbing of the brave ... For you have known that there is no eternity.'
'And striking skulls the harm of the de... af the colocynth of a ravine gathering seeds.'
The deaf, if struck, does not hear, so he intensifies the beating. 'Al-Habid': Seeds of colocynth.
Ibn al-Rumi said:
'The eye does not cease from looking ... And the soul does not cease from wandering.'
'And the beauties of things in you are together ... So my two boredoms are the boredoms of Basra.'
'The enjoyments of your face in its intuition ... Are new, and in their consequences are the others.'
'And as if your face from its renewal ... Is moving for the eye in forms.'
He has (Munsarih Meter):
'There is nothing except in it is its best ... So the eye moves from it to you.'
'The benefits of the eye from it are its new ... As if its lasts are the first.'
He also has:
'My glance to your glance when you look is a killing spot ... But your glance is an arrow of death sent.'
'And of wonders is that one meaning ... It is from you an arrow and it is from me a killing spot.'
He also has:
'She gave him my eye the slumber ... So she rewarded it from him with tears.'
'A gazelle, as if in his waist ... From his leanness is thirst and hunger.'
Bil'a' bin Qays said:
'She saw me prostrate from wine one day so I displeased her ... And for the drinkers, the addicted ones, are falling places.'
'With me is every loose-baldricked one as if he ... When he appears from the sole of the foot is limping.'
Ibn al-Rumi said on the death of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir:
'The Emir died and the full moon of our sky died ... This bids us farewell and this eclipses.'
'A moon saw a moon sacrificing himself ... So a brother, consoling, fair, wept for his brother.'
Ju'ayfaran al-Muwswis said regarding renters:
'As if they, while life tops them ... And breaths have risen for the people.'
'Are threshing floors for tax stopped ... When their permission came to them, they trod.'
Ibn al-Rumi said regarding Ubaydullah bin Sulayman:
'You dispense with all eulogy by your virtue ... The dispensing of gazelles with kohl against using kohl.'
'Your state shines in the state of Islam ... As if it is the nation of Islam among nations.'
Another said:
'He became sacrificing himself and as if he ... Is a moon covered by darkness with an eclipse.'
'And decay walked in his body so as if he ... Is a plush rose announcing dryness.'
Abu al-Hindi excelled in his saying:
'I gave Abu al-Mutarrah drink when he came to me ... While the possessor of earrings was erect, shouting.'
'A drink flies flee from ... And the eloquent one lisps when he drinks it.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a rain:
'It clothes the lands a shirt from its ornaments ... As if it is buttoned over the body of the earth.'
'Its wild calves remained drowned, thrown down ... As if they are pearls scattered in the horizon.'
Similar is the saying of Ibn al-Rumi describing gray hair:
'As if my spearhead when a star met it ... Hit by it are pieces of cloud, white.'
The sitter of the slave girl of Ja'far bin Yahya looked down on the children of the Barmakids while they were playing, so she said:
'As if they, with the children of the mob in number ... Are pearls and beads scattered on the earth.'
Al-Jammaz was in love with a slave girl in Basra, and a servant in Basra from the Sultan's servants called Sinan used to overcome him regarding her. Al-Jammaz said (Mudari' Meter):
'What is for the hateful Sinan ... And for the beautiful gazelles?'
'Is he not an adulterer, eunuch ... Raiding without a weapon?'
He says regarding him (Mujtath Meter):
'A gazelle, Sinan is my partner ... In him, so what a miserable partner.'
'For Sinan does not fuck ... And he did not let me fuck.'
He says regarding her (Mujtath Meter):
'I did not think Tughya... n loved Time other than me.'

After the intimacy that was... between her vulva and my member.

And another said:
If you deny us weapons, we have... a weapon of ours not bought with dirhams.
Boulders filling the palms, as if they were... heads of men shaved by razors.

And another said:
War is joined by those who hate it, just as... healthy camels come upon the scabby ones and infect them.

It is said that war was called 'Ghashum' (Oppressive) because it afflicts the non-perpetrator. The origin of this saying belongs to Al-Harith bin Abbad:
I was not one of its perpetrators, Allah knows... yet today I burn in its heat.

Similar to it is the poet's saying:
Your perpetrator is the one who commits the crime against you, yet... the kneeling places of scabby camels may infect the healthy ones.

Ibn al-Rumi said:
I saw the perpetrators of war were not its sufficient defenders... when the interlocked spears clashed within it.
Likewise, the flints of fire are safe from it... but the stokers burn in its heat.

And another said:
Speech is like milked milk; it has no... return. How can the milker return the milk [to the udder]?
Likewise is speech; it has no... return into the hollow [of the chest], whether ugly or beautiful.

And another said:
O friend, have you seen or heard of a shepherd... who returned to the udder what he drew into the milking vessels?

Similar to it:
And speech, you do not own it once it rises... like the arrow, the archer who shot it does not own it.

And another said about a man who ate very little:
Little food in the belly, except for a bit... of provision as an excuse, just as the falcon eats.

A'sha Bahila said:
A slice of meat suffices him like it... if he touches the roast, and a small cup satisfies his thirst.

Tarafa said, mocking Amr bin Hind for eating too much:
He drinks until the pure milk overwhelms his heart... but if you give him [food], I leave a roosting place for my heart [i.e., remain alert].
And there is no fault in him except that he is wealthy... and that he has a flank, when he stands, that is slender [sarcastic or contrasting].

This is the opposite of Urwa bin al-Ward's saying:
I divide my body among many bodies... and I sip pure water while the water is cold.

Al-A'sha said:
I saw you yesterday as the best of Banu Ma'add... and you today are better than you were yesterday.
And tomorrow you will increase double upon double... thus do the masters of Abd Shams increase.

Ibn al-Mu'tazz said regarding wasps:
And troops I came upon early with fire... that blazes when it senses a wind.
The eye was delighted when it saw them falling... like scattered confetti of beautiful pebbles.
How many a screamer among them yells and howls... like a wineskin thrown down among drinking companions.

Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman bin Hassan bin Thabit said to his father when a wasp stung him: 'A creature stung me, looking like a Hibara garment.' His father said: 'My son has spoken poetry, by Allah.'

Ibn al-Mu'tazz said describing a book:
Speckled, having a color like the gray hair of a middle-aged man... you think it has kohl applied, yet it has no kohl.
A rider of a palm [hand/pen], wherever it wishes, it travels.

And another said:
They shook the chests of the Mashrafiyah [swords] as if... they were falling upon the skulls of the people into fresh colocynth [melons].

And another said:
I saw you like a walnut; its good is withheld... while whole, and it gives its good when it is broken.

Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
What is wrong with your two chickens, suspended... like the suspension of Harut and Marut?
Perhaps at dawn they did not wake... a morning drinker at all with crowing.

And another said regarding lice:
Around Abu al-Ala are battlegrounds... between the killed and the wounded.
As if they are, at the buttons of his shirt... solitary ones and twins of husked sesame seeds.

And among the good things said in this meaning is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
Whoever's hunting trap is far from him... the trap of Ayyub is his clothes.
O Lord of one hiding by the side... of the seam, whom correctness surrounds.
Or a flea-jumper leaping... his leaping did not save him from him.
He aimed his finger at him with the slipperiness of the two corners [of the eye]... his finger-tips are his dogs.

Jarir said:
You see the nits adhering to him... like the goatee of Al-Farazdaq when he went gray.

Al-Hamdawi said:
I do not see, if I slaughtered Sa'id's sheep... anything obtained in my hands other than the hide.
Nothing but its bones; if you saw them... you would say: These are pine cones in a bag.

And another said:
Sodom was unjust in judgment once... and Musa bin Salih is more unjust than him today.
He transfers water with us until it is as if... he lunched on coffee beans or dined on salty fish.

Di'bil said:
He looks like a ram when he appears... but in his nature, he is a ewe.
If you sit by his side... you would think there is a lute in his scrotum.

A man killed a slave girl of his whom he saw flirting with a man, so the man said:

'Endure or ask for blessing over the killing of a young woman... as if the spray of musk was her breath.
A naive young woman died upon his hands... just as a narcissus dies amidst the drink and wine.'

Abu Nuwas said:
If a living thing were to escape destruction... a female eagle would have escaped at the peak of the mountain tops.
Mother of a little chick she protected in a hollow... as if she were seated due to senility.

Similar is his saying in Munsarih meter:
She bends her chest over a group... like the sitting of one bent by old age.

Al-Hudhali said:
He has a nature that clears up over the days... just as wine clears over time.

Al-Alawi al-Isbahani said:
Suns of literature rise in the darkness... and cast their rays upon the horizon of the conscience.
Meanings fulfilled in a conscience as if they were... wishes in which I encountered their fulfillment.

Ibn al-Rumi said regarding the crescent moon:
O you whose brow is the crescent, do you not see... the moon of the sky having shone in the East?
Like a shy virgin who looked at a mate of hers... then hid in shame behind a blue sleeve.

Abu Ishaq said: We have fulfilled in this book of ours all that we stipulated regarding rare similes and chosen gems, which it encompasses or points to. And praise be to Allah abundantly.
